"This was because my studies in architecture had been constantly turning"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"The only questions therefore were the following: What form shall the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"nations? A clear analysis of the principles on which the foreign policy"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of German statecraft were to be based should have led to the following"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conclusions:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The annual increase of population in Germany amounts to almost 900,000"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"souls. The difficulties of providing for this army of new citizens must"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"grow from year to year and must finally lead to a catastrophe, unless"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ways and means are found which will forestall the danger of misery and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"hunger. There were four ways of providing against this terrible"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"calamity:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"(1) It was possible to adopt the French example and artificially"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"restrict the number of births, thus avoiding an excess of population."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Under certain circumstances, in periods of distress or under bad"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"climatic condition, or if the soil yields too poor a return, Nature"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"herself tends to check the increase of population in some countries and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"impede the further existence of the offspring by submitting it to such"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"tests and privations that everything which is less strong or less"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"healthy is forced to retreat into the bosom of tile unknown. Whatever"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"survives these hardships of existence has been tested and tried a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"thousandfold, hardened and renders fit to continue the process of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"procreation; so that the same thorough selection will begin all over"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"again. By thus dealing brutally with the individual and recalling him"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the very moment he shows that he is not fitted for the trials of life,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Nature preserves the strength of the race and the species and raises it"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to the highest degree of efficiency."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The decrease in numbers therefore implies an increase of strength, as"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"far as the individual is concerned, and this finally means the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"invigoration of the species."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"But the case is different when man himself starts the process of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"numerical restriction. Man is not carved from Nature's wood. He is made"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of 'human' material. He knows more than the ruthless Queen of Wisdom. He"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"does not impede the preservation of the individual but prevents"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"procreation itself. To the individual, who always sees only himself and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"not the race, this line of action seems more humane and just than the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"opposite."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"By leaving the process of procreation unchecked and by submitting the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"individual to the hardest preparatory tests in life, Nature selects the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"best from an abundance of single elements and stamps them as fit to live"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and carry on the conservation of the species. But man restricts the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"procreative faculty and strives obstinately to keep alive at any cost"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"him to be wise and humane, and he rejoices at having trumped Nature's"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"card in one game at least and thus proved that she is not entirely"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"reliable. The dear little ape of an all-mighty father is delighted to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"see and hear that he has succeeded in effecting a numerical restriction;"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"but he would be very displeased if told that this, his system, brings"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"about a degeneration in personal quality."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For as soon as the procreative faculty is thwarted and the number of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"births diminished, the natural struggle for existence which allows only"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"But if that policy be carried out the final results must be that such a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"Any policy which aims at securing the existence of a nation by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"restricting the birth-rate robs that nation of its future."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"(2) A second solution is that of internal colonization. This is a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"proposal which is frequently made in our own time and one hears it"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"lauded a good deal. It is a suggestion that is well-meant but it is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"It is certainly true that the productivity of the soil can be increased"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"content with 'internal colonization.' But at the same time nations of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"inferior quality succeed in getting hold of large spaces for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"colonization all over the globe. The state of affairs which must result"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"from this contrast is the following:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Races which are culturally superior but less ruthless would be forced to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"restrict their increase, because of insufficient territory to support"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the population, while less civilized races could increase indefinitely,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"owing to the vast territories at their disposal. In other words: should"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that state of affairs continue, then the world will one day be possessed"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"by that portion of mankind which is culturally inferior but more active"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and energetic."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"A time will come, even though in the distant future, when there can be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"only two alternatives: Either the world will be ruled according to our"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"modern concept of democracy, and then every decision will be in favour"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of the numerically stronger races; or the world will be governed by the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"law of natural distribution of power, and then those nations will be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"victorious who are of more brutal will and are not the nations who have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"practised self-denial."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Nobody can doubt that this world will one day be the scene of dreadful"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"struggles for existence on the part of mankind. In the end the instinct"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of self-preservation alone will triumph. Before its consuming fire this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"so-called humanitarianism, which connotes only a mixture of fatuous"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"timidity and self-conceit, will melt away as under the March sunshine."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Man has become great through perpetual struggle. In perpetual peace his"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"greatness must decline."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For us Germans, the slogan of 'internal colonization' is fatal, because"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"it encourages the belief that we have discovered a means which is in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"accordance with our innate pacifism and which will enable us to work for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"our livelihood in a half slumbering existence. Such a teaching, once it"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"were taken seriously by our people, would mean the end of all effort to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"acquire for ourselves that place in the world which we deserve. If. the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"average German were once convinced that by this measure he has the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"chance of ensuring his livelihood and guaranteeing his future, any"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"attempt to take an active and profitable part in sustaining the vital"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"demands of his country would be out of the question. Should the nation"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"agree to such an attitude then any really useful foreign policy might be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"looked upon as dead and buried, together with all hope for the future of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the German people."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Once we know what the consequences of this 'internal colonization'"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"theory would be we can no longer consider as a mere accident the fact"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that among those who inculcate this quite pernicious mentality among our"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"people the Jew is always in the first line. He knows his softies only"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"too well not to know that they are ready to be the grateful victims of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"every swindle which promises them a gold-block in the shape of a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"discovery that will enable them to outwit Nature and thus render"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"superfluous the hard and inexorable struggle for existence; so that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"finally they may become lords of the planet partly by sheer DOLCE FAR"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"NIENTE and partly by working when a pleasing opportunity arises."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It cannot be too strongly emphasised that any German 'internal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"colonization' must first of all be considered as suited only for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"relief of social grievances. To carry out a system of internal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"colonization, the most important preliminary measure would be to free"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the soil from the grip of the speculator and assure that freedom. But"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"such a system could never suffice to assure the future of the nation"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"without the acquisition of new territory."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"If we adopt a different plan we shall soon reach a point beyond which"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the resources of our soil can no longer be exploited, and at the same"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"time we shall reach a point beyond which our man-power cannot develop."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In conclusion, the following must be said:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The fact that only up to a limited extent can internal colonization be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"practised in a national territory which is of definitely small area and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the restriction of the procreative faculty which follows as a result of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"such conditions--these two factors have a very unfavourable effect on"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the military and political standing of a nation."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The extent of the national territory is a determining factor in the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"external security of the nation. The larger the territory which a people"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"has at its disposal the stronger are the national defences of that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"people. Military decisions are more quickly, more easily, more"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"completely and more effectively gained against a people occupying a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"national territory which is restricted in area, than against States"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which have extensive territories. Moreover, the magnitude of a national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"territory is in itself a certain assurance that an outside Power will"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"not hastily risk the adventure of an invasion; for in that case the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"struggle would have to be long and exhausting before victory could be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"hoped for. The risk being so great. there would have to be extraordinary"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"reasons for such an aggressive adventure. Hence it is that the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"territorial magnitude of a State furnishes a basis whereon national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"liberty and independence can be maintained with relative ease; while, on"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the contrary, a State whose territory is small offers a natural"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"temptation to the invader."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"As a matter of fact, so-called national circles in the German REICH"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"rejected those first two possibilities of establishing a balance between"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the constant numerical increase in the population and a national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"territory which could not expand proportionately. But the reasons given"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"for that rejection were different from those which I have just"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"expounded. It was mainly on the basis of certain moral sentiments that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"restriction of the birth-rate was objected to. Proposals for internal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"colonization were rejected indignantly because it was suspected that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"such a policy might mean an attack on the big landowners, and that this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"attack might be the forerunner of a general assault against the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"principle of private property as a whole. The form in which the latter"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"solution--internal colonization--was recommended justified the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"misgivings of the big landowners."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"But the form in which the colonization proposal was rejected was not"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"very clever, as regards the impression which such rejection might be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"calculated to make on the mass of the people, and anyhow it did not go"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to the root of the problem at all."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Only two further ways were left open in which work and bread could be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"secured for the increasing population."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"(3) It was possible to think of acquiring new territory on which a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"certain portion of' the increasing population could be settled each"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"year; or else"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"(4) Our industry and commerce had to be organized in such a manner as to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"secure an increase in the exports and thus be able to support our people"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"by the increased purchasing power accruing from the profits made on"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"foreign markets."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Therefore the problem was: A policy of territorial expansion or a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"colonial and commercial policy. Both policies were taken into"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"consideration, examined, recommended and rejected, from various"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"standpoints, with the result that the second alternative was finally"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"adopted. The sounder alternative, however, was undoubtedly the first."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The principle of acquiring new territory, on which the surplus"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"population could be settled, has many advantages to recommend it,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"especially if we take the future as well as the present into account."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the first place, too much importance cannot be placed on the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"necessity for adopting a policy which will make it possible to maintain"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"a healthy peasant class as the basis of the national community. Many of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"our present evils have their origin exclusively in the disproportion"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"between the urban and rural portions of the population. A solid stock of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"small and medium farmers has at all times been the best protection which"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"a nation could have against the social diseases that are prevalent"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to-day. Moreover, that is the only solution which guarantees the daily"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"bread of a nation within the framework of its domestic national economy."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"With this condition once guaranteed, industry and commerce would retire"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"from the unhealthy position of foremost importance which they hold"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to-day and would take their due place within the general scheme of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"national economy, adjusting the balance between demand and supply. Thus"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"industry and commerce would no longer constitute the basis of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"national subsistence, but would be auxiliary institutions. By fulfilling"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"their proper function, which is to adjust the balance between national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"production and national consumption, they render the national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"subsistence more or less independent of foreign countries and thus"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"assure the freedom and independence of the nation, especially at"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"critical junctures in its history."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Such a territorial policy, however, cannot find its fulfilment in the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Cameroons but almost exclusively here in Europe. One must calmly and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"squarely face the truth that it certainly cannot be part of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"dispensation of Divine Providence to give a fifty times larger share of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the soil of this world to one nation than to another. In considering"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"this state of affairs to-day, one must not allow existing political"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"frontiers to distract attention from what ought to exist on principles"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of strict justice. If this earth has sufficient room for all, then we"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ought to have that share of the soil which is absolutely necessary for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"our existence."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Of course people will not voluntarily make that accommodation. At this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"point the right of self-preservation comes into effect. And when"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"attempts to settle the difficulty in an amicable way are rejected the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"clenched hand must take by force that which was refused to the open hand"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of friendship. If in the past our ancestors had based their political"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"decisions on similar pacifist nonsense as our present generation does,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"we should not possess more than one-third of the national territory that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"we possess to-day and probably there would be no German nation to worry"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"about its future in Europe. No. We owe the two Eastern Marks (Note 8) of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the Empire to the natural determination of our forefathers in their"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"struggle for existence, and thus it is to the same determined policy that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"we owe the inner strength which is based on the extent of our political"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and racial territories and which alone has made it possible for us to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"exist up to now."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"[Note 8. German Austria was the East Mark on the South and East Prussia"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"was the East Mark on the North.]"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"And there is still another reason why that solution would have been the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"correct one:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Many contemporary European States are like pyramids standing on their"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"apexes. The European territory which these States possess is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ridiculously small when compared with the enormous overhead weight of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"their colonies, foreign trade, etc. It may be said that they have the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"apex in Europe and the base of the pyramid all over the world; quite"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"different from the United States of America, which has its base on the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"American Continent and is in contact with the rest of the world only"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"through its apex. Out of that situation arises the incomparable inner"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"strength of the U.S.A. and the contrary situation is responsible for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"weakness of most of the colonial European Powers."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"England cannot be suggested as an argument against this assertion,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"though in glancing casually over the map of the British Empire one is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"inclined easily to overlook the existence of a whole Anglo-Saxon world."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"England's position cannot be compared with that of any other State in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Europe, since it forms a vast community of language and culture together"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"with the U.S.A."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Therefore the only possibility which Germany had of carrying a sound"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"territorial policy into effect was that of acquiring new territory in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Europe itself. Colonies cannot serve this purpose as long as they are"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"not suited for settlement by Europeans on a large scale. In the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"been more practical to undertake that military struggle for new"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"territory in Europe rather than to wage war for the acquisition of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"possessions abroad."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Such a decision naturally demanded that the nation's undivided energies"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"should be devoted to it. A policy of that kind which requires for its"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"fulfilment every ounce of available energy on the part of everybody"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"concerned, cannot be carried into effect by half-measures or in a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"hesitating manner. The political leadership of the German Empire should"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"then have been directed exclusively to this goal. No political step"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"should have been taken in response to other considerations than this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"task and the means of accomplishing it. Germany should have been alive"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to the fact that such a goal could have been reached only by war, and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the prospect of war should have been faced with calm and collected"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"The whole system of alliances should have been envisaged and valued from"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"have been mainly at Russia's cost, and once again the new German Empire"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"with its daily bread."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For such a policy, however, there was only one possible ally in Europe."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"That was England."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Only by alliance with England was it possible to safeguard the rear of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the new German crusade. The justification for undertaking such an"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"expedition was stronger than the justification which our forefathers had"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"for setting out on theirs. Not one of our pacifists refuses to eat the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"No sacrifice should have been considered too great if it was a necessary"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"the world's markets, also a renunciation of colonial intentions and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"naval power. All the means of power at the disposal of the State should"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"have been concentrated in the military forces on land. This policy would"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"have involved a period of temporary self-denial, for the sake of a great"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and powerful future."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"There was a time when England might have entered into negotiations with"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"us, on the grounds of that proposal. For England would have well"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"understood that the problems arising from the steady increase in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"with the help of England or, without England, in some other part of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"This outlook was probably the chief reason why London tried to draw"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"nearer to Germany about the turn of the century. For the first time in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"to know that an equivalent must be forthcoming as a consideration for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"Let us suppose that in 1904 our German foreign policy was managed"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"not easy to measure the greatness of the results that might have accrued"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"There would have been no world war. The blood which would have been shed"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"what a position Germany would hold in the world to-day?"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In any case the alliance with Austria was then an absurdity."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For this mummy of a State did not attach itself to Germany for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"In any case, the policy of oppression against the German population in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"Nothing was dreaded so much as the possibility of an armed conflict; but"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"They dreamt of maintaining a world peace and woke up to find themselves"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"And that dream of peace was a most significant reason why the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"There remained still another alternative, which we may call the fourth."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"This was: Industry and world trade, naval power and colonies."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Such a development might certainly have been attained more easily and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"In adopting such a course Germany must have known that to follow it out"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"No. Once we had taken this road, England was bound to be our enemy at"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"If a European territorial policy against Russia could have been put into"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"colonial and world-trade policy could have been carried into effect only"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"policy should have been adopted in full consciousness of all the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"

"At the turn of the century the alliance with Austria had become a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"veritable absurdity from all points of view."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"But nobody thought of forming an alliance with Russia against England,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"just as nobody thought of making England an ally against Russia; for in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"either case the final result would inevitably have meant war. And to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"avoid war was the very reason why a commercial and industrial policy was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"decided upon. It was believed that the peaceful conquest of the world by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"commercial means provided a method which would permanently supplant the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"policy of force. Occasionally, however, there were doubts about the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"efficiency of this principle, especially when some quite"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"incomprehensible warnings came from England now and again. That was the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"reason why the fleet was built. It was not for the purpose of attacking"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"or annihilating England but merely to defend the concept of world-peace,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"mentioned above, and also to protect the principle of conquering the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"world by 'peaceful' means. Therefore this fleet was kept within modest"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"limits, not only as regards the number and tonnage of the vessels but"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"also in regard to their armament, the idea being to furnish new proofs"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of peaceful intentions."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The chatter about the peaceful conquest of the world by commercial means"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"was probably the most completely nonsensical stuff ever raised to the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"dignity of a guiding principle in the policy of a State, This nonsense"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"became even more foolish when England was pointed out as a typical"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"example to prove how the thing could be put into practice. Our doctrinal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"way of regarding history and our professorial ideas in that domain have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"done irreparable harm and offer a striking 'proof' of how people 'learn'"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"history without understanding anything of it. As a matter of fact,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"England ought to have been looked upon as a convincing argument against"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the theory of the pacific conquest of the world by commercial means. No"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"nation prepared the way for its commercial conquests more brutally than"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"England did by means of the sword, and no other nation has defended such"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conquests more ruthlessly. Is it not a characteristic quality of British"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"statecraft that it knows how to use political power in order to gain"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economic advantages and, inversely, to turn economic conquests into"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"political power? What an astounding error it was to believe that England"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"would not have the courage to give its own blood for the purposes of its"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"own economic expansion! The fact that England did not possess a national"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"army proved nothing; for it is not the actual military structure of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"moment that matters but rather the will and determination to use"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"whatever military strength is available. England has always had the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"armament which she needed. She always fought with those weapons which"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"were necessary for success. She sent mercenary troops, to fight as long"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"as mercenaries sufficed; but she never hesitated to draw heavily and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"deeply from the best blood of the whole nation when victory could be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"obtained only by such a sacrifice. And in every case the fighting"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"spirit, dogged determination, and use of brutal means in conducting"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"military operations have always remained the same."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"But in Germany, through the medium of the schools, the Press and the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"comic papers, an idea of the Englishman was gradually formed which was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"bound eventually to lead to the worst kind of self-deception. This"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"absurdity slowly but persistently spread into every quarter of German"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"life. The result was an undervaluation for which we have had to pay a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"heavy penalty. The delusion was so profound that the Englishman was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"looked upon as a shrewd business man, but personally a coward even to an"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"incredible degree. Unfortunately our lofty teachers of professorial"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"history did not bring home to the minds of their pupils the truth that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"it is not possible to build up such a mighty organization as the British"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Empire by mere swindle and fraud. The few who called attention to that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"truth were either ignored or silenced. I can vividly recall to mind the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"astonished looks of my comrades when they found themselves personally"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"face to face for the first time with the Tommies in Flanders. After a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"few days of fighting the consciousness slowly dawned on our soldiers"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that those Scotsmen were not like the ones we had seen described and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"caricatured in the comic papers and mentioned in the communiquÃ©s."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It was then that I formed my first ideas of the efficiency of various"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"forms of propaganda."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Such a falsification, however, served the purpose of those who had"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"fabricated it. This caricature of the Englishman, though false, could be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"used to prove the possibility of conquering the world peacefully by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"commercial means. Where the Englishman succeeded we should also succeed."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Our far greater honesty and our freedom from that specifically English"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"'perfidy' would be assets on our side. Thereby it was hoped that the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"sympathy of the smaller nations and the confidence of the greater"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"nations could be gained more easily."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"We did not realize that our honesty was an object of profound aversion"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"for other people because we ourselves believed in it. The rest of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"world looked on our behaviour as the manifestation of a shrewd"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"deceitfulness; but when the revolution came, then they were amazed at"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the deeper insight it gave them into our mentality, sincere even beyond"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the limits of stupidity."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Once we understand the part played by that absurd notion of conquering"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the world by peaceful commercial means we can clearly understand how"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that other absurdity, the Triple Alliance, came to exist. With what"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"State then could an alliance have been made? In alliance with Austria we"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"could not acquire new territory by military means, even in Europe. And"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"this very fact was the real reason for the inner weakness of the Triple"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Alliance. A Bismarck could permit himself such a makeshift for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"necessities of the moment, but certainly not any of his bungling"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"successors, and least of all when the foundations no longer existed on"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which Bismarck had formed the Triple Alliance. In Bismarck's time"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Austria could still be looked upon as a German State; but the gradual"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"introduction of universal suffrage turned the country into a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"parliamentary Babel, in which the German voice was scarcely audible."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"From the viewpoint of racial policy, this alliance with Austria was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"simply disastrous. A new Slavic Great Power was allowed to grow up close"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to the frontiers of the German Empire. Later on this Power was bound to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"adopt towards Germany an attitude different from that of Russia, for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"example. The Alliance was thus bound to become more empty and more"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"feeble, because the only supporters of it were losing their influence"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and were being systematically pushed out of the more important public"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"offices."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"About the year 1900 the Alliance with Austria had already entered the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"same phase as the Alliance between Austria and Italy."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Here also only one alternative was possible: Either to take the side of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the Habsburg Monarchy or to raise a protest against the oppression of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the German element in Austria. But, generally speaking, when one takes"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"such a course it is bound eventually to lead to open conflict."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"From the psychological point of view also, the Triple decreases"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"according as such an alliance limits its object to the defence of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"STATUS QUO. But, on the other hand, an alliance will increase its"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"cohesive strength the more the parties concerned in it may hope to use"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"it as a means of reaching some practical goal of expansion. Here, as"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"everywhere else, strength does not lie in defence but in attack."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"This truth was recognized in various quarters but, unfortunately, not by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the so-called elected representatives of the people. As early as 1912"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Ludendorff, who was then Colonel and an Officer of the General Staff,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"pointed out these weak features of the Alliance in a memorandum which he"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"then drew up. But of course the 'statesmen' did not attach any"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"importance or value to that document. In general it would seem as if"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"reason were a faculty that is active only in the case of ordinary"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"mortals but that it is entirely absent when we come to deal with that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"branch of the species known as 'diplomats'."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It was lucky for Germany that the war of 1914 broke out with Austria as"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"its direct cause, for thus the Habsburgs were compelled to participate."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Had the origin of the War been otherwise, Germany would have been left"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to her own resources. The Habsburg State would never have been ready or"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"willing to take part in a war for the origin of which Germany was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"responsible. What was the object of so much obloquy later in the case of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Italy's decision would have taken place, only earlier, in the case of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Austria. In other words, if Germany had been forced to go to war for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"some reason of its own, Austria would have remained 'neutral' in order"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to safeguard the State against a revolution which might begin"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"immediately after the war had started. The Slav element would have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"preferred to smash up the Dual Monarchy in 1914 rather than permit it to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"come to the assistance of Germany. But at that time there were only a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"few who understood all the dangers and aggravations which resulted from"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the alliance with the Danubian Monarchy."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the first place, Austria had too many enemies who were eagerly"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"looking forward to obtain the heritage of that decrepit State, so that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"these people gradually developed a certain animosity against Germany,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"because Germany was an obstacle to their desires inasmuch as it kept the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Dual Monarchy from falling to pieces, a consummation that was hoped for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and yearned for on all sides. The conviction developed that Vienna could"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"be reached only by passing through Berlin."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the second place, by adopting this policy Germany lost its best and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"most promising chances of other alliances. In place of these"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"possibilities one now observed a growing tension in the relations with"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Russia and even with Italy. And this in spite of the fact that the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"general attitude in Rome was just as favourable to Germany as it was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"hostile to Austria, a hostility which lay dormant in the individual"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Italian and broke out violently on occasion."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Since a commercial and industrial policy had been adopted, no motive was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"left for waging war against Russia. Only the enemies of the two"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"countries, Germany and Russia, could have an active interest in such a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"war under these circumstances. As a matter of fact, it was only the Jews"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and the Marxists who tried to stir up bad blood between the two States."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the third place, the Alliance constituted a permanent danger to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"German security; for any great Power that was hostile to Bismarck's"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Empire could mobilize a whole lot of other States in a war against"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Germany by promising them tempting spoils at the expense of the Austrian"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ally."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It was possible to arouse the whole of Eastern Europe against Austria,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"especially Russia, and Italy also. The world coalition which had"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"developed under the leadership of King Edward could never have become a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"reality if Germany's ally, Austria, had not offered such an alluring"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"prospect of booty. It was this fact alone which made it possible to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"combine so many heterogeneous States with divergent interests into one"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"common phalanx of attack. Every member could hope to enrich himself at"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the expense of Austria if he joined in the general attack against"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Germany. The fact that Turkey was also a tacit party to the unfortunate"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"alliance with Austria augmented Germany's peril to an extraordinary"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"degree."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Jewish international finance needed this bait of the Austrian heritage"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in order to carry out its plans of ruining Germany; for Germany had not"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"yet surrendered to the general control which the international captains"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of finance and trade exercised over the other States. Thus it was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"possible to consolidate that coalition and make it strong enough and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"brave enough, through the sheer weight of numbers, to join in bodily"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conflict with the 'horned' Siegfried. (Note 9)"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"[Note 9. Carlyle explains the epithet thus: First then, let no one from
the title GEHOERNTE (Horned, Behorned), fancy that our brave Siegfried,
who was the loveliest as well as the bravest of men, was actually
cornuted, and had hornson his brow, though like Michael Angelo's Moses; or
even that his skin, to which the epithet BEHORNED refers, was hard like a
crocodile's, and not softer than the softest shamey, for the truth is,
his Hornedness means only an Invulnerability, like that of Achilles...]"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The alliance with the Habsburg Monarchy, which I loathed while still in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Austria, was the subject of grave concern on my part and caused me to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"meditate on it so persistently that finally I came to the conclusions"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which I have mentioned above."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the small circles which I frequented at that time I did not conceal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"my conviction that this sinister agreement with a State doomed to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"collapse would also bring catastrophe to Germany if she did not free"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"herself from it in time. I never for a moment wavered in that firm"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conviction, even when the tempest of the World War seemed to have made"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"shipwreck of the reasoning faculty itself and had put blind enthusiasm"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in its place, even among those circles where the coolest and hardest"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"objective thinking ought to have held sway. In the trenches I voiced and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"upheld my own opinion whenever these problems came under discussion. I"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"held that to abandon the Habsburg Monarchy would involve no sacrifice if"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Germany could thereby reduce the number of her own enemies; for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"millions of Germans who had donned the steel helmet had done so not to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"fight for the maintenance of a corrupt dynasty but rather for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"salvation of the German people."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Before the War there were occasions on which it seemed that at least one"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"section of the German public had some slight misgivings about the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"political wisdom of the alliance with Austria. From time to time German"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conservative circles issued warnings against being over-confident about"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the worth of that alliance; but, like every other reasonable suggestion"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"made at that time, it was thrown to the winds. The general conviction"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"was that the right measures had been adopted to 'conquer' the world,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that the success of these measures would be enormous and the sacrifices"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"negligible."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Once again the 'uninitiated' layman could do nothing but observe how the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"'elect' were marching straight ahead towards disaster and enticing their"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"beloved people to follow them, as the rats followed the Pied Piper of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Hamelin."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"If we would look for the deeper grounds which made it possible to foist"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"on the people this absurd notion of peacefully conquering the world"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"through commercial penetration, and how it was possible to put forward"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the maintenance of world-peace as a national aim, we shall find that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"these grounds lay in a general morbid condition that had pervaded the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"whole body of German political thought."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The triumphant progress of technical science in Germany and the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"marvellous development of German industries and commerce led us to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"forget that a powerful State had been the necessary pre-requisite of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that success. On the contrary, certain circles went even so far as to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"give vent to the theory that the State owed its very existence to these"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"phenomena; that it was, above all, an economic institution and should be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"constituted in accordance with economic interests. Therefore, it was"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"held, the State was dependent on the economic structure. This condition"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of things was looked upon and glorified as the soundest and most normal"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"arrangement."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Now, the truth is that the State in itself has nothing whatsoever to do"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"with any definite economic concept or a definite economic development."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It does not arise from a compact made between contracting parties,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"within a certain delimited territory, for the purpose of serving"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economic ends. The State is a community of living beings who have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"kindred physical and spiritual natures, organized for the purpose of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"assuring the conservation of their own kind and to help towards"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"fulfilling those ends which Providence has assigned to that particular"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"race or racial branch. Therein, and therein alone, lie the purpose and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"meaning of a State. Economic activity is one of the many auxiliary means"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which are necessary for the attainment of those aims. But economic"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"activity is never the origin or purpose of a State, except where a State"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"has been originally founded on a false and unnatural basis. And this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"alone explains why a State as such does not necessarily need a certain"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"delimited territory as a condition of its establishment. This condition"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"becomes a necessary pre-requisite only among those people who would"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"provide and assure subsistence for their kinsfolk through their own"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"industry, which means that they are ready to carry on the struggle for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"existence by means of their own work. People who can sneak their way,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"like parasites, into the human body politic and make others work for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"them under various pretences can form a State without possessing any"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"definite delimited territory. This is chiefly applicable to that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"parasitic nation which, particularly at the present time preys upon the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"honest portion of mankind; I mean the Jews."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The Jewish State has never been delimited in space. It has been spread"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"all over the world, without any frontiers whatsoever, and has always"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"been constituted from the membership of one race exclusively. That is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"why the Jews have always formed a State within the State. One of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"most ingenious tricks ever devised has been that of sailing the Jewish"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ship-of-state under the flag of Religion and thus securing that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"tolerance which Aryans are always ready to grant to different religious"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"faiths. But the Mosaic Law is really nothing else than the doctrine of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the preservation of the Jewish race. Therefore this Law takes in all"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"spheres of sociological, political and economic science which have a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"bearing on the main end in view."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The instinct for the preservation of one's own species is the primary"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"cause that leads to the formation of human communities. Hence the State"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"is a racial organism, and not an economic organization. The difference"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"between the two is so great as to be incomprehensible to our"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"contemporary so-called 'statesmen'. That is why they like to believe"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that the State may be constituted as an economic structure, whereas the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"truth is that it has always resulted from the exercise of those"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"qualities which are part of the will to preserve the species and the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"race. But these qualities always exist and operate through the heroic"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"virtues and have nothing to do with commercial egoism; for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"conservation of the species always presupposes that the individual is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"ready to sacrifice himself. Such is the meaning of the poet's lines:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"UND SETZET IHR NICHT DAS LEBEN EIN,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"NIE WIRD EUCH DAS LEBEN GEWONNEN SEIN."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"(AND IF YOU DO NOT STAKE YOUR LIFE,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"YOU WILL NEVER WIN LIFE FOR YOURSELF.)"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"[Note 10. Lines quoted from the Song of the Curassiers in Schiller's"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"WALLENSTEIN.]"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The sacrifice of the individual existence is necessary in order to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"assure the conservation of the race. Hence it is that the most essential"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"condition for the establishment and maintenance of a State is a certain"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"feeling of solidarity, wounded in an identity of character and race and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in a resolute readiness to defend these at all costs. With people who"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"live on their own territory this will result in a development of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"heroic virtues; with a parasitic people it will develop the arts of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"subterfuge and gross perfidy unless we admit that these characteristics"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"are innate and that the varying political forms through which the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"parasitic race expresses itself are only the outward manifestations of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"innate characteristics. At least in the beginning, the formation of a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"State can result only from a manifestation of the heroic qualities I"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"have spoken of. And the people who fail in the struggle for existence,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that is to say those, who become vassals and are thereby condemned to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"disappear entirely sooner or later, are those who do not display the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"heroic virtues in the struggle, or those who fall victims to the perfidy"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of the parasites. And even in this latter case the failure is not so"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"much due to lack of intellectual powers, but rather to a lack of courage"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and determination. An attempt is made to conceal the real nature of this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"failing by saying that it is the humane feeling."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The qualities which are employed for the foundation and preservation of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"a State have accordingly little or nothing to do with the economic"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"situation. And this is conspicuously demonstrated by the fact that the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"inner strength of a State only very rarely coincides with what is called"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"its economic expansion. On the contrary, there are numerous examples to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"show that a period of economic prosperity indicates the approaching"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"decline of a State. If it were correct to attribute the foundation of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"human communities to economic forces, then the power of the State as"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"such would be at its highest pitch during periods of economic"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"prosperity, and not vice versa."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"It is specially difficult to understand how the belief that the State is"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"brought into being and preserved by economic forces could gain currency"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in a country which has given proof of the opposite in every phase of its"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"history. The history of Prussia shows in a manner particularly clear and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"distinct, that it is out of the moral virtues of the people and not from"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"their economic circumstances that a State is formed. It is only under"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the protection of those virtues that economic activities can be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"developed and the latter will continue to flourish until a time comes"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"when the creative political capacity declines. Therewith the economic"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"structure will also break down, a phenomenon which is now happening in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"an alarming manner before our eyes. The material interest of mankind can"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"prosper only in the shade of the heroic virtues. The moment they become"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the primary considerations of life they wreck the basis of their own"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"existence."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Whenever the political power of Germany was specially strong the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economic situation also improved. But whenever economic interests alone"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"occupied the foremost place in the life of the people, and thrust"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"transcendent ideals into the back.-ground, the State collapsed and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economic ruin followed readily."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"If we consider the question of what those forces actually are which are"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"necessary to the creation and preservation of a State, we shall find"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that they are: The capacity and readiness to sacrifice the individual to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the common welfare. That these qualities have nothing at all to do with"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economics can be proved by referring to the simple fact that man does"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"not sacrifice himself for material interests. In other words, he will"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"die for an ideal but not for a business. The marvellous gift for public"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"psychology which the English have was never shown better than the way in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which they presented their case in the World War. We were fighting for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"our bread; but the English declared that they were fighting for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"'freedom', and not at all for their own freedom. Oh, no, but for the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"freedom of the small nations. German people laughed at that effrontery"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"and were angered by it; but in doing so they showed how political"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"thought had declined among our so-called diplomats in Germany even"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"before the War. These diplomatists did not have the slightest notion of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"what that force was which brought men to face death of their own free"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"will and determination."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"As long as the German people, in the War of 1914, continued to believe"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that they were fighting for ideals they stood firm. As soon as they were"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"told that they were fighting only for their daily bread they began to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"give up the struggle."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Our clever 'statesmen' were greatly amazed at this change of feeling."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"They never understood that as soon as man is called upon to struggle for"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"purely material causes he will avoid death as best he can; for death and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the enjoyment of the material fruits of a victory are quite incompatible"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"concepts. The frailest woman will become a heroine when the life of her"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"own child is at stake. And only the will to save the race and native"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"land or the State, which offers protection to the race, has in all ages"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"been the urge which has forced men to face the weapons of their enemies."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The following may be proclaimed as a truth that always holds good:"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"A State has never arisen from commercial causes for the purpose of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"peacefully serving commercial ends; but States have always arisen from"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the instinct to maintain the racial group, whether this instinct"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"manifest itself in the heroic sphere or in the sphere of cunning and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"chicanery. In the first case we have the Aryan States, based on the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"principles of work and cultural development. In the second case we have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the Jewish parasitic colonies. But as soon as economic interests begin"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"to predominate over the racial and cultural instincts in a people or a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"State, these economic interests unloose the causes that lead to"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"subjugation and oppression."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"The belief, which prevailed in Germany before the War, that the world"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"could be opened up and even conquered for Germany through a system of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"peaceful commercial penetration and a colonial policy was a typical"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"symptom which indicated the decline of those real qualities whereby"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"States are created and preserved, and indicated also the decline of that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"insight, will-power and practical determination which belong to those"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"qualities. The World War with its consequences, was the natural"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"liquidation of that decline."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"To anyone who had not thought over the matter deeply, this attitude of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the German people--which was quite general--must have seemed an"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"insoluble enigma. After all, Germany herself was a magnificent example"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of an empire that had been built up purely by a policy of power."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Prussia, which was the generative cell of the German Empire, had been"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"created by brilliant heroic deeds and not by a financial or commercial"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"compact. And the Empire itself was but the magnificent recompense for a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"leadership that had been conducted on a policy of power and military"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"valour."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"How then did it happen that the political instincts of this very same"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"German people became so degenerate? For it was not merely one isolated"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"phenomenon which pointed to this decadence, but morbid symptoms which"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"appeared in alarming numbers, now all over the body politic, or eating"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"into the body of the nation like a gangrenous ulcer. It seemed as if"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"some all-pervading poisonous fluid had been injected by some mysterious"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"hand into the bloodstream of this once heroic body, bringing about a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"creeping paralysis that affected the reason and the elementary instinct"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of self-preservation."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"During the years 1912-1914 I used to ponder perpetually on those"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"problems which related to the policy of the Triple Alliance and the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"economic policy then being pursued by the German Empire. Once again I"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"came to the conclusion that the only explanation of this enigma lay in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"the operation of that force which I had already become acquainted with"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in Vienna, though from a different angle of vision. The force to which I"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"refer was the Marxist teaching and WELTANSCHAUUNG and its organized"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"action throughout the nation."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For the second time in my life I plunged deep into the study of that"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"destructive teaching. This time, however, I was not urged by the study"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"of the question by the impressions and influences of my daily"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"environment, but directed rather by the observation of general phenomena"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"in the political life of Germany. In delving again into the theoretical"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"literature of this new world and endeavouring to get a clear view of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"possible consequences of its teaching, I compared the theoretical"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"principles of Marxism with the phenomena and happenings brought about by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"its activities in the political, cultural, and economic spheres."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"For the first time in my life I now turned my attention to the efforts"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that were being made to subdue this universal pest."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"I studied Bismarck's exceptional legislation in its original concept,"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"its operation and its results. Gradually I formed a basis for my own"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"opinions, which has proved as solid as a rock, so that never since have"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"I had to change my attitude towards the general problem. I also made a"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"further and more thorough analysis of the relations between Marxism and"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Jewry."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"During my sojourn in Vienna I used to look upon Germany as an"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"imperturbable colossus; but even then serious doubts and misgivings"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"would often disturb me. In my own mind and in my conversation with my"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"small circle of acquaintances I used to criticize Germany's foreign"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"policy and the incredibly superficial way, according to my thinking, in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"which Marxism was dealt with, though it was then the most important"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"problem in Germany. I could not understand how they could stumble"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"blindfolded into the midst of this peril, the effects of which would be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"momentous if the openly declared aims of Marxism could be put into"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"practice. Even as early as that time I warned people around me, just as"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"I am warning a wider audience now, against that soothing slogan of all"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"indolent and feckless nature: NOTHING CAN HAPPEN TO US. A similar mental"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"contagion had already destroyed a mighty empire. Can Germany escape the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"operation of those laws to which all other human communities are"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"subject?"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"In the years 1913 and 1914 I expressed my opinion for the first time in"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"various circles, some of which are now members of the National Socialist"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Movement, that the problem of how the future of the German nation can be"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"secured is the problem of how Marxism can be exterminated."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"I considered the disastrous policy of the Triple Alliance as one of the"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"consequences resulting from the disintegrating effects of the Marxist"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"teaching; for the alarming feature was that this teaching was invisibly"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"corrupting the foundations of a healthy political and economic outlook."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Those who had been themselves contaminated frequently did not realise"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"that their aims and actions sprang from this WELTANSCHAUUNG, which they"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"otherwise openly repudiated."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"Long before then the spiritual and moral decline of the German people"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"had set in, though those who were affected by the morbid decadence were"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"frequently unaware--as often happens--of the forces which were breaking"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"up their very existence. Sometimes they tried to cure the disease by"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"doctoring the symptoms, which were taken as the cause. But since nobody"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"recognized, or wanted to recognize, the real cause of the disease this"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"way of combating Marxism was no more effective than the application of"	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"some quack's ointment."	"CHAPTER IV   MUNICH"
"CHAPTER V"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"THE WORLD WAR"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"During the boisterous years of my youth nothing used to damp my wild"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"spirits so much as to think that I was born at a time when the world had"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"manifestly decided not to erect any more temples of fame except in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"honour of business people and State officials. The tempest of historical"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"achievements seemed to have permanently subsided, so much so that the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"future appeared to be irrevocably delivered over to what was called"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"peaceful competition between the nations. This simply meant a system of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"mutual exploitation by fraudulent means, the principle of resorting to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the use of force in self-defence being formally excluded. Individual"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"countries increasingly assumed the appearance of commercial"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"undertakings, grabbing territory and clients and concessions from each"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"other under any and every kind of pretext. And it was all staged to an"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"accompaniment of loud but innocuous shouting. This trend of affairs"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"seemed destined to develop steadily and permanently. Having the support"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of public approbation, it seemed bound eventually to transform the world"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"into a mammoth department store. In the vestibule of this emporium there"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"would be rows of monumental busts which would confer immortality on"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"those profiteers who had proved themselves the shrewdest at their trade"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"and those administrative officials who had shown themselves the most"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"innocuous. The salesmen could be represented by the English and the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"administrative functionaries by the Germans; whereas the Jews would be"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"sacrificed to the unprofitable calling of proprietorship, for they are"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"constantly avowing that they make no profits and are always being called"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"upon to 'pay out'. Moreover they have the advantage of being versed in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the foreign languages."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Why could I not have been born a hundred years ago? I used to ask"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"myself. Somewhere about the time of the Wars of Liberation, when a man"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"was still of some value even though he had no 'business'."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Thus I used to think it an ill-deserved stroke of bad luck that I had"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"arrived too late on this terrestrial globe, and I felt chagrined at the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"idea that my life would have to run its course along peaceful and"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"orderly lines. As a boy I was anything but a pacifist and all attempts"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"to make me so turned out futile."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Then the Boer War came, like a glow of lightning on the far horizon. Day"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"after day I used to gaze intently at the newspapers and I almost"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"'devoured' the telegrams and COMMUNIQUES, overjoyed to think that I"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"could witness that heroic struggle, even though from so great a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"distance."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"When the Russo-Japanese War came I was older and better able to judge"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"for myself. For national reasons I then took the side of the Japanese in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"our discussions. I looked upon the defeat of the Russians as a blow to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Austrian Slavism."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Many years had passed between that time and my arrival in Munich. I now"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"realized that what I formerly believed to be a morbid decadence was only"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the lull before the storm. During my Vienna days the Balkans were"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"already in the grip of that sultry pause which presages the violent"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"storm. Here and there a flash of lightning could be occasionally seen;"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"but it rapidly disappeared in sinister gloom. Then the Balkan War broke"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"out; and therewith the first gusts of the forthcoming tornado swept"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"across a highly-strung Europe. In the supervening calm men felt the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"atmosphere oppressive and foreboding, so much so that the sense of an"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"impending catastrophe became transformed into a feeling of impatient"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"expectance. They wished that Heaven would give free rein to the fate"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"which could now no longer be curbed. Then the first great bolt of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"lightning struck the earth. The storm broke and the thunder of the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"heavens intermingled with the roar of the cannons in the World War."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"When the news came to Munich that the Archduke Franz Ferdinand had been"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"murdered, I had been at home all day and did not get the particulars of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"how it happened. At first I feared that the shots may have been fired by"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"some German-Austrian students who had been aroused to a state of furious"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"indignation by the persistent pro-Slav activities of the Heir to the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Habsburg Throne and therefore wished to liberate the German population"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"from this internal enemy. It was quite easy to imagine what the result"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of such a mistake would have been. It would have brought on a new wave"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of persecution, the motives of which would have been 'justified' before"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the whole world. But soon afterwards I heard the names of the presumed"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"assassins and also that they were known to be Serbs. I felt somewhat"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"dumbfounded in face of the inexorable vengeance which Destiny had"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"wrought. The greatest friend of the Slavs had fallen a victim to the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"bullets of Slav patriots."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"It is unjust to the Vienna government of that time to blame it now for"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the form and tenor of the ultimatum which was then presented. In a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"similar position and under similar circumstances, no other Power in the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"world would have acted otherwise. On her southern frontiers Austria had"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"a relentless mortal foe who indulged in acts of provocation against the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Dual Monarchy at intervals which were becoming more and more frequent."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"This persistent line of conduct would not have been relaxed until the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"arrival of the opportune moment for the destruction of the Empire. In"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Austria there was good reason to fear that, at the latest, this moment"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"would come with the death of the old Emperor. Once that had taken place,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"it was quite possible that the Monarchy would not be able to offer any"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"identified with the personality of Francis Joseph that, in the eyes of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the great mass of the people, the death of this venerable"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"Empire itself. Indeed it was one of the clever artifices of Slav policy"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"to foster the impression that the Austrian State owed its very existence"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"of flattery was particularly welcomed at the Hofburg, all the more"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"prepared sting which lay hidden in this glorifying praise. One fact"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"which was entirely overlooked, perhaps intentionally, was that the more"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the Empire remained dependent on the so-called administrative talents of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"'the wisest Monarch of all times', the more catastrophic would be the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"situation when Fate came to knock at the door and demand its tribute."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Was it possible even to imagine the Austrian Empire without its"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"venerable ruler? Would not the tragedy which befell Maria Theresa be"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"repeated at once?"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"It is really unjust to the Vienna governmental circles to reproach them"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"with having instigated a war which might have been prevented. The war"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"was bound to come. Perhaps it might have been postponed for a year or"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"two at the most. But it had always been the misfortune of German, as"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"well as Austrian, diplomats that they endeavoured to put off the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"No. Those who did not wish this war ought to have had the courage to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"would have come, not as a war in which all the nations would have been"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"banded against us but in the form of a dismemberment of the Habsburg"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Monarchy. In that case we should have had to decide whether we should"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"come to the assistance of the Habsburg or stand aside as spectators,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"with our arms folded, and thus allow Fate to run its course."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Just those who are loudest in their imprecations to-day and make a great"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"parade of wisdom in judging the causes of the war are the very same"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"people whose collaboration was the most fatal factor in steering towards"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"For several decades previously the German Social-Democrats had been"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"agitating in an underhand and knavish way for war against Russia;"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"whereas the German Centre Party, with religious ends in view, had worked"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"to make the Austrian State the chief centre and turning-point of German"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"policy. The consequences of this folly had now to be borne. What came"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"was bound to come and under no circumstances could it have been avoided."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"The fault of the German Government lay in the fact that, merely for the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"sake of preserving peace at all costs, it continued to miss the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"occasions that were favourable for action, got entangled in an alliance"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"for the purpose of preserving the peace of the world, and thus finally"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"became the victim of a world coalition which opposed the German effort"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"for the maintenance of peace and was determined to bring about the world"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"war."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Had the Vienna Government of that time formulated its ultimatum in less"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"drastic terms, that would not have altered the situation at all: but"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"such a course might have aroused public indignation. For, in the eyes of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the great masses, the ultimatum was too moderate and certainly not"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"excessive or brutal. Those who would deny this to-day are either"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
