"The War of 1914 was certainly not forced on the masses; it was even"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"desired by the whole people."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"There was a desire to bring the general feeling of uncertainty to an end"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"once and for all. And it is only in the light of this fact that we can"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"understand how more than two million German men and youths voluntarily"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"joined the colours, ready to shed the last drop of their blood for the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"cause."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"For me these hours came as a deliverance from the distress that had"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"Whatever mankind desires, that it will hope for and believe in. The"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"could have been so disastrous?"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"But what should have been done then? Throw the ringleaders into gaol,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"prosecute them and rid the nation of them? Uncompromising military"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"measures should have been adopted to root out the evil. Parties should"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"have been abolished and the Reichstag brought to its senses at the point"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of the bayonet, if necessary. It would have been still better if the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Reichstag had been dissolved immediately. Just as the Republic to-day"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"dissolves the parties when it wants to, so in those days there was even"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"more justification for applying that measure, seeing that the very"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"existence of the nation was at stake. Of course this suggestion would"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"give rise to the question: Is it possible to eradicate ideas by force of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"arms? Could a WELTANSCHAUUNG be attacked by means of physical force?"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"At that time I turned these questions over and over again in my mind. By"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"studying analogous cases, exemplified in history, particularly those"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"which had arisen from religious circumstances, I came to the following"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"fundamental conclusion:"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Ideas and philosophical systems as well as movements grounded on a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"definite spiritual foundation, whether true or not, can never be broken"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"by the use of force after a certain stage, except on one condition:"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"namely, that this use of force is in the service of a new idea or"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"WELTANSCHAUUNG which burns with a new flame."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"The application of force alone, without moral support based on a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"spiritual concept, can never bring about the destruction of an idea or"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"arrest the propagation of it, unless one is ready and able ruthlessly to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"exterminate the last upholders of that idea even to a man, and also wipe"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"out any tradition which it may tend to leave behind. Now in the majority"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of cases the result of such a course has been to exclude such a State,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"either temporarily or for ever, from the comity of States that are of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"political significance; but experience has also shown that such a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"sanguinary method of extirpation arouses the better section of the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"population under the persecuting power. As a matter of fact, every"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"persecution which has no spiritual motives to support it is morally"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"unjust and raises opposition among the best elements of the population;"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"so much so that these are driven more and more to champion the ideas"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"that are unjustly persecuted. With many individuals this arises from the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"sheer spirit of opposition to every attempt at suppressing spiritual"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"things by brute force."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"In this way the number of convinced adherents of the persecuted doctrine"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"increases as the persecution progresses. Hence the total destruction of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"a new doctrine can be accomplished only by a vast plan of extermination;"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"but this, in the final analysis, means the loss of some of the best"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"blood in a nation or State. And that blood is then avenged, because such"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"an internal and total clean-up brings about the collapse of the nation's"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"strength. And such a procedure is always condemned to futility from the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"very start if the attacked doctrine should happen to have spread beyond"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"a small circle."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"That is why in this case, as with all other growths, the doctrine can be"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"exterminated in its earliest stages. As time goes on its powers of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"resistance increase, until at the approach of age it gives way to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"younger elements, but under another form and from other motives."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"The fact remains that nearly all attempts to exterminate a doctrine,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"without having some spiritual basis of attack against it, and also to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"wipe out all the organizations it has created, have led in many cases to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the very opposite being achieved; and that for the following reasons:"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"When sheer force is used to combat the spread of a doctrine, then that"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"force must be employed systematically and persistently. This means that"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the chances of success in the suppression of a doctrine lie only in the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"persistent and uniform application of the methods chosen. The moment"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"hesitation is shown, and periods of tolerance alternate with the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"application of force, the doctrine against which these measures are"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"directed will not only recover strength but every successive persecution"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"will bring to its support new adherents who have been shocked by the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"oppressive methods employed. The old adherents will become more"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"embittered and their allegiance will thereby be strengthened. Therefore"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"when force is employed success is dependent on the consistent manner in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"which it is used. This persistence, however, is nothing less than the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"product of definite spiritual convictions. Every form of force that is"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"not supported by a spiritual backing will be always indecisive and"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"uncertain. Such a force lacks the stability that can be found only in a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"WELTANSCHAUUNG which has devoted champions. Such a force is the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"expression of the individual energies; therefore it is from time to time"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"dependent on the change of persons in whose hands it is employed and"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"also on their characters and capacities."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"But there is something else to be said: Every WELTANSCHAUUNG, whether"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"religious or political--and it is sometimes difficult to say where the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"one ends and the other begins--fights not so much for the negative"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"destruction of the opposing world of ideas as for the positive"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"realization of its own ideas. Thus its struggle lies in attack rather"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"than in defence. It has the advantage of knowing where its objective"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"lies, as this objective represents the realization of its own ideas."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Inversely, it is difficult to say when the negative aim for the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"destruction of a hostile doctrine is reached and secured. For this"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"reason alone a WELTANSCHAUUNG which is of an aggressive character is"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"more definite in plan and more powerful and decisive in action than a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"WELTANSCHAUUNG which takes up a merely defensive attitude. If force be"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"used to combat a spiritual power, that force remains a defensive measure"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"only so long as the wielders of it are not the standard-bearers and"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"apostles of a new spiritual doctrine."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"To sum up, the following must be borne in mind: That every attempt to"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"combat a WELTANSCHAUUNG by means of force will turn out futile in the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"end if the struggle fails to take the form of an offensive for the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"establishment of an entirely new spiritual order of' things. It is only"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"in the struggle between two Weltan-schauungen that physical force,"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"consistently and ruthlessly applied, will eventually turn the scales in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"its own favour. It was here that the fight against Marxism had hitherto"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"failed."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"This was also the reason why Bismarck's anti-socialist legislation"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"failed and was bound to fail in the long run, despite everything. It"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"lacked the basis of a new WELTANSCHAUUNG for whose development and"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"extension the struggle might have been taken up. To say that the serving"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"up of drivel about a so-called 'State-Authority' or 'Law-and-Order' was"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"an adequate foundation for the spiritual driving force in a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"life-or-death struggle is only what one would expect to hear from the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"wiseacres in high official positions."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"It was because there were no adequate spiritual motives back of this"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"offensive that Bismarck was compelled to hand over the administration of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"his socialist legislative measures to the judgment and approval of those"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"circles which were themselves the product of the Marxist teaching. Thus"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"a very ludicrous state of affairs prevailed when the Iron Chancellor"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"surrendered the fate of his struggle against Marxism to the goodwill of"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"the bourgeois democracy. He left the goat to take care of the garden."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"But this was only the necessary result of the failure to find a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"fundamentally new WELTANSCHAUUNG which would attract devoted champions"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"to its cause and could be established on the ground from which Marxism"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"had been driven out. And thus the result of the Bismarckian campaign was"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"deplorable."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"During the World War, or at the beginning of it, were the conditions any"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"different? Unfortunately, they were not."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"The more I then pondered over the necessity for a change in the attitude"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"of the executive government towards Social-Democracy, as the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"incorporation of contemporary Marxism, the more I realized the want of a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"movement existed which promised any success in attracting vast numbers"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"politicians look on the distinction between classes as a very important"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"only impudent but also mendacious."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Generally speaking, one should guard against considering the broad"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"masses more stupid than they really are. In political matters it"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"frequently happens that feeling judges more correctly than intellect."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"exclusively from bourgeois circles. As long as millions of citizens"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"daily gulp down what the social-democratic Press tells them, it ill"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"becomes the 'Masters' to joke at the expense of the 'Comrades'; for in"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"Jew."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"One should be careful about contradicting established facts. It is an"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"undeniable fact that the class question has nothing to do with questions"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"concerning ideals, though that dope is administered at election time."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Class arrogance among a large section of our people, as well as a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"facts and not the fancies of some day-dreamer. Nevertheless it only"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"illustrates the mentality of our so-called intellectual circles, that"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"they have not yet grasped the fact that circumstances which are"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"incapable of preventing the growth of such a plague as Marxism are"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"certainly not capable of restoring what has been lost."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"The bourgeois' parties--a name coined by themselves--will never again be"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"able to win over and hold the proletarian masses in their train. That is"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"because two worlds stand opposed to one another here, in part naturally"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"and in part artificially divided. These two camps have one leading"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"thought, and that is that they must fight one another. But in such a"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"fight the younger will come off victorious; and that is Marxism."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"In 1914 a fight against Social-Democracy was indeed quite conceivable."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"But the lack of any practical substitute made it doubtful how long the"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"fight could be kept up. In this respect there was a gaping void."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"Long before the War I was of the same opinion and that was the reason"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"why I could not decide to join any of the parties then existing. During"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"

"I frequently discussed that want with my intimate comrades. And it was"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"then that I first conceived the idea of taking up political work later"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"on. As I have often assured my friends, it was just this that induced me"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"to become active on the public hustings after the War, in addition to my"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"professional work. And I am sure that this decision was arrived at after"	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"much earnest thought."	"CHAPTER VI   WAR PROPAGANDA"
"CHAPTER VI"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"WAR PROPAGANDA"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"In watching the course of political events I was always struck by the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"active part which propaganda played in them. I saw that it was an"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"instrument, which the Marxist Socialists knew how to handle in a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"masterly way and how to put it to practical uses. Thus I soon came to"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"realize that the right use of propaganda was an art in itself and that"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"this art was practically unknown to our bourgeois parties. The"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Christian-Socialist Party alone, especially in Lueger's time, showed a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"certain efficiency in the employment of this instrument and owed much of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"their success to it."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"It was during the War, however, that we had the best chance of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"estimating the tremendous results which could be obtained by a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propagandist system properly carried out. Here again, unfortunately,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"everything was left to the other side, the work done on our side being"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"worse than insignificant. It was the total failure of the whole German"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"system of information--a failure which was perfectly obvious to every"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"soldier--that urged me to consider the problem of propaganda in a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"comprehensive way. I had ample opportunity to learn a practical lesson"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"in this matter; for unfortunately it was only too well taught us by the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"enemy. The lack on our side was exploited by the enemy in such an"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"efficient manner that one could say it showed itself as a real work of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"genius. In that propaganda carried on by the enemy I found admirable"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"sources of instruction. The lesson to be learned from this had"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"unfortunately no attraction for the geniuses on our own side. They were"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"simply above all such things, too clever to accept any teaching. Anyhow"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"they did not honestly wish to learn anything."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Had we any propaganda at all? Alas, I can reply only in the negative."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"All that was undertaken in this direction was so utterly inadequate and"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"misconceived from the very beginning that not only did it prove useless"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"but at times harmful. In substance it was insufficient. Psychologically"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"it was all wrong. Anybody who had carefully investigated the German"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propaganda must have formed that judgment of it. Our people did not seem"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"to be clear even about the primary question itself: Whether propaganda"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"is a means or an end?"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Propaganda is a means and must, therefore, be judged in relation to the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"end it is intended to serve. It must be organized in such a way as to be"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"capable of attaining its objective. And, as it is quite clear that the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"importance of the objective may vary from the standpoint of general"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"necessity, the essential internal character of the propaganda must vary"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"accordingly. The cause for which we fought during the War was the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"noblest and highest that man could strive for. We were fighting for the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"freedom and independence of our country, for the security of our future"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"welfare and the honour of the nation. Despite all views to the contrary,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"this honour does actually exist, or rather it will have to exist; for a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"nation without honour will sooner or later lose its freedom and"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"independence. This is in accordance with the ruling of a higher justice,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"for a generation of poltroons is not entitled to freedom. He who would"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"be a slave cannot have honour; for such honour would soon become an"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"object of general scorn."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Germany was waging war for its very existence. The purpose of its war"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propaganda should have been to strengthen the fighting spirit in that"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"struggle and help it to victory."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"But when nations are fighting for their existence on this earth, when"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"the question of 'to be or not to be' has to be answered, then all humane"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"and aesthetic considerations must be set aside; for these ideals do not"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"exist of themselves somewhere in the air but are the product of man's"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"creative imagination and disappear when he disappears. Nature knows"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"nothing of them. Moreover, they are characteristic of only a small"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"number of nations, or rather of races, and their value depends on the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"measure in which they spring from the racial feeling of the latter."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Humane and aesthetic ideals will disappear from the inhabited earth when"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"those races disappear which are the creators and standard-bearers of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"them."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"All such ideals are only of secondary importance when a nation is"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"struggling for its existence. They must be prevented from entering into"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"the struggle the moment they threaten to weaken the stamina of the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"nation that is waging war. That is always the only visible effect"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"whereby their place in the struggle is to be judged."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"In regard to the part played by humane feeling, Moltke stated that in"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"time of war the essential thing is to get a decision as quickly as"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"possible and that the most ruthless methods of fighting are at the same"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"time the most humane. When people attempt to answer this reasoning by"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"highfalutin talk about aesthetics, etc., only one answer can be given. It"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"is that the vital questions involved in the struggle of a nation for its"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"existence must not be subordinated to any aesthetic considerations. The"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"yoke of slavery is and always will remain the most unpleasant experience"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"that mankind can endure. Do the Schwabing (Note 12) decadents look upon"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Germany's lot to-day as 'aesthetic'? Of course, one doesn't discuss such"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"a question with the Jews, because they are the modern inventors of this"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"cultural perfume. Their very existence is an incarnate denial of the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"beauty of God's image in His creation."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"[Note 12. Schwabing is the artistic quarter in Munich where artists have"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"their studios and litterateurs, especially of the Bohemian class,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"foregather.]"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Since these ideas of what is beautiful and humane have no place in"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"warfare, they are not to be used as standards of war propaganda."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"During the War, propaganda was a means to an end. And this end was the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"struggle for existence of the German nation. Propaganda, therefore,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"should have been regarded from the standpoint of its utility for that"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"

"beautiful which helped towards securing the dignity and freedom of the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"nation. Such was the only possible attitude to adopt towards war"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propaganda in the life-or-death struggle."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"If those in what are called positions of authority had realized this"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"there would have been no uncertainty about the form and employment of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"war propaganda as a weapon; for it is nothing but a weapon, and indeed a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"most terrifying weapon in the hands of those who know how to use it."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"The second question of decisive importance is this: To whom should"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propaganda be made to appeal? To the educated intellectual classes? Or"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"to the less intellectual?"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Propaganda must always address itself to the broad masses of the people."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"For the intellectual classes, or what are called the intellectual"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"classes to-day, propaganda is not suited, but only scientific"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"exposition. Propaganda has as little to do with science as an"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"advertisement poster has to do with art, as far as concerns the form in"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"which it presents its message. The art of the advertisement poster"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"consists in the ability of the designer to attract the attention of the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"crowd through the form and colours he chooses. The advertisement poster"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"announcing an exhibition of art has no other aim than to convince the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"public of the importance of the exhibition. The better it does that, the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"better is the art of the poster as such. Being meant accordingly to"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"impress upon the public the meaning of the exposition, the poster can"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"never take the place of the artistic objects displayed in the exposition"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"hall. They are something entirely different. Therefore. those who wish"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"to study the artistic display must study something that is quite"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"different from the poster; indeed for that purpose a mere wandering"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"through the exhibition galleries is of no use. The student of art must"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"carefully and thoroughly study each exhibit in order slowly to form a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"judicious opinion about it."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"The situation is the same in regard to what we understand by the word,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"propaganda. The purpose of propaganda is not the personal instruction of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"the individual, but rather to attract public attention to certain"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"things, the importance of which can be brought home to the masses only"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"by this means."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Here the art of propaganda consists in putting a matter so clearly and"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"forcibly before the minds of the people as to create a general"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"conviction regarding the reality of a certain fact, the necessity of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"certain things and the just character of something that is essential."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"But as this art is not an end in itself and because its purpose must be"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"exactly that of the advertisement poster, to attract the attention of"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"the masses and not by any means to dispense individual instructions to"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"those who already have an educated opinion on things or who wish to form"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"such an opinion on grounds of objective study--because that is not the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"purpose of propaganda, it must appeal to the feelings of the public"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"rather than to their reasoning powers."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"All propaganda must be presented in a popular form and must fix its"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"intellectual level so as not to be above the heads of the least"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"intellectual of those to whom it is directed. Thus its purely"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"intellectual level will have to be that of the lowest mental common"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"denominator among the public it is desired to reach. When there is"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"question of bringing a whole nation within the circle of its influence,"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"as happens in the case of war propaganda, then too much attention cannot"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"be paid to the necessity of avoiding a high level, which presupposes a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"relatively high degree of intelligence among the public."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"The more modest the scientific tenor of this propaganda and the more it"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"

"its success. This is the best test of the value of a propaganda, and not"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"the approbation of a small group of intellectuals or artistic people."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"The art of propaganda consists precisely in being able to awaken the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"imagination of the public through an appeal to their feelings, in"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"finding the appropriate psychological form that will arrest the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"attention and appeal to the hearts of the national masses. That this is"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"not understood by those among us whose wits are supposed to have been"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"

"mental inertia."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"Once we have understood how necessary it is to concentrate the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"persuasive forces of propaganda on the broad masses of the people, the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"following lessons result therefrom:"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"That it is a mistake to organize the direct propaganda as if it were a"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"manifold system of scientific instruction."	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"
"The receptive powers of the masses are very restricted, and their"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"

"It was, for example, a fundamental mistake to ridicule the worth of the"	"CHAPTER VII  THE REVOLUTION"

"The depth of a fall is always measured by the difference between the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"level of the original position from which a body has fallen and that in"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"

"or rather the greatest height that had been attained before the descent"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"

"The most outstanding trait in the civil service and the whole body of"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"the civil administration was its independence of the vicissitudes of"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"government, the political mentality of which could exercise no influence"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"on the attitude of the German State officials. Since the Revolution this"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"situation has been completely changed. Efficiency and capability have"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"been replaced by the test of party-adherence; and independence of"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"character and initiative are no longer appreciated as positive qualities"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"in a public official. They rather tell against him."	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"The wonderful might and power of the old Empire was based on the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"monarchical form of government, the army and the civil service. On these"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"three foundations rested that great strength which is now entirely"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"lacking; namely, the authority of the State. For the authority of the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"State cannot be based on the babbling that goes on in Parliament or in"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"the provincial diets and not upon laws made to protect the State, or"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"upon sentences passed by the law courts to frighten those who have had"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"the hardihood to deny the authority of the State, but only on the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"general confidence which the management and administration of the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"community establishes among the people. This confidence is in its turn,"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"nothing else than the result of an unshakable inner conviction that the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"government and administration of a country is inspired by disinterested"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"and honest goodwill and on the feeling that the spirit of the law is in"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"complete harmony with the moral convictions of the people. In the long"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"run, systems of government are not maintained by terrorism but on the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"belief of the people in the merits and sincerity of those who administer"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"and promote the public interests."	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"Though it be true that in the period preceding the War certain grave"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"evils tended to infect and corrode the inner strength of the nation, it"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"must be remembered that the other States suffered even more than Germany"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"from these drawbacks and yet those other States did not fail and break"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"down when the time of crisis came. If we remember further that those"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"defects in pre-War Germany were outweighed by great positive qualities"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"we shall have to look elsewhere for the effective cause of the collapse."	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"And elsewhere it lay."	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"The ultimate and most profound reason of the German downfall is to be"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"found in the fact that the racial problem was ignored and that its"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"importance in the historical development of nations was not grasped. For"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"the events that take place in the life of nations are not due to chance"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"but are the natural results of the effort to conserve and multiply the"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"species and the race, even though men may not be able consciously to"	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"picture to their minds the profound motives of their conduct."	"CHAPTER X    WHY THE SECOND REICH COLLAPSED"
"CHAPTER XI"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"RACE AND PEOPLE"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"There are certain truths which stand out so openly on the roadsides of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"life, as it were, that every passer-by may see them. Yet, because of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"their very obviousness, the general run of people disregard such truths"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"or at least they do not make them the object of any conscious knowledge."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"People are so blind to some of the simplest facts in every-day life that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"they are highly surprised when somebody calls attention to what"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"everybody ought to know. Examples of The Columbus Egg lie around us in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"hundreds of thousands; but observers like Columbus are rare."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Walking about in the garden of Nature, most men have the self-conceit to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"think that they know everything; yet almost all are blind to one of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"outstanding principles that Nature employs in her work. This principle"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"may be called the inner isolation which characterizes each and every"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"living species on this earth."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Even a superficial glance is sufficient to show that all the innumerable"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"forms in which the life-urge of Nature manifests itself are subject to a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"fundamental law--one may call it an iron law of Nature--which compels"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the various species to keep within the definite limits of their own"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"life-forms when propagating and multiplying their kind. Each animal"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"mates only with one of its own species. The titmouse cohabits only with"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the titmouse, the finch with the finch, the stork with the stork, the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"field-mouse with the field-mouse, the house-mouse with the house-mouse,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the wolf with the she-wolf, etc."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Deviations from this law take place only in exceptional circumstances."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This happens especially under the compulsion of captivity, or when some"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"other obstacle makes procreative intercourse impossible between"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"individuals of the same species. But then Nature abhors such intercourse"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"with all her might; and her protest is most clearly demonstrated by the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"fact that the hybrid is either sterile or the fecundity of its"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"descendants is limited. In most cases hybrids and their progeny are"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"denied the ordinary powers of resistance to disease or the natural means"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of defence against outer attack."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Such a dispensation of Nature is quite logical. Every crossing between"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"two breeds which are not quite equal results in a product which holds an"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"intermediate place between the levels of the two parents. This means"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"that the offspring will indeed be superior to the parent which stands in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the biologically lower order of being, but not so high as the higher"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"parent. For this reason it must eventually succumb in any struggle"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"against the higher species. Such mating contradicts the will of Nature"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"towards the selective improvements of life in general. The favourable"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"preliminary to this improvement is not to mate individuals of higher and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"lower orders of being but rather to allow the complete triumph of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"higher order. The stronger must dominate and not mate with the weaker,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"which would signify the sacrifice of its own higher nature. Only the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"born weakling can look upon this principle as cruel, and if he does so"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"it is merely because he is of a feebler nature and narrower mind; for if"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"such a law did not direct the process of evolution then the higher"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"development of organic life would not be conceivable at all."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This urge for the maintenance of the unmixed breed, which is a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"phenomenon that prevails throughout the whole of the natural world,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"results not only in the sharply defined outward distinction between one"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"species and another but also in the internal similarity of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"characteristic qualities which are peculiar to each breed or species."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The fox remains always a fox, the goose remains a goose, and the tiger"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"will retain the character of a tiger. The only difference that can exist"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"within the species must be in the various degrees of structural strength"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and active power, in the intelligence, efficiency, endurance, etc., with"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"which the individual specimens are endowed. It would be impossible to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"find a fox which has a kindly and protective disposition towards geese,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"just as no cat exists which has a friendly disposition towards mice."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"That is why the struggle between the various species does not arise from"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"a feeling of mutual antipathy but rather from hunger and love. In both"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"cases Nature looks on calmly and is even pleased with what happens. The"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"struggle for the daily livelihood leaves behind in the ruck everything"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"that is weak or diseased or wavering; while the fight of the male to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"possess the female gives to the strongest the right, or at least, the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"possibility to propagate its kind. And this struggle is a means of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"furthering the health and powers of resistance in the species. Thus it"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"is one of the causes underlying the process of development towards a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"higher quality of being."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"If the case were different the progressive process would cease, and even"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"retrogression might set in. Since the inferior always outnumber the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"superior, the former would always increase more rapidly if they"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"possessed the same capacities for survival and for the procreation of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"their kind; and the final consequence would be that the best in quality"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"would be forced to recede into the background. Therefore a corrective"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"measure in favour of the better quality must intervene. Nature supplies"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"this by establishing rigorous conditions of life to which the weaker"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"will have to submit and will thereby be numerically restricted; but even"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"that portion which survives cannot indiscriminately multiply, for here a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"new and rigorous selection takes place, according to strength and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"health."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"If Nature does not wish that weaker individuals should mate with the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"stronger, she wishes even less that a superior race should intermingle"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"with an inferior one; because in such a case all her efforts, throughout"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"hundreds of thousands of years, to establish an evolutionary higher"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"stage of being, may thus be rendered futile."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"History furnishes us with innumerable instances that prove this law. It"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"shows, with a startling clarity, that whenever Aryans have mingled their"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"blood with that of an inferior race the result has been the downfall of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the people who were the standard-bearers of a higher culture. In North"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"America, where the population is prevalently Teutonic, and where those"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"elements intermingled with the inferior race only to a very small"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"degree, we have a quality of mankind and a civilization which are"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"different from those of Central and South America. In these latter"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"countries the immigrants--who mainly belonged to the Latin races--mated"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"with the aborigines, sometimes to a very large extent indeed. In this"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"case we have a clear and decisive example of the effect produced by the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"mixture of races. But in North America the Teutonic element, which has"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"kept its racial stock pure and did not mix it with any other racial"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"stock, has come to dominate the American Continent and will remain"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"master of it as long as that element does not fall a victim to the habit"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of adulterating its blood."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"In short, the results of miscegenation are always the following:"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"(a) The level of the superior race becomes lowered;"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"(b) physical and mental degeneration sets in, thus leading slowly but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"steadily towards a progressive drying up of the vital sap."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The act which brings about such a development is a sin against the will"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of the Eternal Creator. And as a sin this act will be avenged."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Man's effort to build up something that contradicts the iron logic of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Nature brings him into conflict with those principles to which he"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"himself exclusively owes his own existence. By acting against the laws"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of Nature he prepares the way that leads to his ruin."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Here we meet the insolent objection, which is Jewish in its inspiration"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and is typical of the modern pacifist. It says: Man can control even
Nature."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"There are millions who repeat by rote that piece of Jewish babble and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"end up by imagining that somehow they themselves are the conquerors of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Nature. And yet their only weapon is just a mere idea, and a very"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"preposterous idea into the bargain; because if one accepted it, then it"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"would be impossible even to imagine the existence of the world."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The real truth is that, not only has man failed to overcome Nature in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"any sphere whatsoever but that at best he has merely succeeded in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"getting hold of and lifting a tiny corner of the enormous veil which she"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"has spread over her eternal mysteries and secret. He never creates"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"anything. All he can do is to discover something. He does not master"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Nature but has only come to be the master of those living beings who"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"have not gained the knowledge he has arrived at by penetrating into some"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of Nature's laws and mysteries. Apart from all this, an idea can never"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"subject to its own sway those conditions which are necessary for the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"existence and development of mankind; for the idea itself has come only"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"from man. Without man there would be no human idea in this world. The"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"idea as such is therefore always dependent on the existence of man and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"consequently is dependent on those laws which furnish the conditions of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"his existence."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"And not only that. Certain ideas are even confined to certain people."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This holds true with regard to those ideas in particular which have not"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"their roots in objective scientific truth but in the world of feeling."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"In other words, to use a phrase which is current to-day and which well"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and clearly expresses this truth: THEY REFLECT AN INNER EXPERIENCE. All"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"such ideas, which have nothing to do with cold logic as such but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"represent mere manifestations of feeling, such as ethical and moral"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"conceptions, etc., are inextricably bound up with man's existence. It is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to the creative powers of man's imagination that such ideas owe their"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"existence."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Now, then, a necessary condition for the maintenance of such ideas is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the existence of certain races and certain types of men. For example,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"anyone who sincerely wishes that the pacifist idea should prevail in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"this world ought to do all he is capable of doing to help the Germans"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"conquer the world; for in case the reverse should happen it may easily"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"be that the last pacifist would disappear with the last German. I say"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"this because, unfortunately, only our people, and no other people in the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"world, fell a prey to this idea. Whether you like it or not, you would"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"have to make up your mind to forget wars if you would achieve the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"pacifist ideal. Nothing less than this was the plan of the American"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"world-redeemer, Woodrow Wilson. Anyhow that was what our visionaries"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"believed, and they thought that through his plans their ideals would be"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"attained."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The pacifist-humanitarian idea may indeed become an excellent one when"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the most superior type of manhood will have succeeded in subjugating the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"world to such an extent that this type is then sole master of the earth."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This idea could have an injurious effect only in the measure according"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to which its application would become difficult and finally impossible."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"So, first of all, the fight and then pacifism. If the case were"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"different it would mean that mankind has already passed the zenith of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"its development, and accordingly the end would not be the supremacy of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"some moral ideal but degeneration into barbarism and consequent chaos."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"People may laugh at this statement; but our planet has been moving"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"through the spaces of ether for millions and millions of years,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"uninhabited by men, and at some future date may easily begin to do so"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"again--if men should forget that wherever they have reached a superior"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"level of existence, it was not the result of following the ideas of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"crazy visionaries but by acknowledging and rigorously observing the iron"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"laws of Nature."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"All that we admire in the world to-day, its science, its art, its"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"technical developments and discoveries, are the products of the creative"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"activities of a few peoples, and it may be true that their first"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"However great, for example, be the influence which the soil exerts on"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"men, this influence will always vary according to the race in which it"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"produces its effect. Dearth of soil may stimulate one race to the most"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"strenuous efforts and highest achievement; while, for another race, the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"characteristics of a people are always the causes which determine the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"nature of the effect that outer circumstances have on them. What reduces"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"one race to starvation trains another race to harder work."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"All the great civilizations of the past became decadent because the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"originally creative race died out, as a result of contamination of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"blood."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The most profound cause of such a decline is to be found in the fact"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"that the people ignored the principle that all culture depends on men,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and not the reverse. In other words, in order to preserve a certain"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"culture, the type of manhood that creates such a culture must be"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"preserved. But such a preservation goes hand-in-hand with the inexorable"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"law that it is the strongest and the best who must triumph and that they"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"have the right to endure."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"He who would live must fight. He who does not wish to fight in this"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"world, where permanent struggle is the law of life, has not the right to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"exist."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Such a saying may sound hard; but, after all, that is how the matter"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"really stands. Yet far harder is the lot of him who believes that he can"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"overcome Nature and thus in reality insults her. Distress, misery, and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"disease are her rejoinders."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Whoever ignores or despises the laws of race really deprives himself of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the happiness to which he believes he can attain. For he places an"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"obstacle in the victorious path of the superior race and, by so doing,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"he interferes with a prerequisite condition of all human progress."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Loaded with the burden of humanitarian sentiment, he falls back to the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"level of those who are unable to raise themselves in the scale of being."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"It would be futile to attempt to discuss the question as to what race or"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"races were the original standard-bearers of human culture and were"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"thereby the real founders of all that we understand by the word"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"humanity. It is much simpler to deal with this question in so far as it"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"relates to the present time. Here the answer is simple and clear. Every"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"manifestation of human culture, every product of art, science and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"technical skill, which we see before our eyes to-day, is almost"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"exclusively the product of the Aryan creative power. This very fact"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"fully justifies the conclusion that it was the Aryan alone who founded a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"superior type of humanity; therefore he represents the architype of what"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"we understand by the term: MAN. He is the Prometheus of mankind, from"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"whose shining brow the divine spark of genius has at all times flashed"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"forth, always kindling anew that fire which, in the form of knowledge,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"the earth. Should he be forced to disappear, a profound darkness will"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"descend on the earth; within a few thousand years human culture will"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"vanish and the world will become a desert."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"If we divide mankind into three categories--founders of culture, bearers"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of culture, and destroyers of culture--the Aryan alone can be considered"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"as representing the first category. It was he who laid the groundwork"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and erected the walls of every great structure in human culture. Only"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the shape and colour of such structures are to be attributed to the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"has furnished the great building-stones and plans for the edifices of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"few decades the whole of Eastern Asia, for instance, appropriated a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"culture and called such a culture its own, whereas the basis of that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"culture was the Greek mind and Teutonic skill as we know it. Only the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"external form--at least to a certain degree--shows the traits of an"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"in Japan to-day are not those of the native Japanese culture, although"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"this characterizes the external features of the country, which features"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"strike the eye of European observers on account of their fundamental"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"difference from us; but the real foundations of contemporary Japanese"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"life are the enormous scientific and technical achievements of Europe"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and America, that is to say, of Aryan peoples. Only by adopting these"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"achievements as the foundations of their own progress can the various"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"nations of the Orient take a place in contemporary world progress. The"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"scientific and technical achievements of Europe and America provide the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"basis on which the struggle for daily livelihood is carried on in the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Orient. They provide the necessary arms and instruments for this"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"struggle, and only the outer forms of these instruments have become"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"gradually adapted to Japanese ways of life."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"If, from to-day onwards, the Aryan influence on Japan would cease--and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"if we suppose that Europe and America would collapse--then the present"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"progress of Japan in science and technique might still last for a short"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"duration; but within a few decades the inspiration would dry up, and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"native Japanese character would triumph, while the present civilization"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"would become fossilized and fall back into the sleep from which it was"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"aroused about seventy years ago by the impact of Aryan culture. We may"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"therefore draw the conclusion that, just as the present Japanese"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"development has been due to Aryan influence, so in the immemorial past"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"an outside influence and an outside culture brought into existence the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Japanese culture of that day. This opinion is very strongly supported by"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the fact that the ancient civilization of Japan actually became"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"fossilizied and petrified. Such a process of senility can happen only if"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"a people loses the racial cell which originally had been creative or if"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the outside influence should be withdrawn after having awakened and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"maintained the first cultural developments in that region. If it be"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"shown that a people owes the fundamental elements of its culture to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"foreign races, assimilating and elaborating such elements, and if"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"subsequently that culture becomes fossilized whenever the external"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"influence ceases, then such a race may be called the depository but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"never the creator of a culture."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"If we subject the different peoples to a strict test from this"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"standpoint we shall find that scarcely any one of them has originally"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"created a culture, but almost all have been merely the recipients of a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"culture created elsewhere."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This development may be depicted as always happening somewhat in the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"following way:"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Aryan tribes, often almost ridiculously small in number, subjugated"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"foreign peoples and, stimulated by the conditions of life which their"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"new country offered them (fertility, the nature of the climate, etc.),"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and profiting also by the abundance of manual labour furnished them by"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the inferior race, they developed intellectual and organizing faculties"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"which had hitherto been dormant in these conquering tribes. Within the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"course of a few thousand years, or even centuries, they gave life to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"cultures whose primitive traits completely corresponded to the character"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of the founders, though modified by adaptation to the peculiarities of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the soil and the characteristics of the subjugated people. But finally"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the conquering race offended against the principles which they first had"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"observed, namely, the maintenance of their racial stock unmixed, and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"they began to intermingle with the subjugated people. Thus they put an"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"end to their own separate existence; for the original sin committed in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Paradise has always been followed by the expulsion of the guilty"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"parties."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"After a thousand years or more the last visible traces of those former"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"masters may then be found in a lighter tint of the skin which the Aryan"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"blood had bequeathed to the subjugated race, and in a fossilized culture"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of which those Aryans had been the original creators. For just as the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"blood. of the conqueror, who was a conqueror not only in body but also"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"in spirit, got submerged in the blood of the subject race, so the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"substance disappeared out of which the torch of human culture and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"progress was kindled. In so far as the blood of the former ruling race"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"has left a light nuance of colour in the blood of its descendants, as a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"token and a memory, the night of cultural life is rendered less dim and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"dark by a mild light radiated from the products of those who were the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"bearers of the original fire. Their radiance shines across the barbarism"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to which the subjected race has reverted and might often lead the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"superficial observer to believe that he sees before him an image of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"present race when he is really looking into a mirror wherein only the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"past is reflected."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"It may happen that in the course of its history such a people will come"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"into contact a second time, and even oftener, with the original founders"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of their culture and may not even remember that distant association."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Instinctively the remnants of blood left from that old ruling race will"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"be drawn towards this new phenomenon and what had formerly been possible"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"only under compulsion can now be successfully achieved in a voluntary"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"way. A new cultural wave flows in and lasts until the blood of its"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"standard-bearers becomes once again adulterated by intermixture with the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"originally conquered race."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"It will be the task of those who set themselves to the study of a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"universal history of civilization to investigate history from this point"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of view instead of allowing themselves to be smothered under the mass of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"external data, as is only too often the case with our present historical"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"science."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This short sketch of the changes that take place among those races that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"are only the depositories of a culture also furnishes a picture of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"development and the activity and the disappearance of those who are the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"true founders of culture on this earth, namely the Aryans themselves."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Just as in our daily life the so-called man of genius needs a particular"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"occasion, and sometimes indeed a special stimulus, to bring his genius"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to light, so too in the life of the peoples the race that has genius in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"it needs the occasion and stimulus to bring that genius to expression."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"In the monotony and routine of everyday life even persons of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"significance seem just like the others and do not rise beyond the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"average level of their fellow-men. But as soon as such men find"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"and manifesting wonderful powers of calm reflection under such"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"thought that the soul of a hero lurked in the body of that beardless"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"youth. A special impulse is almost always necessary to bring a man of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"Though an inventor, for example, does not establish his fame until the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"very day that he carries through his invention, it would be a mistake to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"believe that the creative genius did not become alive in him until that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"moment. From the very hour of his birth the spark of genius is living"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"within the man who has been endowed with the real creative faculty. True"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"genius is an innate quality. It can never be the result of education or"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"training."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"As I have stated already, this holds good not merely of the individual"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"the urge of special circumstances, so in the life of the nations the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"The most obvious example of this truth is furnished by that race which"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"create under such circumstances are almost always conditioned by the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"soil, the climate and the people they subjugate. The last factor--that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"primitive the technical conditions under which the civilizing activity"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"takes place, the more necessary is the existence of manual labour which"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"can be organized and employed so as to take the place of mechanical"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"power. Had it not been possible for them to employ members of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"a position to take the first steps on the road which led them to a later"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"type of culture; just as, without the help of certain suitable animals"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"which they were able to tame, they would never have come to the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"invention of mechanical power which has subsequently enabled them to do"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"without these beasts. The phrase, 'The Moor has accomplished his"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"function, so let him now depart', has, unfortunately, a profound"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"application. For thousands of years the horse has been the faithful"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"servant of man and has helped him to lay the foundations of human"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"progress, but now motor power has dispensed with the use of the horse."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"In a few years to come the use of the horse will cease entirely; and yet"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"without its collaboration man could scarcely have come to the stage of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"development which he has now created."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"For the establishment of superior types of civilization the members of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"inferior races formed one of the most essential pre-requisites. They"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"alone could supply the lack of mechanical means without which no"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"progress is possible. It is certain that the first stages of human"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"civilization were not based so much on the use of tame animals as on the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"employment of human beings who were members of an inferior race."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Only after subjugated races were employed as slaves was a similar fate"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"allotted to animals, and not vice versa, as some people would have us"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"believe. At first it was the conquered enemy who had to draw the plough"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and only afterwards did the ox and horse take his place. Nobody else but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"puling pacifists can consider this fact as a sign of human degradation."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Such people fail to recognize that this evolution had to take place in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"order that man might reach that degree of civilization which these"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"apostles now exploit in an attempt to make the world pay attention to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"their rigmarole."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The progress of mankind may be compared to the process of ascending an"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"infinite ladder. One does not reach the higher level without first"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"having climbed the lower rungs. The Aryan therefore had to take that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"road which his sense of reality pointed out to him and not that which"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the modern pacifist dreams of. The path of reality is, however,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"difficult and hard to tread; yet it is the only one which finally leads"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to the goal where the others envisage mankind in their dreams. But the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"real truth is that those dreamers help only to lead man away from his"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"goal rather than towards it."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"It was not by mere chance that the first forms of civilization arose"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"there where the Aryan came into contact with inferior races, subjugated"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"them and forced them to obey his command. The members of the inferior"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"race became the first mechanical tools in the service of a growing"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"civilization."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Thereby the way was clearly indicated which the Aryan had to follow. As"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"a conqueror, he subjugated inferior races and turned their physical"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"powers into organized channels under his own leadership, forcing them to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"follow his will and purpose. By imposing on them a useful, though hard,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"manner of employing their powers he not only spared the lives of those"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"whom he had conquered but probably made their lives easier than these"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"had been in the former state of so-called 'freedom'. While he ruthlessly"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"maintained his position as their master, he not only remained master but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"he also maintained and advanced civilization. For this depended"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"exclusively on his inborn abilities and, therefore, on the preservation"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of the Aryan race as such. As soon, however, as his subject began to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"ascension was probably the use of his language, the barriers that had"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"distinguished master from servant broke down. The Aryan neglected to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"maintain his own racial stock unmixed and therewith lost the right to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"live in the paradise which he himself had created. He became submerged"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"in the racial mixture and gradually lost his cultural creativeness,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
