"the aborigines whom he had subjected rather than his own ancestors. For"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"some time he could continue to live on the capital of that culture which"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"still remained; but a condition of fossilization soon set in and he sank"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"into oblivion."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"That is how cultures and empires decline and yield their places to new"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"formations."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The adulteration of the blood and racial deterioration conditioned"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"thereby are the only causes that account for the decline of ancient"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"civilizations; for it is never by war that nations are ruined, but by"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the loss of their powers of resistance, which are exclusively a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"characteristic of pure racial blood. In this world everything that is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"not of sound racial stock is like chaff. Every historical event in the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"world is nothing more nor less than a manifestation of the instinct of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"racial self-preservation, whether for weal or woe."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The question as to the ground reasons for the predominant importance of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Aryanism can be answered by pointing out that it is not so much that the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Aryans are endowed with a stronger instinct for self-preservation, but"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"rather that this manifests itself in a way which is peculiar to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"themselves. Considered from the subjective standpoint, the will-to-live"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"is of course equally strong all round and only the forms in which it is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"expressed are different. Among the most primitive organisms the instinct"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"for self-preservation does not extend beyond the care of the individual"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"ego. Egotism, as we call this passion, is so predominant that it"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"includes even the time element; which means that the present moment is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"deemed the most important and that nothing is left to the future. The"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"animal lives only for itself, searching for food only when it feels"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"hunger and fighting only for the preservation of its own life. As long"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"as the instinct for self-preservation manifests itself exclusively in"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"such a way, there is no basis for the establishment of a community; not"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"even the most primitive form of all, that is to say the family. The"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"society formed by the male with the female, where it goes beyond the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"mere conditions of mating, calls for the extension of the instinct of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"Almost always they are ready to protect and defend each other; so that"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"here we find the first, though infinitely simple, manifestation of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"spirit of sacrifice. As soon as this spirit extends beyond the narrow"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"limits of the family, we have the conditions under which larger"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"associations and finally even States can be formed."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The lowest species of human beings give evidence of this quality only to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"a very small degree, so that often they do not go beyond the formation"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"of the family society. With an increasing readiness to place their"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"immediate personal interests in the background, the capacity for"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"organizing more extensive communities develops."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The readiness to sacrifice one's personal work and, if necessary, even"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"one's life for others shows its most highly developed form in the Aryan"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"race. The greatness of the Aryan is not based on his intellectual"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"powers, but rather on his willingness to devote all his faculties to the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"service of the community. Here the instinct for self-preservation has"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"ego to the common weal and when necessity calls he will even sacrifice"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"his own life for the community."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The constructive powers of the Aryan and that peculiar ability he has"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"for the building up of a culture are not grounded in his intellectual"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"gifts alone. If that were so they might only be destructive and could"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"never have the ability to organize; for the latter essentially depends"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"on the readiness of the individual to renounce his own personal opinions"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and interests and to lay both at the service of the human group. By"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"serving the common weal he receives his reward in return. For example,"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"he does not work directly for himself but makes his productive work a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"part of the activity of the group to which he belongs, not only for his"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"own benefit but for the general. The spirit underlying this attitude is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"expressed by the word: WORK, which to him does not at all signify a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"means of earning one's daily livelihood but rather a productive activity"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"which cannot clash with the interests of the community. Whenever human"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"activity is directed exclusively to the service of the instinct for"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"self-preservation it is called theft or usury, robbery or burglary, etc."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"This mental attitude, which forces self-interest to recede into the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"background in favour of the common weal, is the first prerequisite for"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"any kind of really human civilization. It is out of this spirit alone"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"that great human achievements have sprung for which the original doers"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"alone which can explain why it so often happens that people can endure a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"harsh but honest existence which offers them no returns for their toil"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"except a poor and modest livelihood. But such a livelihood helps to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"consolidate the foundations on which the community exists. Every worker"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and every peasant, every inventor, state official, etc., who works"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"without ever achieving fortune or prosperity for himself, is a"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"representative of this sublime idea, even though he may never become"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"conscious of the profound meaning of his own activity."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"Everything that may be said of that kind of work which is the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"fundamental condition of providing food and the basic means of human"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"progress is true even in a higher sense of work that is done for the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"protection of man and his civilization. The renunciation of one's own"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"life for the sake of the community is the crowning significance of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"idea of all sacrifice. In this way only is it possible to protect what"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"Since the Jew has never had a State which was based on territorial"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"delimitations, and therefore never a civilization of his own, the idea"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"arose that here we were dealing with a people who had to be considered"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"have to wage for the bare means of existence, a struggle which has been"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"occasioned by the greediness and narrow-mindedness of many of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"industrialists. Unless the workers be ready to surrender all claims to"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"an existence which the dignity of human nature itself demands, and"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"unless they are ready to submit their fate to the will of employers who"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"in many cases have no sense of human responsibilities and are utterly"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"callous to human wants, then the worker must necessarily take matters"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"into his own hands, seeing that the organized social community--that is"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"to say, the State--pays no attention to his needs."	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"The so-called national-minded bourgeoisie, blinded by its own material"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"interests, opposes this life-or-death struggle of the workers and places"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the most difficult obstacles in their way. Not only does this"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"bourgeoisie hinder all efforts to enact legislation which would shorten"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"the inhumanly long hours of work, prohibit child-labour, grant security"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"and protection to women and improve the hygienic conditions of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"bourgeoisie hinders all this the shrewd Jew takes the cause of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"
"oppressed into his own hands. He gradually becomes the leader of the"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"while a sound social policy has to move between the two poles of"	"CHAPTER XI   RACE AND PEOPLE"

"CHAPTER XIV"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"THE STATE"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Already in 1920-1921 certain circles belonging to the effete bourgeois"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"class accused our movement again and again of taking up a negative"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attitude towards the modern State. For that reason the motley gang of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"camp followers attached to the various political parties, representing a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"heterogeneous conglomeration of political views, assumed the right of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"utilizing all available means to suppress the protagonists of this young"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"movement which was preaching a new political gospel. Our opponents"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"deliberately ignored the fact that the bourgeois class itself stood for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"no uniform opinion as to what the State really meant and that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"bourgeoisie did not and could not give any coherent definition of this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institution. Those whose duty it is to explain what is meant when we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"speak of the State, hold chairs in State universities, often in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"department of constitutional law, and consider it their highest duty to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"find explanations and justifications for the more or less fortunate"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"existence of that particular form of State which provides them with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their daily bread. The more absurd such a form of State is the more"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"obscure and artificial and incomprehensible are the definitions which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"are advanced to explain the purpose of its existence. What, for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instance, could a royal and imperial university professor write about"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the meaning and purpose of a State in a country whose statal form"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"represented the greatest monstrosity of the twentieth century? That"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would be a difficult undertaking indeed, in view of the fact that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"contemporary professor of constitutional law is obliged not so much to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"serve the cause of truth but rather to serve a certain definite purpose."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"And this purpose is to defend at all costs the existence of that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"monstrous human mechanism which we now call the State. Nobody can be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"surprised if concrete facts are evaded as far as possible when the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"problem of the State is under discussion and if professors adopt the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"tactics of concealing themselves in morass of abstract values and duties"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and purposes which are described as 'ethical' and 'moral'."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Generally speaking, these various theorists may be classed in three"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"groups:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"1. Those who hold that the State is a more or less voluntary association"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of men who have agreed to set up and obey a ruling authority."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This is numerically the largest group. In its ranks are to be found"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those who worship our present principle of legalized authority. In their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"eyes the will of the people has no part whatever in the whole affair."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For them the fact that the State exists is sufficient reason to consider"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it sacred and inviolable. To accept this aberration of the human brain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"one would have to have a sort of canine adoration for what is called the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"authority of the State. In the minds of these people the means is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"substituted for the end, by a sort of sleight-of-hand movement. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State no longer exists for the purpose of serving men but men exist for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the purpose of adoring the authority of the State, which is vested in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its functionaries, even down to the smallest official. So as to prevent"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this placid and ecstatic adoration from changing into something that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"might become in any way disturbing, the authority of the State is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"limited simply to the task of preserving order and tranquillity."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therewith it is no longer either a means or an end. The State must see"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that public peace and order are preserved and, in their turn, order and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"peace must make the existence of the State possible. All life must move"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"between these two poles. In Bavaria this view is upheld by the artful"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"politicians of the Bavarian Centre, which is called the 'Bavarian"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Populist Party'. In Austria the Black-and-Yellow legitimists adopt a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"similar attitude. In the REICH, unfortunately, the so-called"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"conservative elements follow the same line of thought."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"2. The second group is somewhat smaller in numbers. It includes those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who would make the existence of the State dependent on some conditions"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"at least. They insist that not only should there be a uniform system of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"efficiency. Its venerable age no longer protects it from being"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"3. The third group is numerically the smallest. In the State they"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"a definite direction."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"During the last century it was lamentable for those who had to witness"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"other formula that might be universally accepted, the bourgeois teaching"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"prepared the way for that doctrine which rejects the State as such."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"That is why the bourgeois struggle against Marxist internationalism is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"absolutely doomed to fail in this field. The bourgeois classes have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"already sacrificed the basic principles which alone could furnish a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"solid footing for their ideas. Their crafty opponent has perceived the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defects in their structure and advances to the assault on it with those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"weapons which they themselves have placed in his hands though not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"meaning to do so."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore any new movement which is based on the racial concept of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"world will first of all have to put forward a clear and logical doctrine"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the nature and purpose of the State."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The fundamental principle is that the State is not an end in itself but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the means to an end. It is the preliminary condition under which alone a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"higher form of human civilization can be developed, but it is not the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"source of such a development. This is to be sought exclusively in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"actual existence of a race which is endowed with the gift of cultural"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"creativeness. There may be hundreds of excellent States on this earth,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and yet if the Aryan, who is the creator and custodian of civilization,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"should disappear, all culture that is on an adequate level with the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spiritual needs of the superior nations to-day would also disappear. We"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"may go still further and say that the fact that States have been created"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"by human beings does not in the least exclude the possiblity that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"human race may become extinct, because the superior intellectual"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculties and powers of adaptation would be lost when the racial bearer"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of these faculties and powers disappeared."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"If, for instance, the surface of the globe should be shaken to-day by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"some seismic convulsion and if a new Himalaya would emerge from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"waves of the sea, this one catastrophe alone might annihilate human"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"civilization. No State could exist any longer. All order would be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"shattered. And all vestiges of cultural products which had been evolved"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"through thousands of years would disappear. Nothing would be left but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"one tremendous field of death and destruction submerged in floods of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"water and mud. If, however, just a few people would survive this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"terrible havoc, and if these people belonged to a definite race that had"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the innate powers to build up a civilization, when the commotion had"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"passed, the earth would again bear witness to the creative power of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"human spirit, even though a span of a thousand years might intervene."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Only with the extermination of the last race that possesses the gift of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cultural creativeness, and indeed only if all the individuals of that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"race had disappeared, would the earth definitely be turned into a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"desert. On the other hand, modern history furnishes examples to show"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that statal institutions which owe their beginnings to members of a race"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which lacks creative genius are not made of stuff that will endure. Just"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"as many varieties of prehistoric animals had to give way to others and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"leave no trace behind them, so man will also have to give way, if he"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"loses that definite faculty which enables him to find the weapons that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"are necessary for him to maintain his own existence."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is not the State as such that brings about a certain definite advance"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in cultural progress. The State can only protect the race that is the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cause of such progress. The State as such may well exist without"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"undergoing any change for hundreds of years, though the cultural"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculties and the general life of the people, which is shaped by these"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculties, may have suffered profound changes by reason of the fact that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the State did not prevent a process of racial mixture from taking place."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The present State, for instance, may continue to exist in a mere"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mechanical form, but the poison of miscegenation permeating the national"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"body brings about a cultural decadence which manifests itself already in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"various symptoms that are of a detrimental character."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Thus the indispensable prerequisite for the existence of a superior"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"quality of human beings is not the State but the race, which is alone"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"capable of producing that higher human quality."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This capacity is always there, though it will lie dormant unless"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"external circumstances awaken it to action. Nations, or rather races,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which are endowed with the faculty of cultural creativeness possess this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculty in a latent form during periods when the external circumstances"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"are unfavourable for the time being and therefore do not allow the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculty to express itself effectively. It is therefore outrageously"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"unjust to speak of the pre-Christian Germans as barbarians who had no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"civilization. They never have been such. But the severity of the climate"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that prevailed in the northern regions which they inhabited imposed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"conditions of life which hampered a free development of their creative"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"faculties. If they had come to the fairer climate of the South, with no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"previous culture whatsoever, and if they acquired the necessary human"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"material--that is to say, men of an inferior race--to serve them as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"working implements, the cultural faculty dormant in them would have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"splendidly blossomed forth, as happened in the case of the Greeks, for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"example. But this primordial creative faculty in cultural things was not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"solely due to their northern climate. For the Laplanders or the Eskimos"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would not have become creators of a culture if they were transplanted to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the South. No, this wonderful creative faculty is a special gift"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"bestowed on the Aryan, whether it lies dormant in him or becomes active,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"according as the adverse conditions of nature prevent the active"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"expression of that faculty or favourable circumstances permit it."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"From these facts the following conclusions may be drawn:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The State is only a means to an end. Its end and its purpose is to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"preserve and promote a community of human beings who are physically as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"well as spiritually kindred. Above all, it must preserve the existence"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the race, thereby providing the indispensable condition for the free"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"development of all the forces dormant in this race. A great part of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"these faculties will always have to be employed in the first place to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"maintain the physical existence of the race, and only a small portion"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will be free to work in the field of intellectual progress. But, as a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"matter of fact, the one is always the necessary counterpart of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Those States which do not serve this purpose have no justification for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their existence. They are monstrosities. The fact that they do exist is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"no more of a justification than the successful raids carried out by a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"band of pirates can be considered a justification of piracy."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"We National Socialists, who are fighting for a new WELTANSCHAUUNG, must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"never take our stand on the famous 'basis of facts', and especially not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"on mistaken facts. If we did so, we should cease to be the protagonists"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of a new and great idea and would become slaves in the service of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fallacy which is dominant to-day. We must make a clear-cut distinction"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"between the vessel and its contents. The State is only the vessel and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the race is what it contains. The vessel can have a meaning only if it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"preserves and safeguards the contents. Otherwise it is worthless."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Hence the supreme purpose of the ethnical State is to guard and preserve"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those racial elements which, through their work in the cultural field,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"create that beauty and dignity which are characteristic of a higher"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mankind. As Aryans, we can consider the State only as the living"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"organism of a people, an organism which does not merely maintain the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"existence of a people, but functions in such a way as to lead its people"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to a position of supreme liberty by the progressive development of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual and cultural faculties."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"What they want to impose upon us as a State to-day is in most cases"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nothing but a monstrosity, the product of a profound human aberration"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which brings untold suffering in its train."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"We National Socialists know that in holding these views we take up a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"revolutionary stand in the world of to-day and that we are branded as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"revolutionaries. But our views and our conduct will not be determined by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the approbation or disapprobation of our contemporaries, but only by our"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duty to follow a truth which we have acknowledged. In doing this we have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reason to believe that posterity will have a clearer insight, and will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not only understand the work we are doing to-day, but will also ratify"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it as the right work and will exalt it accordingly."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"On these principles we National Socialists base our standards of value"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in appraising a State. This value will be relative when viewed from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"particular standpoint of the individual nation, but it will be absolute"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when considered from the standpoint of humanity as a whole. In other"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"words, this means:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"That the excellence of a State can never be judged by the level of its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"culture or the degree of importance which the outside world attaches to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its power, but that its excellence must be judged by the degree to which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its institutions serve the racial stock which belongs to it."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A State may be considered as a model example if it adequately serves not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"only the vital needs of the racial stock it represents but if it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"actually assures by its own existence the preservation of this same"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"racial stock, no matter what general cultural significance this statal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institution may have in the eyes of the rest of the world. For it is not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the task of the State to create human capabilities, but only to assure"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"free scope for the exercise of capabilities that already exist. On the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other hand, a State may be called bad if, in spite of the existence of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"high cultural level, it dooms to destruction the bearers of that culture"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"by breaking up their racial uniformity. For the practical effect of such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a policy would be to destroy those conditions that are indispensable for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the ulterior existence of that culture, which the State did not create"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but which is the fruit of the creative power inherent in the racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stock whose existence is assured by being united in the living organism"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the State. Once again let me emphasize the fact that the State itself"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is not the substance but the form. Therefore, the cultural level is not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the standard by which we can judge the value of the State in which that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people lives. It is evident that a people which is endowed with high"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"creative powers in the cultural sphere is of more worth than a tribe of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"negroes. And yet the statal organization of the former, if judged from"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the standpoint of efficiency, may be worse than that of the negroes. Not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"even the best of States and statal institutions can evolve faculties"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"from a people which they lack and which they never possessed, but a bad"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State may gradually destroy the faculties which once existed. This it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"can do by allowing or favouring the suppression of those who are the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"bearers of a racial culture."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore, the worth of a State can be determined only by asking how far"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it actually succeeds in promoting the well-being of a definite race and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not by the role which it plays in the world at large. Its relative worth"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"can be estimated readily and accurately; but it is difficult to judge"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its absolute worth, because the latter is conditioned not only by the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State but also by the quality and cultural level of the people that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"belong to the individual State in question."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore, when we speak of the high mission of the State we must not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"forget that the high mission belongs to the people and that the business"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the State is to use its organizing powers for the purpose of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"furnishing the necessary conditions which allow this people freely to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"unfold its creative faculties. And if we ask what kind of statal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institution we Germans need, we must first have a clear notion as to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people which that State must embrace and what purpose it must serve."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Unfortunately the German national being is not based on a uniform racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"type. The process of welding the original elements together has not gone"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"so far as to warrant us in saying that a new race has emerged. On the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"contrary, the poison which has invaded the national body, especially"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"since the Thirty Years' War, has destroyed the uniform constitution not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"only of our blood but also of our national soul. The open frontiers of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"our native country, the association with non-German foreign elements in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the territories that lie all along those frontiers, and especially the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"strong influx of foreign blood into the interior of the REICH itself,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has prevented any complete assimilation of those various elements,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because the influx has continued steadily. Out of this melting-pot no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"new race arose. The heterogeneous elements continue to exist side by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"side. And the result is that, especially in times of crisis, when the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"herd usually flocks together, the Germans disperse in all directions."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The fundamental racial elements are not only different in different"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"districts, but there are also various elements in the single districts."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Beside the Nordic type we find the East-European type, beside the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Eastern there is the Dinaric, the Western type intermingling with both,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and hybrids among them all. That is a grave drawback for us. Through it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the Germans lack that strong herd instinct which arises from unity of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"blood and saves nations from ruin in dangerous and critical times;"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because on such occasions small differences disappear, so that a united"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"herd faces the enemy. What we understand by the word hyper-individualism"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"arises from the fact that our primordial racial elements have existed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"side by side without ever consolidating. During times of peace such a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"situation may offer some advantages, but, taken all in all, it has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"prevented us from gaining a mastery in the world. If in its historical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"development the German people had possessed the unity of herd instinct"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"by which other peoples have so much benefited, then the German REICH"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would probably be mistress of the globe to-day. World history would have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"taken another course and in this case no man can tell if what many"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"blinded pacifists hope to attain by petitioning, whining and crying, may"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not have been reached in this way: namely, a peace which would not be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"based upon the waving of olive branches and tearful misery-mongering of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pacifist old women, but a peace that would be guaranteed by the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"triumphant sword of a people endowed with the power to master the world"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and administer it in the service of a higher civilization."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The fact that our people did not have a national being based on a unity"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of blood has been the source of untold misery for us. To many petty"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"German potentates it gave residential capital cities, but the German"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people as a whole was deprived of its right to rulership."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Even to-day our nation still suffers from this lack of inner unity; but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"what has been the cause of our past and present misfortunes may turn out"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a blessing for us in the future. Though on the one hand it may be a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"drawback that our racial elements were not welded together, so that no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"homogeneous national body could develop, on the other hand, it was"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fortunate that, since at least a part of our best blood was thus kept"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pure, its racial quality was not debased."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A complete assimilation of all our racial elements would certainly have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"in the case of every racial mixture, it would have been less capable of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"elements. A benefit which results from the fact that there was no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"must look upon this as our most valuable treasure for the sake of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"future. During that dark period of absolute ignorance in regard to all"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"aims would not have been attained, because the only kind of people which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"But what has been prevented by a friendly Destiny, without any"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"Thus for the first time a high inner purpose is accredited to the State."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In face of the ridiculous phrase that the State should do no more than"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"unswerving persistence. Many of the officials who direct the affairs of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State nowadays may find it easier to work for the maintenance of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"present order than to fight for a new one. They will find it more"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"comfortable to look upon the State as a mechanism, whose purpose is its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"own preservation, and to say that 'their lives belong to the State,' as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"if anything that grew from the inner life of the nation can logically"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"serve anything but the national being, and as if man could be made for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"anything else than for his fellow beings. Naturally, it is easier, as I"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have said, to consider the authority of the State as nothing but the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"formal mechanism of an organization, rather than as the sovereign"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"incarnation of a people's instinct for self-preservation on this earth."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For these weak minds the State and the authority of the State is nothing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but an aim in itself, while for us it is an effective weapon in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"service of the great and eternal struggle for existence, a weapon which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"everyone must adopt, not because it is a mere formal mechanism, but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because it is the main expression of our common will to exist."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore, in the fight for our new idea, which conforms completely to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"comrades in a social order which has become decrepit not only physically"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"exceptional people will join our ranks, only those few old people whose"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"hearts have remained young and whose courage is still vigorous, but not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those who consider it their duty to maintain the state of affairs that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"exists."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Against us we have the innumerable army of all those who are lazy-minded"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and indifferent rather than evil, and those whose self-interest leads"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"them to uphold the present state of affairs. On the apparent"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"fight for one goal, thereby ultimately rising above the inert masses of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the people, this small percentage will become masters of the whole."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"World history is made by minorities if these numerical minorities"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"represent in themselves the will and energy and initiative of the people"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"as a whole."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"What seems an obstacle to many persons is really a preliminary condition"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of our victory. Just because our task is so great and because so many"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"difficulties have to be overcome, the highest probability is that only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the best kind of protagonists will join our ranks. This selection is the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"guarantee of our success. Nature generally takes certain measures to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"correct the effect which racial mixture produces in life. She is not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"much in favour of the mongrel. The later products of cross-breeding have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to suffer bitterly, especially the third, fourth and fifth generations."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Not only are they deprived of the higher qualities that belonged to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"parents who participated in the first mixture, but they also lack"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"definite will-power and vigorous vital energies owing to the lack of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"harmony in the quality of their blood. At all critical moments in which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a person of pure racial blood makes correct decisions, that is to say,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decisions that are coherent and uniform, the person of mixed blood will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"become confused and take measures that are incoherent. Hence we see that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a person of mixed blood is not only relatively inferior to a person of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pure blood, but is also doomed to become extinct more rapidly. In"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"innumerable cases wherein the pure race holds its ground the mongrel"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"breaks down. Therein we witness the corrective provision which Nature"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"adopts. She restricts the possibilities of procreation, thus impeding"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the fertility of cross-breeds and bringing them to extinction."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For instance, if an individual member of a race should mingle his blood"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with the member of a superior race the first result would be a lowering"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the racial level, and furthermore the descendants of this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cross-breeding would be weaker than those of the people around them who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"had maintained their blood unadulterated. Where no new blood from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"superior race enters the racial stream of the mongrels, and where those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mongrels continue to cross-breed among themselves, the latter will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"either die out because they have insufficient powers of resistance,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which is Nature's wise provision, or in the course of many thousands of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"years they will form a new mongrel race in which the original elements"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will become so wholly mixed through this millennial crossing that traces"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the original elements will be no longer recognizable. And thus a new"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people would be developed which possessed a certain resistance capacity"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the herd type, but its intellectual value and its cultural"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"significance would be essentially inferior to those which the first"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cross-breeds possessed. But even in this last case the mongrel product"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would succumb in the mutual struggle for existence with a higher racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"group that had maintained its blood unmixed. The herd solidarity which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this mongrel race had developed through thousands of years will not be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"equal to the struggle. And this is because it would lack elasticity and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"constructive capacity to prevail over a race of homogeneous blood that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"was mentally and culturally superior."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therewith we may lay down the following principle as valid: every racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mixture leads, of necessity, sooner or later to the downfall of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mongrel product, provided the higher racial strata of this cross-breed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has not retained within itself some sort of racial homogeneity. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"danger to the mongrels ceases only when this higher stratum, which has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"maintained certain standards of homogeneous breeding, ceases to be true"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to its pedigree and intermingles with the mongrels."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This principle is the source of a slow but constant regeneration whereby"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"all the poison which has invaded the racial body is gradually eliminated"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"so long as there still remains a fundamental stock of pure racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"elements which resists further crossbreeding."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Such a process may set in automatically among those people where a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"strong racial instinct has remained. Among such people we may count"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those elements which, for some particular cause such as coercion, have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"been thrown out of the normal way of reproduction along strict racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lines. As soon as this compulsion ceases, that part of the race which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has remained intact will tend to marry with its own kind and thus impede"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"further intermingling. Then the mongrels recede quite naturally into the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"background unless their numbers had increased so much as to be able to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"withstand all serious resistance from those elements which had preserved"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the purity of their race."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"When men have lost their natural instincts and ignore the obligations"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"imposed on them by Nature, then there is no hope that Nature will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"correct the loss that has been caused, until recognition of the lost"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instincts has been restored. Then the task of bringing back what has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"been lost will have to be accomplished. But there is serious danger that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those who have become blind once in this respect will continue more and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"more to break down racial barriers and finally lose the last remnants of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"what is best in them. What then remains is nothing but a uniform"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mish-mash, which seems to be the dream of our fine Utopians. But that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mish-mash would soon banish all ideals from the world. Certainly a great"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"herd could thus be formed. One can breed a herd of animals; but from a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mixture of this kind men such as have created and founded civilizations"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would not be produced. The mission of humanity might then be considered"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"at an end."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Those who do not wish that the earth should fall into such a condition"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must realize that it is the task of the German State in particular to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"see to it that the process of bastardization is brought to a stop."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Our contemporary generation of weaklings will naturally decry such a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"policy and whine and complain about it as an encroachment on the most"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"sacred of human rights. But there is only one right that is sacrosanct"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and this right is at the same time a most sacred duty. This right and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"obligation are: that the purity of the racial blood should be guarded,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"so that the best types of human beings may be preserved and that thus we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"should render possible a more noble development of humanity itself."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A folk-State should in the first place raise matrimony from the level of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"being a constant scandal to the race. The State should consecrate it as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an institution which is called upon to produce creatures made in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"likeness of the Lord and not create monsters that are a mixture of man"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and ape. The protest which is put forward in the name of humanity does"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not fit the mouth of a generation that makes it possible for the most"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"depraved degenerates to propagate themselves, thereby imposing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"unspeakable suffering on their own products and their contemporaries,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"while on the other hand contraceptives are permitted and sold in every"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"drug store and even by street hawkers, so that babies should not be born"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"even among the healthiest of our people. In this present State of ours,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"whose function it is to be the guardian of peace and good order, our"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"national bourgeoisie look upon it as a crime to make procreation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"impossible for syphilitics and those who suffer from tuberculosis or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other hereditary diseases, also cripples and imbeciles. But the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"practical prevention of procreation among millions of our very best"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people is not considered as an evil, nor does it offend against the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"noble morality of this social class but rather encourages their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"short-sightedness and mental lethargy. For otherwise they would at least"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stir their brains to find an answer to the question of how to create"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"conditions for the feeding and maintaining of those future beings who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will be the healthy representatives of our nation and must also provide"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the conditions on which the generation that is to follow them will have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to support itself and live."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"How devoid of ideals and how ignoble is the whole contemporary system!"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The fact that the churches join in committing this sin against the image"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of God, even though they continue to emphasize the dignity of that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"image, is quite in keeping with their present activities. They talk"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"about the Spirit, but they allow man, as the embodiment of the Spirit,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to degenerate to the proletarian level. Then they look on with amazement"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when they realize how small is the influence of the Christian Faith in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their own country and how depraved and ungodly is this riff-raff which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is physically degenerate and therefore morally degenerate also. To"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"balance this state of affairs they try to convert the Hottentots and the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Zulus and the Kaffirs and to bestow on them the blessings of the Church."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"While our European people, God be praised and thanked, are left to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"become the victims of moral depravity, the pious missionary goes out to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Central Africa and establishes missionary stations for negroes. Finally,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"sound and healthy--though primitive and backward--people will be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"transformed, under the name of our 'higher civilization', into a motley"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of lazy and brutalized mongrels."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It would better accord with noble human aspirations if our two Christian"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"denominations would cease to bother the negroes with their preaching,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which the negroes do not want and do not understand. It would be better"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"if they left this work alone, and if, in its stead, they tried to teach"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people in Europe, kindly and seriously, that it is much more pleasing to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"God if a couple that is not of healthy stock were to show loving"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"kindness to some poor orphan and become a father and mother to him,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"rather than give life to a sickly child that will be a cause of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"suffering and unhappiness to all."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In this field the People's State will have to repair the damage that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"arises from the fact that the problem is at present neglected by all the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"various parties concerned. It will be the task of the People's State to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"make the race the centre of the life of the community. It must make sure"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that the purity of the racial strain will be preserved. It must proclaim"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the truth that the child is the most valuable possession a people can"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have. It must see to it that only those who are healthy shall beget"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"children; that there is only one infamy, namely, for parents that are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ill or show hereditary defects to bring children into the world and that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in such cases it is a high honour to refrain from doing so. But, on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other hand, it must be considered as reprehensible conduct to refrain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"from giving healthy children to the nation. In this matter the State"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must assert itself as the trustee of a millennial future, in face of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which the egotistic desires of the individual count for nothing and will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have to give way before the ruling of the State. In order to fulfil this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duty in a practical manner the State will have to avail itself of modern"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"medical discoveries. It must proclaim as unfit for procreation all those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who are inflicted with some visible hereditary disease or are the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"carriers of it; and practical measures must be adopted to have such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people rendered sterile. On the other hand, provision must be made for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the normally fertile woman so that she will not be restricted in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"child-bearing through the financial and economic system operating in a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"political regime that looks upon the blessing of having children as a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"curse to their parents. The State will have to abolish the cowardly and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"even criminal indifference with which the problem of social amenities"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for large families is treated, and it will have to be the supreme"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"protector of this greatest blessing that a people can boast of. Its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attention and care must be directed towards the child rather than the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"adult."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Those who are physically and mentally unhealthy and unfit must not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"perpetuate their own suffering in the bodies of their children. From the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"educational point of view there is here a huge task for the People's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State to accomplish. But in a future era this work will appear greater"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and more significant than the victorious wars of our present bourgeois"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"epoch. Through educational means the State must teach individuals that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"illness is not a disgrace but an unfortunate accident which has to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pitied, yet that it is a crime and a disgrace to make this affliction"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"all the worse by passing on disease and defects to innocent creatures"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"out of mere egotism."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"And the State must also teach the people that it is an expression of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"really noble nature and that it is a humanitarian act worthy of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"admiration if a person who innocently suffers from hereditary disease"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"refrains from having a child of his own but gives his love and affection"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to some unknown child who, through its health, promises to become a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"robust member of a healthy community. In accomplishing such an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"educational task the State integrates its function by this activity in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the moral sphere. It must act on this principle without paying any"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attention to the question of whether its conduct will be understood or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"misconstrued, blamed or praised."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"If for a period of only 600 years those individuals would be sterilized"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who are physically degenerate or mentally diseased, humanity would not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"only be delivered from an immense misfortune but also restored to a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"eliminated which are to-day the cause of our moral and physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decadence. If a people and a State take this course to develop that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nucleus of the nation which is most valuable from the racial standpoint"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and thus increase its fecundity, the people as a whole will subsequently"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"enjoy that most precious of gifts which consists in a racial quality"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fashioned on truly noble lines."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"To achieve this the State should first of all not leave the colonization"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of newly acquired territory to a haphazard policy but should have it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"carried out under the guidance of definite principles. Specially"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"competent committees ought to issue certificates to individuals"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"entitling them to engage in colonization work, and these certificates"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"should guarantee the racial purity of the individuals in question. In"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this way frontier colonies could gradually be founded whose inhabitants"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would be of the purest racial stock, and hence would possess the best"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"qualities of the race. Such colonies would be a valuable asset to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"whole nation. Their development would be a source of joy and confidence"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and pride to each citizen of the nation, because they would contain the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pure germ which would ultimately bring about a great development of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nation and indeed of mankind itself."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The WELTANSCHAUUNG which bases the State on the racial idea must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"finally succeed in bringing about a nobler era, in which men will no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"longer pay exclusive attention to breeding and rearing pedigree dogs and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"horses and cats, but will endeavour to improve the breed of the human"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"race itself. That will be an era of silence and renunciation for one"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"class of people, while the others will give their gifts and make their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"sacrifices joyfully."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"That such a mentality may be possible cannot be denied in a world where"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"hundreds and thousands accept the principle of celibacy from their own"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"choice, without being obliged or pledged to do so by anything except an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"their bounden duty to give to the Almighty Creator beings such as He"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"himself made to His own image."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Naturally, our wretched army of contemporary philistines will not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"understand these things. They will ridicule them or shrug their round"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"shoulders and groan out their everlasting excuses: Of course it is a
fine thing, but the pity is that it cannot be carried out. And we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reply: With you indeed it cannot be done, for your world is incapable
of such an idea. You know only one anxiety and that is for your own
personal existence. You have one God, and that is your money. We do not
turn to you, however, for help, but to the great army of those who are
too poor to consider their personal existence as the highest good on

whose hands they confide their lives. Above all we turn to the vast army

they will fight against the evils which were due to the laziness and
indifference of their fathers. Either the German youth will one day"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"create a new State founded on the racial idea or they will be the last"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"witnesses of the complete breakdown and death of the bourgeois world."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For if a generation suffers from defects which it recognizes and even"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"world is to-day, resorting to the cheap excuse that nothing can be done"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to remedy the situation, then such a generation is doomed to disaster. A"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"marked characteristic of our bourgeois world is that they no longer can"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"deny the evil conditions that exist. They have to admit that there is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"attitude. If, for instance, a whole continent wages war against"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"aim and in that part of the world this sublime and intangible attitude"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"principles are used in this slanderous campaign against a movement which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"aims at suppressing a great source of immorality."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"No. We must not permit ourselves to be deceived by any illusions on this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"noble human task because it has lost all high quality and is evil, not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"the further propagation of the racial stock."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Just as, in general, the racial quality is the preliminary condition for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the mental efficiency of any given human material, the training of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual will first of all have to be directed towards the development"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"degenerates it is rare for a great spirit to arise from such a miserable"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"motley. And in any case his activities would never meet with great"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"success. A degenerate mob will either be incapable of understanding him"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"at all or their will-power is so feeble that they cannot follow the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"soaring of such an eagle."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The State that is grounded on the racial principle and is alive to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"significance of this truth will first of all have to base its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"

"physical training and development of healthy bodies. The cultivation of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the intellectual facilities comes only in the second place. And here"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"again it is character which has to be developed first of all, strength"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of will and decision. And the educational system ought to foster the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spirit of readiness to accept responsibilities gladly. Formal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instruction in the sciences must be considered last in importance."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Accordingly the State which is grounded on the racial idea must start"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with the principle that a person whose formal education in the sciences"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is relatively small but who is physically sound and robust, of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"steadfast and honest character, ready and able to make decisions and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"endowed with strength of will, is a more useful member of the national"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"community than a weakling who is scholarly and refined. A nation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"composed of learned men who are physical weaklings, hesitant about"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decisions of the will, and timid pacifists, is not capable of assuring"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"even its own existence on this earth. In the bitter struggle which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decides the destiny of man it is very rare that an individual has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"succumbed because he lacked learning. Those who fail are they who try to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ignore these consequences and are too faint-hearted about putting them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"into effect. There must be a certain balance between mind and body. An"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ill-kept body is not made a more beautiful sight by the indwelling of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"radiant spirit. We should not be acting justly if we were to bestow the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"highest intellectual training on those who are physically deformed and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"crippled, who lack decision and are weak-willed and cowardly. What has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"made the Greek ideal of beauty immortal is the wonderful union of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"splendid physical beauty with nobility of mind and spirit."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Moltke's saying, that in the long run fortune favours only the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"efficient, is certainly valid for the relationship between body and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spirit. A mind which is sound will generally maintain its dwelling in a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"body that is sound."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Accordingly, in the People's State physical training is not a matter for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the individual alone. Nor is it a duty which first devolves on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"parents and only secondly or thirdly a public interest; but it is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"necessary for the preservation of the people, who are represented and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"protected by the State. As regards purely formal education the State"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"even now interferes with the individual's right of self-determination"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and insists upon the right of the community by submitting the child to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an obligatory system of training, without paying attention to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"approval or disapproval of the parents. In a similar way and to a higher"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"degree the new People's State will one day make its authority prevail"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"over the ignorance and incomprehension of individuals in problems"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"appertaining to the safety of the nation. It must organize its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"educational work in such a way that the bodies of the young will be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"systematically trained from infancy onwards, so as to be tempered and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"hardened for the demands to be made on them in later years. Above all,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the State must see to it that a generation of stay-at-homes is not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"developed."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The work of education and hygiene has to begin with the young mother."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The painstaking efforts carried on for several decades have succeeded in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"abolishing septic infection at childbirth and reducing puerperal fever"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to a relatively small number of cases. And so it ought to be possible by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"means of instructing sisters and mothers in an opportune way, to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institute a system of training the child from early infancy onwards so"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that this may serve as an excellent basis for future development."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The People's State ought to allow much more time for physical training"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the school. It is nonsense to burden young brains with a load of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"material of which, as experience shows, they retain only a small part,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and mostly not the essentials, but only the secondary and useless"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"portion; because the young mind is incapable of sifting the right kind"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of learning out of all the stuff that is pumped into it. To-day, even in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the curriculum of the high schools, only two short hours in the week are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reserved for gymnastics; and worse still, it is left to the pupils to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decide whether or not they want to take part. This shows a grave"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"disproportion between this branch of education and purely intellectual"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instruction. Not a single day should be allowed to pass in which the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"young pupil does not have one hour of physical training in the morning"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and one in the evening; and every kind of sport and gymnastics should be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"included. There is one kind of sport which should be specially"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"encouraged, although many people who call themselves VÃLKISCH consider"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it brutal and vulgar, and that is boxing. It is incredible how many"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"false notions prevail among the 'cultivated' classes. The fact that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"young man learns how to fence and then spends his time in duels is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"considered quite natural and respectable. But boxing--that is brutal."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Why? There is no other sport which equals this in developing the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"militant spirit, none that demands such a power of rapid decision or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which gives the body the flexibility of good steel. It is no more vulgar"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when two young people settle their differences with their fists than"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with sharp-pointed pieces of steel. One who is attacked and defends"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"himself with his fists surely does not act less manly than one who runs"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"off and yells for the assistance of a policeman. But, above all, a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"healthy youth has to learn to endure hard knocks. This principle may"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"appear savage to our contemporary champions who fight only with the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"weapons of the intellect. But it is not the purpose of the People's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State to educate a colony of aesthetic pacifists and physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"degenerates. This State does not consider that the human ideal is to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"found in the honourable philistine or the maidenly spinster, but in a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"dareful personification of manly force and in women capable of bringing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"men into the world."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Generally speaking, the function of sport is not only to make the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual strong, alert and daring, but also to harden the body and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"train it to endure an adverse environment."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"If our superior class had not received such a distinguished education,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and if, on the contrary, they had learned boxing, it would never have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"been possible for bullies and deserters and other such CANAILLE to carry"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"through a German revolution. For the success of this revolution was not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"due to the courageous, energetic and audacious activities of its authors"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but to the lamentable cowardice and irresolution of those who ruled the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"German State at that time and were responsible for it. But our educated"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"leaders had received only an 'intellectual' training and thus found"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"themselves defenceless when their adversaries used iron bars instead of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual weapons. All this could happen only because our superior"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"scholastic system did not train men to be real men but merely to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"civil servants, engineers, technicians, chemists, litterateurs, jurists"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and, finally, professors; so that intellectualism should not die out."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Our leadership in the purely intellectual sphere has always been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"brilliant, but as regards will-power in practical affairs our leadership"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has been beneath criticism."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Of course education cannot make a courageous man out of one who is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"temperamentally a coward. But a man who naturally possesses a certain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"degree of courage will not be able to develop that quality if his"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defective education has made him inferior to others from the very start"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"as regards physical strength and prowess. The army offers the best"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"example of the fact that the knowledge of one's physical ability"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"develops a man's courage and militant spirit. Outstanding heroes are not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the rule in the army, but the average represents men of high courage."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The excellent schooling which the German soldiers received before the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"War imbued the members of the whole gigantic organism with a degree of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"confidence in their own superiority such as even our opponents never"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"thought possible. All the immortal examples of dauntless courage and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"daring which the German armies gave during the late summer and autumn of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"1914, as they advanced from triumph to triumph, were the result of that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"education which had been pursued systematically. During those long years"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of peace before the last War men who were almost physical weaklings were"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"made capable of incredible deeds, and thus a self-confidence was"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"developed which did not fail even in the most terrible battles."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is our German people, which broke down and were delivered over to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"kicked by the rest of the world, that had need of the power that comes"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"by suggestion from self-confidence. But this confidence in one's self"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must be instilled into our children from their very early years. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"whole system of education and training must be directed towards"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fostering in the child the conviction that he is unquestionably a match"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for any- and everybody. The individual has to regain his own physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"strength and prowess in order to believe in the invincibility of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nation to which he belongs. What has formerly led the German armies to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"victory was the sum total of the confidence which each individual had in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"himself, and which all of them had in those who held the positions of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"command. What will restore the national strength of the German people is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the conviction that they will be able to reconquer their liberty. But"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this conviction can only be the final product of an equal feeling in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"millions of individuals. And here again we must have no illusions."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The collapse of our people was overwhelming, and the efforts to put an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"end to so much misery must also be overwhelming. It would be a bitter"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and grave error to believe that our people could be made strong again"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"simply by means of our present bourgeois training in good order and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"obedience. That will not suffice if we are to break up the present order"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of things, which now sanctions the acknowledgment of our defeat and cast"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the broken chains of our slavery in the face of our opponents. Only by a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"superabundance of national energy and a passionate thirst for liberty"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"can we recover what has been lost."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
