"Also the manner of clothing the young should be such as harmonizes with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this purpose. It is really lamentable to see how our young people have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fallen victims to a fashion mania which perverts the meaning of the old"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"adage that clothes make the man."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Especially in regard to young people clothes should take their place in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the service of education. The boy who walks about in summer-time wearing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"long baggy trousers and clad up to the neck is hampered even by his"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"clothes in feeling any inclination towards strenuous physical exercise."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Ambition and, to speak quite frankly, even vanity must be appealed to. I"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"do not mean such vanity as leads people to want to wear fine clothes,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which not everybody can afford, but rather the vanity which inclines a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"person towards developing a fine bodily physique. And this is something"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which everybody can help to do."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This will come in useful also for later years. The young girl must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"become acquainted with her sweetheart. If the beauty of the body were"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not completely forced into the background to-day through our stupid"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"manner of dressing, it would not be possible for thousands of our girls"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to be led astray by Jewish mongrels, with their repulsive crooked"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"waddle. It is also in the interests of the nation that those who have a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"beautiful physique should be brought into the foreground, so that they"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"might encourage the development of a beautiful bodily form among the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people in general."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Military training is excluded among us to-day, and therewith the only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institution which in peace-times at least partly made up for the lack of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"physical training in our education. Therefore what I have suggested is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"all the more necessary in our time. The success of our old military"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"training not only showed itself in the education of the individual but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"also in the influence which it exercised over the mutual relationship"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"between the sexes. The young girl preferred the soldier to one who was"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not a soldier. The People's State must not confine its control of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"physical training to the official school period, but it must demand"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that, after leaving school and while the adolescent body is still"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"developing, the boy continues this training. For on such proper physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"development success in after-life largely depends. It is stupid to think"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that the right of the State to supervise the education of its young"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"citizens suddenly comes to an end the moment they leave school and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"recommences only with military service. This right is a duty, and as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"such it must continue uninterruptedly. The present State, which does not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"interest itself in developing healthy men, has criminally neglected this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duty. It leaves our contemporary youth to be corrupted on the streets"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and in the brothels, instead of keeping hold of the reins and continuing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the physical training of these youths up to the time when they are grown"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"into healthy young men and women."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For the present it is a matter of indifference what form the State"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"chooses for carrying on this training. The essential matter is that it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"should be developed and that the most suitable ways of doing so should"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be investigated. The People's State will have to consider the physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"training of the youth after the school period just as much a public duty"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"as their intellectual training; and this training will have to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"carried out through public institutions. Its general lines can be a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"preparation for subsequent service in the army. And then it will no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"longer be the task of the army to teach the young recruit the most"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"elementary drill regulations. In fact the army will no longer have to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"deal with recruits in the present sense of the word, but it will rather"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have to transform into a soldier the youth whose bodily prowess has been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"already fully trained."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In the People's State the army will no longer be obliged to teach boys"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"how to walk and stand erect, but it will be the final and supreme school"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of patriotic education. In the army the young recruit will learn the art"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of bearing arms, but at the same time he will be equipped for his other"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duties in later life. And the supreme aim of military education must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"always be to achieve that which was attributed to the old army as its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"highest merit: namely, that through his military schooling the boy must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be transformed into a man, that he must not only learn to obey but also"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"acquire the fundamentals that will enable him one day to command. He"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must learn to remain silent not only when he is rightly rebuked but also"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when he is wrongly rebuked."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Furthermore, on the self-consciousness of his own strength and on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"basis of that ESPRIT DE CORPS which inspires him and his comrades, he"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must become convinced that he belongs to a people who are invincible."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"After he has completed his military training two certificates shall be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"handed to the soldier. The one will be his diploma as a citizen of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State, a juridical document which will enable him to take part in public"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"affairs. The second will be an attestation of his physical health, which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"guarantees his fitness for marriage."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The People's State will have to direct the education of girls just as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that of boys and according to the same fundamental principles. Here"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"again special importance must be given to physical training, and only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"after that must the importance of spiritual and mental training be taken"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"into account. In the education of the girl the final goal always to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"kept in mind is that she is one day to be a mother."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is only in the second place that the People's State must busy itself"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with the training of character, using all the means adapted to that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"purpose."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Of course the essential traits of the individual character are already"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"there fundamentally before any education takes place. A person who is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fundamentally egoistic will always remain fundamentally egoistic, and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the idealist will always remain fundamentally an idealist. Besides"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those, however, who already possess a definite stamp of character there"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"are millions of people with characters that are indefinite and vague."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The born delinquent will always remain a delinquent, but numerous people"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who show only a certain tendency to commit criminal acts may become"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"useful members of the community if rightly trained; whereas, on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other hand, weak and unstable characters may easily become evil elements"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"if the system of education has been bad."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"During the War it was often lamented that our people could be so little"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reticent. This failing made it very difficult to keep even highly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"important secrets from the knowledge of the enemy. But let us ask this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"question: What did the German educational system do in pre-War times to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"teach the Germans to be discreet? Did it not very often happen in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"schooldays that the little tell-tale was preferred to his companions who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"kept their mouths shut? Is it not true that then, as well as now,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"complaining about others was considered praiseworthy 'candour', while"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"silent discretion was taken as obstinacy? Has any attempt ever been made"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to teach that discretion is a precious and manly virtue? No, for such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"matters are trifles in the eyes of our educators. But these trifles cost"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"our State innumerable millions in legal expenses; for 90 per cent of all"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the processes for defamation and such like charges arise only from a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lack of discretion. Remarks that are made without any sense of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"responsibility are thoughtlessly repeated from mouth to mouth; and our"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"economic welfare is continually damaged because important methods of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"production are thus disclosed. Secret preparations for our national"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defence are rendered illusory because our people have never learned the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duty of silence. They repeat everything they happen to hear. In times of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"war such talkative habits may even cause the loss of battles and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"therefore may contribute essentially to the unsuccessful outcome of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"campaign. Here, as in other matters, we may rest assured that adults"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cannot do what they have not learnt to do in youth. A teacher must not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"try to discover the wild tricks of the boys by encouraging the evil"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"practice of tale-bearing. Young people form a sort of State among"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"themselves and face adults with a certain solidarity. That is quite"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"natural. The ties which unite the ten-year boys to one another are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stronger and more natural than their relationship to adults. A boy who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"tells on his comrades commits an act of treason and shows a bent of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"character which is, to speak bluntly, similar to that of a man who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"commits high treason. Such a boy must not be classed as 'good',"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"'reliable', and so on, but rather as one with undesirable traits of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"character. It may be rather convenient for the teacher to make use of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"such unworthy tendencies in order to help his own work, but by such an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attitude the germ of a moral habit is sown in young hearts and may one"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"day show fatal consequences. It has happened more often than once that a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"young informer developed into a big scoundrel."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This is only one example among many. The deliberate training of fine and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"noble traits of character in our schools to-day is almost negative. In"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the future much more emphasis will have to be laid on this side of our"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"educational work. Loyalty, self-sacrifice and discretion are virtues"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which a great nation must possess. And the teaching and development of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"these in the school is a more important matter than many others things"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"now included in the curriculum. To make the children give up habits of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"complaining and whining and howling when they are hurt, etc., also"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"belongs to this part of their training. If the educational system fails"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to teach the child at an early age to endure pain and injury without"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"complaining we cannot be surprised if at a later age, when the boy has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"grown to be the man and is, for example, in the trenches, the postal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"service is used for nothing else than to send home letters of weeping"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and complaint. If our youths, during their years in the primary schools,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"had had their minds crammed with a little less knowledge, and if instead"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"they had been better taught how to be masters of themselves, it would"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have served us well during the years 1914-1918."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In its educational system the People's State will have to attach the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"highest importance to the development of character, hand-in-hand with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"physical training. Many more defects which our national organism shows"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"at present could be at least ameliorated, if not completely eliminated,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"by education of the right kind."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Extreme importance should be attached to the training of will-power and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the habit of making firm decisions, also the habit of being always ready"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to accept responsibilities."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In the training of our old army the principle was in vogue that any"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"order is always better than no order. Applied to our youth this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"principle ought to take the form that any answer is better than no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"answer. The fear of replying, because one fears to be wrong, ought to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"considered more humiliating than giving the wrong reply. On this simple"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and primitive basis our youth should be trained to have the courage to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"act."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It has been often lamented that in November and December 1918 all the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"authorities lost their heads and that, from the monarch down to the last"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"divisional commander, nobody had sufficient mettle to make a decision on"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"his own responsibility. That terrible fact constitutes a grave rebuke to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"our educational system; because what was then revealed on a colossal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"scale at that moment of catastrophe was only what happens on a smaller"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"scale everywhere among us. It is the lack of will-power, and not the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lack of arms, which renders us incapable of offering any serious"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"resistance to-day. This defect is found everywhere among our people and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"prevents decisive action wherever risks have to be taken, as if any"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"great action can be taken without also taking the risk. Quite"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"unsuspectingly, a German General found a formula for this lamentable"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lack of the will-to-act when he said: I act only when I can count on a
51 per cent probability of success. In that '51 per cent probability'"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"we find the very root of the German collapse. The man who demands from"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Fate a guarantee of his success deliberately denies the significance of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an heroic act. For this significance consists in the very fact that, in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the definite knowledge that the situation in question is fraught with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mortal danger, an action is undertaken which may lead to success. A"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"patient suffering from cancer and who knows that his death is certain if"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"he does not undergo an operation, needs no 51 per cent probability of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cure before facing the operation. And if the operation promises only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"half of one per cent probability of success a man of courage will risk"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it and would not whine if it turned out unsuccessful."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"All in all, the cowardly lack of will-power and the incapacity for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"making decisions are chiefly results of the erroneous education given us"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in our youth. The disastrous effects of this are now widespread among"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"us. The crowning examples of that tragic chain of consequences are shown"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the lack of civil courage which our leading statesmen display."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The cowardice which leads nowadays to the shirking of every kind of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"responsibility springs from the same roots. Here again it is the fault"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the education given our young people. This drawback permeates all"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"sections of public life and finds its immortal consummation in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"institutions of government that function under the parliamentary regime."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Already in the school, unfortunately, more value is placed on"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"'confession and full repentance' and 'contrite renouncement', on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"part of little sinners, than on a simple and frank avowal. But this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"latter seems to-day, in the eyes of many an educator, to savour of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spirit of utter incorrigibility and depravation. And, though it may seem"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"incredible, many a boy is told that the gallows tree is waiting for him"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because he has shown certain traits which might be of inestimable value"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the nation as a whole."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Just as the People's State must one day give its attention to training"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the will-power and capacity for decision among the youth, so too it must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"inculcate in the hearts of the young generation from early childhood"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"onwards a readiness to accept responsibilities, and the courage of open"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and frank avowal. If it recognizes the full significance of this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"necessity, finally--after a century of educative work--it will succeed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in building up a nation which will no longer be subject to those defeats"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that have contributed so disastrously to bring about our present"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"overthrow."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The formal imparting of knowledge, which constitutes the chief work of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"our educational system to-day, will be taken over by the People's State"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with only few modifications. These modifications must be made in three"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"branches."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"First of all, the brains of the young people must not generally be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"burdened with subjects of which ninety-five per cent are useless to them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and are therefore forgotten again. The curriculum of the primary and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"secondary schools presents an odd mixture at the present time. In many"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"branches of study the subject matter to be learned has become so"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"enormous that only a very small fraction of it can be remembered later"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"on, and indeed only a very small fraction of this whole mass of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"knowledge can be used. On the other hand, what is learned is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"insufficient for anybody who wishes to specialize in any certain branch"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for the purpose of earning his daily bread. Take, for example, the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"average civil servant who has passed through the GYMNASIUM or High"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"School, and ask him at the age of thirty or forty how much he has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"retained of the knowledge that was crammed into him with so much pains."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"How much is retained from all that was stuffed into his brain? He will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"certainly answer: Well, if a mass of stuff was then taught, it was not
for the sole purpose of supplying the student with a great stock of
knowledge from which he could draw in later years, but it served to
develop the understanding, the memory, and above all it helped to
strengthen the thinking powers of the brain. That is partly true. And"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"yet it is somewhat dangerous to submerge a young brain in a flood of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"impressions which it can hardly master and the single elements of which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it cannot discern or appreciate at their just value. It is mostly the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"essential part of this knowledge, and not the accidental, that is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"forgotten and sacrificed. Thus the principal purpose of this copious"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instruction is frustrated, for that purpose cannot be to make the brain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"capable of learning by simply offering it an enormous and varied amount"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of subjects for acquisition, but rather to furnish the individual with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that stock of knowledge which he will need in later life and which he"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"can use for the good of the community. This aim, however, is rendered"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"illusory if, because of the superabundance of subjects that have been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"crammed into his head in childhood, a person is able to remember"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nothing, or at least not the essential portion, of all this in later"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"life. There is no reason why millions of people should learn two or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"three languages during the school years, when only a very small fraction"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will have the opportunity to use these languages in later life and when"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"most of them will therefore forget those languages completely. To take"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an instance: Out of 100,000 students who learn French there are probably"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not 2,000 who will be in a position to make use of this accomplishment"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in later life, while 98,000 will never have a chance to utilize in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"practice what they have learned in youth. They have spent thousands of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"hours on a subject which will afterwards be without any value or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"importance to them. The argument that these matters form part of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"general process of educating the mind is invalid. It would be sound if"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"all these people were able to use this learning in after life. But, as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the situation stands, 98,000 are tortured to no purpose and waste their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"valuable time, only for the sake of the 2,000 to whom the language will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be of any use."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In the case of that language which I have chosen as an example it cannot"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be said that the learning of it educates the student in logical thinking"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"or sharpens his mental acumen, as the learning of Latin, for instance,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"might be said to do. It would therefore be much better to teach young"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"students only the general outline, or, better, the inner structure of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"such a language: that is to say, to allow them to discern the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"characteristic features of the language, or perhaps to make them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"acquainted with the rudiments of its grammar, its pronunciation, its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"syntax, style, etc. That would be sufficient for average students,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because it would provide a clearer view of the whole and could be more"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"easily remembered. And it would be more practical than the present-day"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attempt to cram into their heads a detailed knowledge of the whole"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"language, which they can never master and which they will readily"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"forget. If this method were adopted, then we should avoid the danger"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that, out of the superabundance of matter taught, only some fragments"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will remain in the memory; for the youth would then have to learn what"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is worth while, and the selection between the useful and the useless"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would thus have been made beforehand."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"As regards the majority of students the knowledge and understanding of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the rudiments of a language would be quite sufficient for the rest of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their lives. And those who really do need this language subsequently"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would thus have a foundation on which to start, should they choose to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"make a more thorough study of it."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"By adopting such a curriculum the necessary amount of time would be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"gained for physical exercises as well as for a more intense training in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the various educational fields that have already been mentioned."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A reform of particular importance is that which ought to take place in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the present methods of teaching history. Scarcely any other people are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"made to study as much of history as the Germans, and scarcely any other"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people make such a bad use of their historical knowledge. If politics"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"means history in the making, then our way of teaching history stands"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"condemned by the way we have conducted our politics. But there would be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"no point in bewailing the lamentable results of our political conduct"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"unless one is now determined to give our people a better political"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"education. In 99 out of 100 cases the results of our present teaching of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"history are deplorable. Usually only a few dates, years of birth and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"names, remain in the memory, while a knowledge of the main and clearly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defined lines of historical development is completely lacking. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"essential features which are of real significance are not taught. It is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"left to the more or less bright intelligence of the individual to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"discover the inner motivating urge amid the mass of dates and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"chronological succession of events."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"You may object as strongly as you like to this unpleasant statement. But"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"read with attention the speeches which our parliamentarians make during"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"one session alone on political problems and on questions of foreign"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"policy in particular. Remember that those gentlemen are, or claim to be,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the elite of the German nation and that at least a great number of them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have sat on the benches of our secondary schools and that many of them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have passed through our universities. Then you will realize how"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defective the historical education of these people has been. If these"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"gentlemen had never studied history at all but had possessed a sound"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instinct for public affairs, things would have gone better, and the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nation would have benefited greatly thereby."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The subject matter of our historical teaching must be curtailed. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"chief value of that teaching is to make the principal lines of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"historical development understood. The more our historical teaching is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"limited to this task, the more we may hope that it will turn out"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"subsequently to be of advantage to the individual and, through the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual, to the community as a whole. For history must not be studied"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"merely with a view to knowing what happened in the past but as a guide"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for the future, and to teach us what policy would be the best to follow"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for the preservation of our own people. That is the real end; and the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"teaching of history is only a means to attain this end. But here again"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the means has superseded the end in our contemporary education. The goal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is completely forgotten. Do not reply that a profound study of history"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"demands a detailed knowledge of all these dates because otherwise we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"could not fix the great lines of development. That task belongs to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"professional historians. But the average man is not a professor of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"history. For him history has only one mission and that is to provide him"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with such an amount of historical knowledge as is necessary in order to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"enable him to form an independent opinion on the political affairs of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"his own country. The man who wants to become a professor of history can"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"devote himself to all the details later on. Naturally he will have to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"occupy himself even with the smallest details. Of course our present"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"teaching of history is not adequate to all this. Its scope is too vast"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for the average student and too limited for the student who wishes to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an historical expert."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Finally, it is the business of the People's State to arrange for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"writing of a world history in which the race problem will occupy a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"dominant position."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"To sum up: The People's State must reconstruct our system of general"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instruction in such a way that it will embrace only what is essential."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Beyond this it will have to make provision for a more advanced teaching"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the various subjects for those who want to specialize in them. It"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will suffice for the average individual to be acquainted with the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fundamentals of the various subjects to serve as the basis of what may"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be called an all-round education. He ought to study exhaustively and in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"detail only that subject in which he intends to work during the rest of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"his life. A general instruction in all subjects should be obligatory,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and specialization should be left to the choice of the individual."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In this way the scholastic programme would be shortened, and thus"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"several school hours would be gained which could be utilized for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"physical training and character training, in will-power, the capacity"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for making practical judgments, decisions, etc."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The little account taken by our school training to-day, especially in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the secondary schools, of the callings that have to be followed in after"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"life is demonstrated by the fact that men who are destined for the same"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"calling in life are educated in three different kinds of schools. What"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is of decisive importance is general education only and not the special"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"teaching. When special knowledge is needed it cannot be given in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"curriculum of our secondary schools as they stand to-day."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore the People's State will one day have to abolish such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"half-measures."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The second modification in the curriculum which the People's State will"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have to make is the following:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is a characteristic of our materialistic epoch that our scientific"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"education shows a growing emphasis on what is real and practical: such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"subjects, for instance, as applied mathematics, physics, chemistry, etc."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Of course they are necessary in an age that is dominated by industrial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"technology and chemistry, and where everyday life shows at least the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"external manifestations of these. But it is a perilous thing to base the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"general culture of a nation on the knowledge of these subjects. On the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"contrary, that general culture ought always to be directed towards"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ideals. It ought to be founded on the humanist disciplines and should"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"aim at giving only the ground work of further specialized instruction in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the various practical sciences. Otherwise we should sacrifice those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"forces that are more important for the preservation of the nation than"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"any technical knowledge. In the historical department the study of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ancient history should not be omitted. Roman history, along general"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lines, is and will remain the best teacher, not only for our own time"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but also for the future. And the ideal of Hellenic culture should be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"preserved for us in all its marvellous beauty. The differences between"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the various peoples should not prevent us from recognizing the community"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of race which unites them on a higher plane. The conflict of our times"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is one that is being waged around great objectives. A civilization is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fighting for its existence. It is a civilization that is the product of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"thousands of years of historical development, and the Greek as well as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the German forms part of it."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A clear-cut division must be made between general culture and the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"special branches. To-day the latter threaten more and more to devote"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"themselves exclusively to the service of Mammon. To counterbalance this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"tendency, general culture should be preserved, at least in its ideal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"forms. The principle should be repeatedly emphasized, that industrial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and technical progress, trade and commerce, can flourish only so long as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a folk community exists whose general system of thought is inspired by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ideals, since that is the preliminary condition for a flourishing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"development of the enterprises I have spoken of. That condition is not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"created by a spirit of materialist egotism but by a spirit of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"self-denial and the joy of giving one's self in the service of others."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The system of education which prevails to-day sees its principal object"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in pumping into young people that knowledge which will help them to make"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their way in life. This principle is expressed in the following terms:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The young man must one day become a useful member of human society. By"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that phrase they mean the ability to gain an honest daily livelihood."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The superficial training in the duties of good citizenship, which he"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"acquires merely as an accidental thing, has very weak foundations. For"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in itself the State represents only a form, and therefore it is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"difficult to train people to look upon this form as the ideal which they"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will have to serve and towards which they must feel responsible. A form"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"can be too easily broken. But, as we have seen, the idea which people"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have of the State to-day does not represent anything clearly defined."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore, there is nothing but the usual stereotyped 'patriotic'"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"training. In the old Germany the greatest emphasis was placed on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"divine right of the small and even the smallest potentates. The way in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which this divine right was formulated and presented was never very"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"clever and often very stupid. Because of the large numbers of those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"small potentates, it was impossible to give adequate biographical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"accounts of the really great personalities that shed their lustre on the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"history of the German people. The result was that the broad masses"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"received a very inadequate knowledge of German history. Here, too, the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"great lines of development were missing."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is evident that in such a way no real national enthusiasm could be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"aroused. Our educational system proved incapable of selecting from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"general mass of our historical personages the names of a few"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"personalities which the German people could be proud to look upon as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"their own. Thus the whole nation might have been united by the ties of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"common knowledge of this common heritage. The really important figures"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in German history were not presented to the present generation. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"attention of the whole nation was not concentrated on them for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"purpose of awakening a common national spirit. From the various subjects"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that were taught, those who had charge of our training seemed incapable"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of selecting what redounded most to the national honour and lifting that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"above the common objective level, in order to inflame the national pride"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the light of such brilliant examples. At that time such a course"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would have been looked upon as rank chauvinism, which did not then have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a very pleasant savour. Pettifogging dynastic patriotism was more"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"acceptable and more easily tolerated than the glowing fire of a supreme"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"national pride. The former could be always pressed into service, whereas"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the latter might one day become a dominating force. Monarchist"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"patriotism terminated in Associations of Veterans, whereas passionate"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"national patriotism might have opened a road which would be difficult to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"determine. This national passion is like a highly tempered thoroughbred"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who is discriminate about the sort of rider he will tolerate in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"saddle. No wonder that most people preferred to shirk such a danger."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Nobody seemed to think it possible that one day a war might come which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"would put the mettle of this kind of patriotism to the test, in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"artillery bombardment and waves of attacks with poison gas. But when it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"did come our lack of this patriotic passion was avenged in a terrible"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"way. None were very enthusiastic about dying for their imperial and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"royal sovereigns; while on the other hand the 'Nation' was not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"recognized by the greater number of the soldiers."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Since the revolution broke out in Germany and the monarchist patriotism"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"was therefore extinguished, the purpose of teaching history was nothing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"more than to add to the stock of objective knowledge. The present State"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has no use for patriotic enthusiasm; but it will never obtain what it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"really desires. For if dynastic patriotism failed to produce a supreme"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"power of resistance at a time when the principle of nationalism"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"dominated, it will be still less possible to arouse republican"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"enthusiasm. There can be no doubt that the German people would not have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stood on the field of battle for four and a half years to fight under"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the battle slogan 'For the Republic,' and least of all those who created"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this grand institution."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In reality this Republic has been allowed to exist undisturbed only by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"grace of its readiness and its promise to all and sundry, to pay tribute"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and reparations to the stranger and to put its signature to any kind of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"territorial renunciation. The rest of the world finds it sympathetic,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"just as a weakling is always more pleasing to those who want to bend him"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to their own uses than is a man who is made of harder metal. But the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fact that the enemy likes this form of government is the worst kind of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"condemnation. They love the German Republic and tolerate its existence"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"because no better instrument could be found which would help them to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"keep our people in slavery. It is to this fact alone that this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"magnanimous institution owes its survival. And that is why it can"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"renounce any REAL system of national education and can feel satisfied"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when the heroes of the REICH banner shout their hurrahs, but in reality"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"these same heroes would scamper away like rabbits if called upon to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"defend that banner with their blood."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The People's State will have to fight for its existence. It will not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"gain or secure this existence by signing documents like that of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Dawes Plan. But for its existence and defence it will need precisely"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those things which our present system believes can be repudiated. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"more worthy its form and its inner national being. the greater will be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the envy and opposition of its adversaries. The best defence will not be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the arms it possesses but in its citizens. Bastions of fortresses"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will not save it, but the living wall of its men and women, filled with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"an ardent love for their country and a passionate spirit of national"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"patriotism."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Therefore the third point which will have to be considered in relation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to our educational system is the following:"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The People's State must realize that the sciences may also be made a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"means of promoting a spirit of pride in the nation. Not only the history"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the world but the history of civilization as a whole must be taught"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in the light of this principle. An inventor must appear great not only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"as an inventor but also, and even more so, as a member of the nation."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The admiration aroused by the contemplation of a great achievement must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be transformed into a feeling of pride and satisfaction that a man of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"one's own race has been chosen to accomplish it. But out of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"abundance of great names in German history the greatest will have to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"selected and presented to our young generation in such a way as to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"become solid pillars of strength to support the national spirit."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The subject matter ought to be systematically organized from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"standpoint of this principle. And the teaching should be so orientated"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that the boy or girl, after leaving school, will not be a semi-pacifist,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a democrat or of something else of that kind, but a whole-hearted"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"German. So that this national feeling be sincere from the very"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"beginning, and not a mere pretence, the following fundamental and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"inflexible principle should be impressed on the young brain while it is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"yet malleable: The man who loves his nation can prove the sincerity of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this sentiment only by being ready to make sacrifices for the nation's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"welfare. There is no such thing as a national sentiment which is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"directed towards personal interests. And there is no such thing as a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nationalism that embraces only certain classes. Hurrahing proves nothing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and does not confer the right to call oneself national if behind that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"shout there is no sincere preoccupation for the conservation of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nation's well-being. One can be proud of one's people only if there is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"no class left of which one need to be ashamed. When one half of a nation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is sunk in misery and worn out by hard distress, or even depraved or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"degenerate, that nation presents such an unattractive picture that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nobody can feel proud to belong to it. It is only when a nation is sound"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in all its members, physically and morally, that the joy of belonging to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it can properly be intensified to the supreme feeling which we call"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"national pride. But this pride, in its highest form, can be felt only by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"those who know the greatness of their nation."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The spirit of nationalism and a feeling for social justice must be fused"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"into one sentiment in the hearts of the youth. Then a day will come when"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a nation of citizens will arise which will be welded together through a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"common love and a common pride that shall be invincible and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"indestructible for ever."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The dread of chauvinism, which is a symptom of our time, is a sign of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its impotence. Since our epoch not only lacks everything in the nature"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of exuberant energy but even finds such a manifestation disagreeable,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fate will never elect it for the accomplishment of any great deeds. For"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the greatest changes that have taken place on this earth would have been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"inconceivable if they had not been inspired by ardent and even"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"hysterical passions, but only by the bourgeois virtues of peacefulness"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and order."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"One thing is certain: our world is facing a great revolution. The only"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"question is whether the outcome will be propitious for the Aryan portion"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of mankind or whether the everlasting Jew will profit by it."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"By educating the young generation along the right lines, the People's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State will have to see to it that a generation of mankind is formed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which will be adequate to this supreme combat that will decide the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"destinies of the world."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"That nation will conquer which will be the first to take this road."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The whole organization of education and training which the People's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State is to build up must take as its crowning task the work of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"instilling into the hearts and brains of the youth entrusted to it the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"racial instinct and understanding of the racial idea. No boy or girl"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"must leave school without having attained a clear insight into the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"meaning of racial purity and the importance of maintaining the racial"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"blood unadulterated. Thus the first indispensable condition for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"preservation of our race will have been established and thus the future"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cultural progress of our people will be assured."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"For in the last analysis all physical and mental training would be in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"vain unless it served an entity which is ready and determined to carry"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"on its own existence and maintain its own characteristic qualities."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"If it were otherwise, something would result which we Germans have cause"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to regret already, without perhaps having hitherto recognized the extent"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the tragic calamity. We should be doomed to remain also in the future"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"only manure for civilization. And that not in the banal sense of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"contemporary bourgeois mind, which sees in a lost fellow member of our"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people only a lost citizen, but in a sense which we should have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"painfully to recognize: namely, that our racial blood would be destined"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to disappear. By continually mixing with other races we might lift them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"from their former lower level of civilization to a higher grade; but we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ourselves should descend for ever from the heights we had reached."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Finally, from the racial standpoint this training also must find its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"culmination in the military service. The term of military service is to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be a final stage of the normal training which the average German"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"receives."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"While the People's State attaches the greatest importance to physical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and mental training, it has also to consider, and no less importantly,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the task of selecting men for the service of the State itself. This"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"important matter is passed over lightly at the present time. Generally"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the children of parents who are for the time being in higher situations"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"are in their turn considered worthy of a higher education. Here talent"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"plays a subordinate part. But talent can be estimated only relatively."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Though in general culture he may be inferior to the city child, a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"peasant boy may be more talented than the son of a family that has"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"occupied high positions through many generations. But the superior"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"culture of the city child has in itself nothing to do with a greater or"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lesser degree of talent; for this culture has its roots in the more"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"copious mass of impressions which arise from the more varied education"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and the surroundings among which this child lives. If the intelligent"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"son of peasant parents were educated from childhood in similar"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"surroundings his intellectual accomplishments would be quite otherwise."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In our day there is only one sphere where the family in which a person"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"has been born means less than his innate gifts. That is the sphere of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"art. Here, where a person cannot just 'learn,' but must have innate"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"gifts that later on may undergo a more or less happy development (in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"sense of a wise development of what is already there), money and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"parental property are of no account. This is a good proof that genius is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not necessarily connected with the higher social strata or with wealth."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Not rarely the greatest artists come from poor families. And many a boy"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"from the country village has eventually become a celebrated master."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It does not say much for the mental acumen of our time that advantage is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not taken of this truth for the sake of our whole intellectual life. The"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"opinion is advanced that this principle, though undoubtedly valid in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"field of art, has not the same validity in regard to what are called the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"applied sciences. It is true that a man can be trained to a certain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"amount of mechanical dexterity, just as a poodle can be taught"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"incredible tricks by a clever master. But such training does not bring"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the animal to use his intelligence in order to carry out those tricks."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"And the same holds good in regard to man. It is possible to teach men,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"irrespective of talent or no talent, to go through certain scientific"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"exercises, but in such cases the results are quite as inanimate and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mechanical as in the case of the animal. It would even be possible to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"force a person of mediocre intelligence, by means of a severe course of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual drilling, to acquire more than the average amount of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"knowledge; but that knowledge would remain sterile. The result would be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a man who might be a walking dictionary of knowledge but who will fail"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"miserably on every critical occasion in life and at every juncture where"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"vital decisions have to be taken. Such people need to be drilled"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"specially for every new and even most insignificant task and will never"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be capable of contributing in the least to the general progress of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"mankind. Knowledge that is merely drilled into people can at best"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"qualify them to fill government positions under our present regime."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It goes without saying that, among the sum total of individuals who make"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"up a nation, gifted people are always to be found in every sphere of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"life. It is also quite natural that the value of knowledge will be all"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the greater the more vitally the dead mass of learning is animated by"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the innate talent of the individual who possesses it. Creative work in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this field can be done only through the marriage of knowledge and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"talent."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"One example will suffice to show how much our contemporary world is at"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fault in this matter. From time to time our illustrated papers publish,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"for the edification of the German philistine, the news that in some"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"quarter or other of the globe, and for the first time in that locality,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a Negro has become a lawyer, a teacher, a pastor, even a grand opera"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"tenor or something else of that kind. While the bourgeois blockhead"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stares with amazed admiration at the notice that tells him how"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"marvellous are the achievements of our modern educational technique, the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"more cunning Jew sees in this fact a new proof to be utilized for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"theory with which he wants to infect the public, namely that all men are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"equal. It does not dawn on the murky bourgeois mind that the fact which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is published for him is a sin against reason itself, that it is an act"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of criminal insanity to train a being who is only an anthropoid by birth"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"until the pretence can be made that he has been turned into a lawyer;"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"while, on the other hand, millions who belong to the most civilized"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"races have to remain in positions which are unworthy of their cultural"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"level. The bourgeois mind does not realize that it is a sin against the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will of the eternal Creator to allow hundreds of thousands of highly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"gifted people to remain floundering in the swamp of proletarian misery"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"while Hottentots and Zulus are drilled to fill positions in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual professions. For here we have the product only of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"drilling technique, just as in the case of the performing dog. If the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"same amount of care and effort were applied among intelligent races each"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual would become a thousand times more capable in such matters."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This state of affairs would become intolerable if a day should arrive"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"when it no longer refers to exceptional cases. But the situation is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"already intolerable where talent and natural gifts are not taken as"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decisive factors in qualifying for the right to a higher education. It"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is indeed intolerable to think that year after year hundreds of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"thousands of young people without a single vestige of talent are deemed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"worthy of a higher education, while other hundreds of thousands who"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"possess high natural gifts have to go without any sort of higher"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"schooling at all. The practical loss thus caused to the nation is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"incalculable. If the number of important discoveries which have been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"made in America has grown considerably in recent years one of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reasons is that the number of gifted persons belonging to the lowest"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"social classes who were given a higher education in that country is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"proportionately much larger than in Europe."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"A stock of knowledge packed into the brain will not suffice for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"making of discoveries. What counts here is only that knowledge which is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"illuminated by natural talent. But with us at the present time no value"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is placed on such gifts. Only good school reports count."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Here is another educative work that is waiting for the People's State to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"do. It will not be its task to assure a dominant influence to a certain"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"social class already existing, but it will be its duty to attract the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"most competent brains in the total mass of the nation and promote them"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to place and honour. It is not merely the duty of the State to give to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the average child a certain definite education in the primary school,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but it is also its duty to open the road to talent in the proper"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"direction. And above all, it must open the doors of the higher schools"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"under the State to talent of every sort, no matter in what social class"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it may appear. This is an imperative necessity; for thus alone will it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"be possible to develop a talented body of public leaders from the class"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which represents learning that in itself is only a dead mass."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"There is still another reason why the State should provide for this"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"situation. Our intellectual class, particularly in Germany, is so shut"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"up in itself and fossilized that it lacks living contact with the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"classes beneath it. Two evil consequences result from this: First, the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual class neither understands nor sympathizes with the broad"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"masses. It has been so long cut off from all connection with them that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it cannot now have the necessary psychological ties that would enable it"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to understand them. It has become estranged from the people. Secondly,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the intellectual class lacks the necessary will-power; for this faculty"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is always weaker in cultivated circles, which live in seclusion, than"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"among the primitive masses of the people. God knows we Germans have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"never been lacking in abundant scientific culture, but we have always"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"had a considerable lack of will-power and the capacity for making"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decisions. For example, the more 'intellectual' our statesmen have been"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the more lacking they have been, for the most part, in practical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"achievement. Our political preparation and our technical equipment for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the world war were defective, certainly not because the brains governing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the nation were too little educated, but because the men who directed"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"our public affairs were over-educated, filled to over-flowing with"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"knowledge and intelligence, yet without any sound instinct and simply"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"without energy, or any spirit of daring. It was our nation's tragedy to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have to fight for its existence under a Chancellor who was a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"dillydallying philosopher. If instead of a Bethmann von Hollweg we had"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"had a rough man of the people as our leader the heroic blood of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"common grenadier would not have been shed in vain. The exaggeratedly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual material out of which our leaders were made proved to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the best ally of the scoundrels who carried out the November revolution."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"These intellectuals safeguarded the national wealth in a miserly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fashion, instead of launching it forth and risking it, and thus they set"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the conditions on which the others won success."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Here the Catholic Church presents an instructive example. Clerical"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"celibacy forces the Church to recruit its priests not from their own"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ranks but progressively from the masses of the people. Yet there are not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"many who recognize the significance of celibacy in this relation. But"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"therein lies the cause of the inexhaustible vigour which characterizes"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that ancient institution. For by thus unceasingly recruiting the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ecclesiastical dignitaries from the lower classes of the people, the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Church is enabled not only to maintain the contact of instinctive"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"understanding with the masses of the population but also to assure"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"itself of always being able to draw upon that fund of energy which is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"present in this form only among the popular masses. Hence the surprising"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"youthfulness of that gigantic organism, its mental flexibility and its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"iron will-power."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It will be the task of the Peoples' State so to organize and administer"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"its educational system that the existing intellectual class will be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"constantly furnished with a supply of fresh blood from beneath. From the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"bulk of the nation the State must sift out with careful scrutiny those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"persons who are endowed with natural talents and see that they are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"employed in the service of the community. For neither the State itself"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"nor the various departments of State exist to furnish revenues for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"members of a special class, but to fulfil the tasks allotted to them."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"This will be possible, however, only if the State trains individuals"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"specially for these offices. Such individuals must have the necessary"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"fundamental capabilities and will-power. The principle does not hold"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"true only in regard to the civil service but also in regard to all those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who are to take part in the intellectual and moral leadership of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people, no matter in what sphere they may be employed. The greatness of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"a people is partly dependent on the condition that it must succeed in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"training the best brains for those branches of the public service for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which they show a special natural aptitude and in placing them in the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"offices where they can do their best work for the good of the community."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"If two nations of equal strength and quality engage in a mutual conflict"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that nation will come out victorious which has entrusted its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"intellectual and moral leadership to its best talents and that nation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will go under whose government represents only a common food trough for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"privileged groups or classes and where the inner talents of its"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual members are not availed of."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Of course such a reform seems impossible in the world as it is to-day."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The objection will at once be raised, that it is too much to expect from"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the favourite son of a highly-placed civil servant, for instance, that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"he shall work with his hands simply because somebody else whose parents"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"belong to the working-class seems more capable for a job in the civil"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"service. That argument may be valid as long as manual work is looked"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"upon in the same way as it is looked upon to-day. Hence the Peoples'"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"State will have to take up an attitude towards the appreciation of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"manual labour which will be fundamentally different from that which now"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"exists. If necessary, it will have to organize a persistent system of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"teaching which will aim at abolishing the present-day stupid habit of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"looking down on physical labour as an occupation to be ashamed of."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The individual will have to be valued, not by the class of work he does"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but by the way in which he does it and by its usefulness to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"community. This statement may sound monstrous in an epoch when the most"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"brainless columnist on a newspaper staff is more esteemed than the most"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"expert mechanic, merely because the former pushes a pen. But, as I have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"said, this false valuation does not correspond to the nature of things."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It has been artificially introduced, and there was a time when it did"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"not exist at all. The present unnatural state of affairs is one of those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"general morbid phenomena that have arisen from our materialistic epoch."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Fundamentally every kind of work has a double value; the one material,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the other ideal. The material value depends on the practical importance"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the work to the life of the community. The greater the number of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"population who benefit from the work, directly or indirectly, the higher"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will be its material value. This evaluation is expressed in the material"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"recompense which the individual receives for his labour. In"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"contradistinction to this purely material value there is the ideal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"value. Here the work performed is not judged by its material importance"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but by the degree to which it answers a necessity. Certainly the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"material utility of an invention may be greater than that of the service"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"rendered by an everyday workman; but it is also certain that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"community needs each of those small daily services just as much as the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"greater services. From the material point of view a distinction can be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"made in the evaluation of different kinds of work according to their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"utility to the community, and this distinction is expressed by the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"differentiation in the scale of recompense; but on the ideal or abstract"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"plans all workmen become equal the moment each strives to do his best in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"his own field, no matter what that field may be. It is on this that a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"man's value must be estimated, and not on the amount of recompense"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"received."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"In a reasonably directed State care must be taken that each individual"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"is given the kind of work which corresponds to his capabilities. In"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"other words, people will be trained for the positions indicated by their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"natural endowments; but these endowments or faculties are innate and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cannot be acquired by any amount of training, being a gift from Nature"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and not merited by men. Therefore, the way in which men are generally"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"esteemed by their fellow-citizens must not be according to the kind of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"work they do, because that has been more or less assigned to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"individual. Seeing that the kind of work in which the individual is"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"employed is to be accounted to his inborn gifts and the resultant"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"training which he has received from the community, he will have to be"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"judged by the way in which he performs this work entrusted to him by the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"community. For the work which the individual performs is not the purpose"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of his existence, but only a means. His real purpose in life is to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"better himself and raise himself to a higher level as a human being; but"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this he can only do in and through the community whose cultural life he"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"shares. And this community must always exist on the foundations on which"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the State is based. He ought to contribute to the conservation of those"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"foundations. Nature determines the form of this contribution. It is the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"duty of the individual to return to the community, zealously and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"honestly, what the community has given him. He who does this deserves"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the highest respect and esteem. Material remuneration may be given to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"him whose work has a corresponding utility for the community; but the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ideal recompense must lie in the esteem to which everybody has a claim"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"who serves his people with whatever powers Nature has bestowed upon him"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and which have been developed by the training he has received from the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"national community. Then it will no longer be dishonourable to be an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"honest craftsman; but it will be a cause of disgrace to be an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"inefficient State official, wasting God's day and filching daily bread"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"from an honest public. Then it will be looked upon as quite natural that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"positions should not be given to persons who of their very nature are"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"incapable of filling them."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Furthermore, this personal efficiency will be the sole criterion of the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"right to take part on an equal juridical footing in general civil"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"affairs."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"The present epoch is working out its own ruin. It introduces universal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"suffrage, chatters about equal rights but can find no foundation for"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this equality. It considers the material wage as the expression of a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"man's value and thus destroys the basis of the noblest kind of equality"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that can exist. For equality cannot and does not depend on the work a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"man does, but only on the manner in which each one does the particular"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"work allotted to him. Thus alone will mere natural chance be set aside"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in determining the work of a man and thus only does the individual"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"become the artificer of his own social worth."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"At the present time, when whole groups of people estimate each other's"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"value only by the size of the salaries which they respectively receive,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"there will be no understanding of all this. But that is no reason why we"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"should cease to champion those ideas. Quite the opposite: in an epoch"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
