"which is inwardly diseased and decaying anyone who would heal it must"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"have the courage first to lay bare the real roots of the disease. And"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the National Socialist Movement must take that duty on its shoulders. It"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"will have to lift its voice above the heads of the small bourgeoisie and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"rally together and co-ordinate all those popular forces which are ready"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to become the protagonists of a new WELTANSCHAUUNG."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Of course the objection will be made that in general it is difficult to"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"differentiate between the material and ideal values of work and that the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"lower prestige which is attached to physical labour is due to the fact"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"that smaller wages are paid for that kind of work. It will be said that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the lower wage is in its turn the reason why the manual worker has less"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"chance to participate in the culture of the nation; so that the ideal"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"side of human culture is less open to him because it has nothing to do"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with his daily activities. It may be added that the reluctance to do"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"physical work is justified by the fact that, on account of the small"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"income, the cultural level of manual labourers must naturally be low,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and that this in turn is a justification for the lower estimation in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"which manual labour is generally held."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"There is quite a good deal of truth in all this. But that is the very"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"reason why we ought to see that in the future there should not be such a"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"wide difference in the scale of remuneration. Don't say that under such"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"conditions poorer work would be done. It would be the saddest symptom of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"decadence if finer intellectual work could be obtained only through the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"stimulus of higher payment. If that point of view had ruled the world up"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"to now humanity would never have acquired its greatest scientific and"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"cultural heritage. For all the greatest inventions, the greatest"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"discoveries, the most profoundly revolutionary scientific work, and the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"most magnificent monuments of human culture, were never given to the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"world under the impulse or compulsion of money. Quite the contrary: not"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"rarely was their origin associated with a renunciation of the worldly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"pleasures that wealth can purchase."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It may be that money has become the one power that governs life to-day."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Yet a time will come when men will again bow to higher gods. Much that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"we have to-day owes its existence to the desire for money and property;"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"but there is very little among all this which would leave the world"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"poorer by its lack."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"It is also one of the aims before our movement to hold out the prospect"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of a time when the individual will be given what he needs for the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"purposes of his life and it will be a time in which, on the other hand,"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the principle will be upheld that man does not live for material"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"enjoyment alone. This principle will find expression in a wiser scale of"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"wages and salaries which will enable everyone, including the humblest"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"workman who fulfils his duties conscientiously, to live an honourable"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"and decent life both as a man and as a citizen. Let it not be said that"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"this is merely a visionary ideal, that this world would never tolerate"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"it in practice and that of itself it is impossible to attain."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Even we are not so simple as to believe that there will ever be an age"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"in which there will be no drawbacks. But that does not release us from"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the obligation to fight for the removal of the defects which we have"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"recognized, to overcome the shortcomings and to strive towards the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ideal. In any case the hard reality of the facts to be faced will always"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"place only too many limits to our aspirations. But that is precisely why"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"man must strive again and again to serve the ultimate aim and no"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"failures must induce him to renounce his intentions, just as we cannot"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spurn the sway of justice because mistakes creep into the administration"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"of the law, and just as we cannot despise medical science because, in"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"spite of it, there will always be diseases."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"Man should take care not to have too low an estimate of the power of an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"ideal. If there are some who may feel disheartened over the present"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"conditions, and if they happen to have served as soldiers, I would"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"remind them of the time when their heroism was the most convincing"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"example of the power inherent in ideal motives. It was not preoccupation"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"about their daily bread that led men to sacrifice their lives, but the"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"love of their country, the faith which they had in its greatness, and an"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"all round feeling for the honour of the nation. Only after the German"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"people had become estranged from these ideals, to follow the material"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"promises offered by the Revolution, only after they threw away their"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"arms to take up the rucksack, only then--instead of entering an earthly"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"paradise--did they sink into the purgatory of universal contempt and at"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"the same time universal want."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"That is why we must face the calculators of the materialist Republic"	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"with faith in an idealist REICH."	"CHAPTER XIV   THE STATE"
"CHAPTER XV"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"CITIZENS AND SUBJECTS OF THE STATE"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The institution that is now erroneously called the State generally"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"classifies people only into two groups: citizens and aliens. Citizens"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"are all those who possess full civic rights, either by reason of their"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"birth or by an act of naturalization. Aliens are those who enjoy the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"same rights in some other State. Between these two categories there are"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"certain beings who resemble a sort of meteoric phenomena. They are"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"people who have no citizenship in any State and consequently no civic"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"rights anywhere."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"In most cases nowadays a person acquires civic rights by being born"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"within the frontiers of a State. The race or nationality to which he may"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"belong plays no role whatsoever. The child of a Negro who once lived in"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"one of the German protectorates and now takes up his residence in"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Germany automatically becomes a 'German Citizen' in the eyes of the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"world. In the same way the child of any Jew, Pole, African or Asian may"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"automatically become a German Citizen."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Besides naturalization that is acquired through the fact of having been"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"born within the confines of a State there exists another kind of"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"naturalization which can be acquired later. This process is subject to"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"various preliminary requirements. For example one condition is that, if"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"possible, the applicant must not be a burglar or a common street thug."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"It is required of him that his political attitude is not such as to give"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"cause for uneasiness; in other words he must be a harmless simpleton in"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"politics. It is required that he shall not be a burden to the State of"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"which he wishes to become a citizen. In this realistic epoch of ours"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"this last condition naturally only means that he must not be a financial"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"burden. If the affairs of the candidate are such that it appears likely"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"he will turn out to be a good taxpayer, that is a very important"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"consideration and will help him to obtain civic rights all the more"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"rapidly."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The question of race plays no part at all."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The whole process of acquiring civic rights is not very different from"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"that of being admitted to membership of an automobile club, for"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"instance. A person files his application. It is examined. It is"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"sanctioned. And one day the man receives a card which informs him that"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"he has become a citizen. The information is given in an amusing way. An"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"applicant who has hitherto been a Zulu or Kaffir is told: By these
presents you are now become a German Citizen."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The President of the State can perform this piece of magic. What God"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Himself could not do is achieved by some Theophrastus Paracelsus (Note 16)"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"of a civil servant through a mere twirl of the hand. Nothing but a stroke"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"of the pen, and a Mongolian slave is forthwith turned into a real"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"German. Not only is no question asked regarding the race to which the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"new citizen belongs; even the matter of his physical health is not"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"inquired into. His flesh may be corrupted with syphilis; but he will"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"still be welcome in the State as it exists to-day so long as he may not"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"become a financial burden or a political danger."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"[Note 16. The last and most famous of the medieval alchemists. He was born"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"at Basleabout the year 1490 and died at Salzburg in 1541. He taught that"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"all metals could be transmuted through the action of one primary element"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"common to them all. This element he called ALCAHEST. If it could be found"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"it would proveto be at once the philosopher's stone, the universal"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"medicine and their resistible solvent. There are many aspects of his"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"teaching which are now looked upon as by no means so fantastic as they"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"were considered in his own time.]"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"In this way, year after year, those organisms which we call States take"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"up poisonous matter which they can hardly ever overcome."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Another point of distinction between a citizen and an alien is that the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"former is admitted to all public offices, that he may possibly have to"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"do military service and that in return he is permitted to take a passive"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"or active part at public elections. Those are his chief privileges. For"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"in regard to personal rights and personal liberty the alien enjoys the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"same amount of protection as the citizen, and frequently even more."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Anyhow that is how it happens in our present German Republic."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"I realize fully that nobody likes to hear these things. But it would be"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"difficult to find anything more illogical or more insane than our"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"contemporary laws in regard to State citizenship."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"At present there exists one State which manifests at least some modest"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"attempts that show a better appreciation of how things ought to be done"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"in this matter. It is not, however, in our model German Republic but in"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the U.S.A. that efforts are made to conform at least partly to the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"counsels of commonsense. By refusing immigrants to enter there if they"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"are in a bad state of health, and by excluding certain races from the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"right to become naturalized as citizens, they have begun to introduce"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"principles similar to those on which we wish to ground the People's"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"State."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The People's State will classify its population in three groups:"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Citizens, subjects of the State, and aliens."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The principle is that birth within the confines of the State gives only"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the status of a subject. It does not carry with it the right to fill any"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"position under the State or to participate in political life, such as"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"taking an active or passive part in elections. Another principle is that"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the race and nationality of every subject of the State will have to be"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"proved. A subject is at any time free to cease being a subject and to"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"become a citizen of that country to which he belongs in virtue of his"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"nationality. The only difference between an alien and a subject of the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"State is that the former is a citizen of another country."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The young boy or girl who is of German nationality and is a subject of"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the German State is bound to complete the period of school education"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"which is obligatory for every German. Thereby he submits to the system"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"of training which will make him conscious of his race and a member of"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the folk-community. Then he has to fulfil all those requirements laid"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"down by the State in regard to physical training after he has left"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"school; and finally he enters the army. The training in the army is of a"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"general kind. It must be given to each individual German and will render"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"him competent to fulfil the physical and mental requirements of military"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"service. The rights of citizenship shall be conferred on every young man"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"whose health and character have been certified as good, after having"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"completed his period of military service. This act of inauguration in"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"citizenship shall be a solemn ceremony. And the diploma conferring the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"rights of citizenship will be preserved by the young man as the most"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"precious testimonial of his whole life. It entitles him to exercise all"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the rights of a citizen and to enjoy all the privileges attached"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"thereto. For the State must draw a sharp line of distinction between"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"those who, as members of the nation, are the foundation and the support"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"of its existence and greatness, and those who are domiciled in the State"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"simply as earners of their livelihood there."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"On the occasion of conferring a diploma of citizenship the new citizen"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"must take a solemn oath of loyalty to the national community and the"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"State. This diploma must be a bond which unites together all the various"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"classes and sections of the nation. It shall be a greater honour to be a"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"citizen of this REICH, even as a street-sweeper, than to be the King of"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"a foreign State."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The citizen has privileges which are not accorded to the alien. He is"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"the master in the REICH. But this high honour has also its obligations."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"Those who show themselves without personal honour or character, or"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"common criminals, or traitors to the fatherland, can at any time be"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"deprived of the rights of citizenship. Therewith they become merely"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"subjects of the State."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"The German girl is a subject of the State but will become a citizen when"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"she marries. At the same time those women who earn their livelihood"	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"

"subjects."	"CHAPTER XVI   PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE`S STATE"
"CHAPTER XVI"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"PERSONALITY AND THE IDEAL OF THE PEOPLE'S STATE"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"If the principal duty of the National Socialist People's State be to"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"educate and promote the existence of those who are the material out of"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"which the State is formed, it will not be sufficient to promote those"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"racial elements as such, educate them and finally train them for"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"practical life, but the State must also adapt its own organization to"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"meet the demands of this task."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"It would be absurd to appraise a man's worth by the race to which he"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"belongs and at the same time to make war against the Marxist principle,"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"that all men are equal, without being determined to pursue our own"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"principle to its ultimate consequences. If we admit the significance of"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"blood, that is to say, if we recognize the race as the fundamental"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"element on which all life is based, we shall have to apply to the"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"individual the logical consequences of this principle. In general I must"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"estimate the worth of nations differently, on the basis of the different"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"races from which they spring, and I must also differentiate in"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"estimating the worth of the individual within his own race. The"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"principle, that one people is not the same as another, applies also to"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"the individual members of a national community. No one brain, for"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"instance, is equal to another; because the constituent elements"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"belonging to the same blood vary in a thousand subtle details, though"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"they are fundamentally of the same quality."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"The first consequence of this fact is comparatively simple. It demands"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"that those elements within the folk-community which show the best racial"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"qualities ought to be encouraged more than the others and especially"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"they should be encouraged to increase and multiply."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"This task is comparatively simple because it can be recognized and"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"carried out almost mechanically. It is much more difficult to select"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"from among a whole multitude of people all those who actually possess"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"the highest intellectual and spiritual characteristics and assign them"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"to that sphere of influence which not only corresponds to their"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"outstanding talents but in which their activities will above all things"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"be of benefit to the nation. This selection according to capacity and"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"efficiency cannot be effected in a mechanical way. It is a work which"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"can be accomplished only through the permanent struggle of everyday life"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"itself."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"A WELTANSCHAUUNG which repudiates the democratic principle of the rule"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"of the masses and aims at giving this world to the best people--that"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"is, to the highest quality of mankind--must also apply that same"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"aristocratic postulate to the individuals within the folk-community. It"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"must take care that the positions of leadership and highest influence"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"are given to the best men. Hence it is not based on the idea of the"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"majority, but on that of personality."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"Anyone who believes that the People's National Socialist State should"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"distinguish itself from the other States only mechanically, as it were,"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"

"external reforms would not have the slightest chance of success in the"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"general struggle for life among the nations of the world. A movement"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"

"which we are suffering to-day."	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"
"In order to elucidate this point of view it may be worth while to glance"	"CHAPTER XVII    WELTANSCHAUUNG AND ORGANIZATION"

"In speaking of a co-operative union we generally mean a group of"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"associations which, for the purpose of facilitating their work,"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"discovered a common platform on which they can stand united and have"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"eliminated all grounds of mutual difference. Therewith a general"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"conviction arises, to the effect that such a union is an immense gain in"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"association and it would be more reasonable if there were not a number"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"who--as experience has shown--are most emphatic in proclaiming the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"necessity of union and unity the moment they find they cannot catch up"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"with their adversary's advance."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"It is to that kind of conduct that the so-called 'patriotic"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"disintegration' is to be attributed."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"Certainly in the years 1918--1919 the founding of a multitude of new"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"groups, parties, etc., calling themselves 'Patriotic,' was a natural"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"phenomenon of the time, for which the founders were not at all"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"responsible. By 1920 the National Socialist German Labour Party had"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"slowly crystallized from all these parties and had become supreme. There"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"could be no better proof of the sterling honesty of certain individual"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"founders than the fact that many of them decided, in a really admirable"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"manner, to sacrifice their manifestly less successful movements to the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"stronger movement, by joining it unconditionally and dissolving their"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"own."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"This is specially true in regard to Julius Streicher, who was at that"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"time the protagonist of the German Socialist party in NÃ¼rnberg. The"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"National Socialist German Labour Party had been founded with similar"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"aims in view, but quite independently of the other. I have already said"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"that Streicher, then a teacher in NÃ¼rnberg, was the chief protagonist of"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"the German Socialist Party. He had a sacred conviction of the mission"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"and future of his own movement. As soon, however, as the superior"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"from the mutual contest, and carry on the fight within its ranks for the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"common cause. The decision was personally a difficult one for him, but"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"it showed a profound sense of honesty."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"When that first period of the movement was over there remained no"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"further dispersion of forces: for their honest intentions had led the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"still less any concept of aims to be pursued, felt themselves 'called'"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"German Labour Party became unquestionable."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"motive was the personal ambition of the founders, who wished to play a"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"At that time there was not an idea or concept launched by other people"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"When that did not succeed, and the new enterprises, thanks to the paltry"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"one of those co-operative unions, believing that eight lame people"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"was practically paralysed."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"We ought to look upon the question of joining these working coalitions"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"as a tactical problem, but, in coming to a decision, we must never"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"forget the following fundamental principle:"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"Through the formation of a working coalition associations which are weak"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"in themselves can never be made strong, whereas it can and does happen"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"not infrequently that a strong association loses its strength by joining"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"in a coalition with weaker ones. It is a mistake to believe that a"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"because experience shows that under all forms and all conditions the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"Through such a coalition the free play of forces is paralysed, the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"struggle for the selection of the best is abolished and therewith the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"necessary and final victory of the healthier and stronger is impeded."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"Coalitions of that kind are inimical to the process of natural"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"development, because for the most part they hinder rather than advance"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"the solution of the problem which is being fought for."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"It may happen that, from considerations of a purely tactical kind, the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"supreme command of a movement whose goal is set in the future will enter"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"questions and may also stand on a common platform with them, but this"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"permanent, if the movement does not wish to renounce its liberating"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"mission. Because if it should become indissolubly tied up in such a"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"forces to work freely in following out a natural development, so as to"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"overcome rivals and attain its own objective triumphantly."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"It must never be forgotten that nothing really great in this world has"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"ever been achieved through coalitions, but that such achievements have"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"always been due to the triumph of the individual. Successes achieved"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"through coalitions, owing to the very nature of their source, carry the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"that they have already forfeited what has been achieved. The great"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"

"individual natures, but never as the enterprises of coalitions."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"And, above all things, the People's State will never be created by the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"desire for compromise inherent in a patriotic coalition, but only by the"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"iron will of a single movement which has successfully come through in"	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"the struggle with all the others."	"CHAPTER XX THE STRONG IS STRONGEST WHEN ALONE"
"CHAPTER XXI"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"The strength of the old state rested on three pillars: the monarchical"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"form of government, the civil service, and the army. The Revolution of"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"1918 abolished the form of government, dissolved the army and abandoned"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"the civil service to the corruption of party politics. Thus the"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"essential supports of what is called the Authority of the State were"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"shattered. This authority nearly always depends on three elements, which"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"are the essential foundations of all authority."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"Popular support is the first element which is necessary for the creation"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"of authority. But an authority resting on that foundation alone is still"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"quite frail, uncertain and vacillating. Hence everyone who finds himself"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"vested with an authority that is based only on popular support must take"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"measures to improve and consolidate the foundations of that authority by"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"the creation of force. Accordingly we must look upon power, that is to"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"say, the capacity to use force, as the second foundation on which all"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"authority is based. This foundation is more stable and secure, but not"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"always stronger, than the first. If popular support and power are united"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"together and can endure for a certain time, then an authority may arise"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"which is based on a still stronger foundation, namely, the authority of"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"tradition. And, finally, if popular support, power, and tradition are"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"united together, then the authority based on them may be looked upon as"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"invincible."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"In Germany the Revolution abolished this last foundation. There was no"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"longer even a traditional authority. With the collapse of the old REICH,"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"the suppression of the monarchical form of government, the destruction"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"of all the old insignia of greatness and the imperial symbols, tradition"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"was shattered at a blow. The result was that the authority of the State"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"was shaken to its foundations."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"The second pillar of statal authority, namely POWER, also ceased to"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"exist. In order to carry through the Revolution it was necessary to"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"dissolve that body which had hitherto incorporated the organized force"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"and power of the State, namely, the Army. Indeed, some detached"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"fragments of the Army itself had to be employed as fighting elements in"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"the Revolution. The Armies at the front were not subjected in the same"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"measure to this process of disruption; but as they gradually left"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"farther behind them the fields of glory on which they had fought"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"heroically for four-and-half years, they were attacked by the solvent"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"revolutionary leaders were forced to strengthen statal authority by"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"creating a new factor of power. In the conditions that existed they"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"could do this only by winning over to their side the adherents of a"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"WELTANSCHAUUNG which was a direct contradiction of their own. From"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"limited numerically by the peace treaties, had to be subsequently"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"transformed in spirit so as to become an instrument of the new regime."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"Setting aside the defects of the old State, which really became the"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"cause of the Revolution, if we ask how it was possible to carry the"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"Revolution to a successful issue as a political act, we arrive at the"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"following conclusions:"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"l. It was due to a process of dry rot in our conceptions of duty and"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"obedience."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"2. It was due also to the passive timidity of the Parties who were"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"supposed to uphold the State."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"To this the following must be added: The dry rot which attacked our"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"concepts of duty and obedience was fundamentally due to our wholly"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"non-national and purely State education. From this came the habit of"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"confusing means and ends. Consciousness of duty, fulfilment of duty, and"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"obedience, are not ends in themselves no more than the State is an end"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"in itself; but they all ought to be employed as means to facilitate and"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"assure the existence of a community of people who are kindred both"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"physically and spiritually. At a moment when a nation is manifestly"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"collapsing and when all outward signs show that it is on the point of"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"becoming the victim of ruthless oppression, thanks to the conduct of a"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"few miscreants, to obey these people and fulfil one's duty towards them"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"is merely doctrinaire formalism, and indeed pure folly; whereas, on the"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"other hand, the refusal of obedience and fulfilment of duty in such a"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"case might save the nation from collapse. According to our current"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"bourgeois idea of the State, if a divisional general received from above"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"the order not to shoot he fulfilled his duty and therefore acted rightly"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"personal responsibility towards the whole nation makes its appearance."	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"The Revolution succeeded because that concept had ceased to be a vital"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"force with our people, or rather with our governments, and died down to"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"guaranteed the internal solidity of his position and enabled him to"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"maintain his fearful oppression. In such cases a man may suddenly arise"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"[Note 20. Schiller, who wrote the famous drama of WILLIAM TELL.]"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"
"During 1919 and 1920 there was danger that the members of secret"	"CHAPTER XXI   FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS REGARDING THE NATURE AND ORGANIZATION OF THE STORM TROOPS"

"THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"In the winter of 1919, and still more in the spring and summer of 1920,"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"the young Party felt bound to take up a definite stand on a question"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"which already had become quite serious during the War. In the first"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"volume of this book I have briefly recorded certain facts which I had"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"personally witnessed and which foreboded the break-up of Germany. In"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"describing these facts I made reference to the special nature of the"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"propaganda which was directed by the English as well as the French"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"towards reopening the breach that had existed between North and South in"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Germany. In the spring of 1915 there appeared the first of a series of"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"leaflets which was systematically followed up and the aim of which was"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"to arouse feeling against Prussia as being solely responsible for the"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"war. Up to 1916 this system had been developed and perfected in a"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"cunning and shameless manner. Appealing to the basest of human"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"instincts, this propaganda endeavoured to arouse the wrath of the South"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Germans against the North Germans and after a short time it bore fruit."	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Persons who were then in high positions under the Government and in the"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Army, especially those attached to headquarters in the Bavarian Army,"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"merited the just reproof of having blindly neglected their duty and"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"failed to take the necessary steps to counter such propaganda. But"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"nothing was done. On the contrary, in some quarters it did not appear to"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"be quite unwelcome and probably they were short-sighted enough to think"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"that such propaganda might help along the development of unification in"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Germany but even that it might automatically bring about consolidation"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"of the federative forces. Scarcely ever in history was such a wicked"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"neglect more wickedly avenged. The weakening of Prussia, which they"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"believed would result from this propaganda, affected the whole of"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Germany. It resulted in hastening the collapse which not only wrecked"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"Germany as a whole but even more particularly the federal states."	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"In that town where the artificially created hatred against Prussia raged"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"most violently the revolt against the reigning House was the beginning"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"of the Revolution."	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"
"It would be a mistake to think that the enemy propaganda was exclusively"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"

"The army must definitely be kept clear of the influence of the"	"CHAPTER XXII   THE MASK OF FEDERALISM"

"CHAPTER XXIII"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The year 1921 was specially important for me from many points of view."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"When I entered the German Labour Party I at once took charge of the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"propaganda, believing this branch to be far the most important for the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"time being. Just then it was not a matter of pressing necessity to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"cudgel one's brains over problems of organization. The first necessity"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"was to spread our ideas among as many people as possible. Propaganda"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"should go well ahead of organization and gather together the human"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"material for the latter to work up. I have never been in favour of hasty"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"and pedantic methods of organization, because in most cases the result"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"is merely a piece of dead mechanism and only rarely a living"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organization. Organization is a thing that derives its existence from"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organic life, organic evolution. When the same set of ideas have found a"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"lodgement in the minds of a certain number of people they tend of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"themselves to form a certain degree of order among those people and out"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"of this inner formation something that is very valuable arises. Of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"course here, as everywhere else, one must take account of those human"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"weaknesses which make men hesitate, especially at the beginning, to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"submit to the control of a superior mind. If an organization is imposed"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"from above downwards in a mechanical fashion, there is always the danger"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"that some individual may push himself forward who is not known for what"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"he is and who, out of jealousy, will try to hinder abler persons from"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"taking a leading place in the movement. The damage that results from"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"that kind of thing may have fatal consequences, especially in a new"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"movement."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"For this reason it is advisable first to propagate and publicly expound"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the ideas on which the movement is founded. This work of propaganda"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"should continue for a certain time and should be directed from one"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"centre. When the ideas have gradually won over a number of people this"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"human material should be carefully sifted for the purpose of selecting"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"those who have ability in leadership and putting that ability to the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"test. It will often be found that apparently insignificant persons will"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"nevertheless turn out to be born leaders."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Of course, it is quite a mistake to suppose that those who show a very"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"intelligent grasp of the theory underlying a movement are for that"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"reason qualified to fill responsible positions on the directorate. The"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"contrary is very frequently the case."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Great masters of theory are only very rarely great organizers also. And"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"this is because the greatness of the theorist and founder of a system"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"consists in being able to discover and lay down those laws that are"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"right in the abstract, whereas the organizer must first of all be a man"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"of psychological insight. He must take men as they are, and for that"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"reason he must know them, not having too high or too low an estimate of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"human nature. He must take account of their weaknesses, their baseness"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"and all the other various characteristics, so as to form something out"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"of them which will be a living organism, endowed with strong powers of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"resistance, fitted to be the carrier of an idea and strong enough to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"ensure the triumph of that idea."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"But it is still more rare to find a great theorist who is at the same"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"time a great leader. For the latter must be more of an agitator, a truth"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"that will not be readily accepted by many of those who deal with"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"problems only from the scientific standpoint. And yet what I say is only"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"natural. For an agitator who shows himself capable of expounding ideas"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"to the great masses must always be a psychologist, even though he may be"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"only a demagogue. Therefore he will always be a much more capable leader"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"than the contemplative theorist who meditates on his ideas, far from the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"human throng and the world. For to be a leader means to be able to move"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the masses. The gift of formulating ideas has nothing whatsoever to do"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"with the capacity for leadership. It would be entirely futile to discuss"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the question as to which is the more important: the faculty of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"conceiving ideals and human aims or that of being able to have them put"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"into practice. Here, as so often happens in life, the one would be"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"entirely meaningless without the other. The noblest conceptions of the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"human understanding remain without purpose or value if the leader cannot"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"move the masses towards them. And, conversely, what would it avail to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"have all the genius and elan of a leader if the intellectual theorist"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"does not fix the aims for which mankind must struggle. But when the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"abilities of theorist and organizer and leader are united in the one"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"person, then we have the rarest phenomenon on this earth. And it is that"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"union which produces the great man."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"As I have already said, during my first period in the Party I devoted"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"myself to the work of propaganda. I had to succeed in gradually"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"gathering together a small nucleus of men who would accept the new"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"teaching and be inspired by it. And in this way we should provide the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"human material which subsequently would form the constituent elements of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the organization. Thus the goal of the propagandist is nearly always"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"fixed far beyond that of the organizer."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"If a movement proposes to overthrow a certain order of things and"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"construct a new one in its place, then the following principles must be"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"clearly understood and must dominate in the ranks of its leadership:"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Every movement which has gained its human material must first divide"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"this material into two groups: namely, followers and members."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"It is the task of the propagandist to recruit the followers and it is"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the task of the organizer to select the members."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The follower of a movement is he who understands and accepts its aims;"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the member is he who fights for them."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The follower is one whom the propaganda has converted to the doctrine of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the movement. The member is he who will be charged by the organization"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"to collaborate in winning over new followers from which in turn new"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"members can be formed."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"To be a follower needs only the passive recognition of the idea. To be a"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"member means to represent that idea and fight for it. From ten followers"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"one can have scarcely more than two members. To be a follower simply"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"implies that a man has accepted the teaching of the movement; whereas to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"be a member means that a man has the courage to participate actively in"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"diffusing that teaching in which he has come to believe."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Because of its passive character, the simple effort of believing in a"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"political doctrine is enough for the majority, for the majority of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"mankind is mentally lazy and timid. To be a member one must be"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"intellectually active, and therefore this applies only to the minority."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Such being the case, the propagandist must seek untiringly to acquire"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"new followers for the movement, whereas the organizer must diligently"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"look out for the best elements among such followers, so that these"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"elements may be transformed into members. The propagandist need not"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"trouble too much about the personal worth of the individual proselytes"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"he has won for the movement. He need not inquire into their abilities,"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"their intelligence or character. From these proselytes, however, the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organizer will have to select those individuals who are most capable of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"actively helping to bring the movement to victory."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The propagandist aims at inducing the whole people to accept his"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"teaching. The organizer includes in his body of membership only those"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"who, on psychological grounds, will not be an impediment to the further"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"diffusion of the doctrines of the movement."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The propagandist inculcates his doctrine among the masses, with the idea"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"of preparing them for the time when this doctrine will triumph, through"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the body of combatant members which he has formed from those followers"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"who have given proof of the necessary ability and will-power to carry"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the struggle to victory."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The final triumph of a doctrine will be made all the more easy if the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"propagandist has effectively converted large bodies of men to the belief"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"in that doctrine and if the organization that actively conducts the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"fight be exclusive, vigorous and solid."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"When the propaganda work has converted a whole people to believe in a"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"doctrine, the organization can turn the results of this into practical"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"effect through the work of a mere handful of men. Propaganda and"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organization, therefore follower and member, then stand towards one"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"another in a definite mutual relationship. The better the propaganda has"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"worked, the smaller will the organization be. The greater the number of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"followers, so much the smaller can be the number of members. And"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"conversely. If the propaganda be bad, the organization must be large."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"And if there be only a small number of followers, the membership must be"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"all the larger--if the movement really counts on being successful."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The first duty of the propagandist is to win over people who can"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"subsequently be taken into the organization. And the first duty of the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organization is to select and train men who will be capable of carrying"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"on the propaganda. The second duty of the organization is to disrupt the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"existing order of things and thus make room for the penetration of the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"new teaching which it represents, while the duty of the organizer must"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"be to fight for the purpose of securing power, so that the doctrine may"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"finally triumph."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"A revolutionary conception of the world and human existence will always"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"achieve decisive success when the new WELTANSCHAUUNG has been taught to"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"a whole people, or subsequently forced upon them if necessary, and when,"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"on the other hand, the central organization, the movement itself, is in"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the hands of only those few men who are absolutely indispensable to form"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the nerve-centres of the coming State."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Put in another way, this means that in every great revolutionary"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"movement that is of world importance the idea of this movement must"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"always be spread abroad through the operation of propaganda. The"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"propagandist must never tire in his efforts to make the new ideas"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"clearly understood, inculcating them among others, or at least he must"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"place himself in the position of those others and endeavour to upset"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"their confidence in the convictions they have hitherto held. In order"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"that such propaganda should have backbone to it, it must be based on an"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organization. The organization chooses its members from among those"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"followers whom the propaganda has won. That organization will become all"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the more vigorous if the work of propaganda be pushed forward"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"intensively. And the propaganda will work all the better when the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"organization back of it is vigorous and strong in itself."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Hence the supreme task of the organizer is to see to it that any discord"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"or differences which may arise among the members of the movement will"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"not lead to a split and thereby cramp the work within the movement."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Moreover, it is the duty of the organization to see that the fighting"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"spirit of the movement does not flag or die out but that it is"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"constantly reinvigorated and restrengthened. It is not necessary the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"number of members should increase indefinitely. Quite the contrary would"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"be better. In view of the fact that only a fraction of humanity has"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"energy and courage, a movement which increases its own organization"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"indefinitely must of necessity one day become plethoric and inactive."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Organizations, that is to say, groups of members, which increase their"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"size beyond certain dimensions gradually lose their fighting force and"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"are no longer in form to back up the propagation of a doctrine with"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"aggressive elan and determination."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"Now the greater and more revolutionary a doctrine is, so much the more"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"active will be the spirit inspiring its body of members, because the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"subversive energy of such a doctrine will frighten way the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"chicken-hearted and small-minded bourgeoisie. In their hearts they may"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"believe in the doctrine but they are afraid to acknowledge their belief"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"openly. By reason of this very fact, however, an organization inspired"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"by a veritable revolutionary idea will attract into the body of its"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"membership only the most active of those believers who have been won for"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"success of the idea on which the movement is based."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The greatest danger that can threaten a movement is an abnormal increase"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"It is on these grounds that we are to explain why so many movements"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"Subsequently the party bought it by paying for it in installments. We"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"needed a small safe in order to keep our papers and register of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"membership from danger of being stolen--not to guard our funds, which"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"did not then exist. On the contrary, our financial position was so"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"miserable that I often had to dip my hand into my own personal savings."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"After eighteen months our business quarters had become too small, so we"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"In December 1920, we acquired the VÃLKISCHER BEOBACHTER. This newspaper"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"which, as its name implies, championed the claims of the people, was now"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"to become the organ of the German National Socialist Labour Party. At"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"As a complete novice in journalism I then learned many a lesson for"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"which I had to pay dearly."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"In contradistinction to the enormous number of papers in Jewish hands,"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"there was at that time only one important newspaper that defended the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"cause of the people. This was a matter for grave consideration. As I"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"have often learned by experience, the reason for that state of things"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"must be attributed to the incompetent way in which the business side of"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"the so-called popular newspapers was managed. These were conducted too"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"much according to the rule that opinion should prevail over action that"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"produces results. Quite a wrong standpoint, for opinion is of itself"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"something internal and finds its best expression in productive activity."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The man who does valuable work for his people expresses thereby his"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"excellent sentiments, whereas another who merely talks about his"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"opinions and does nothing that is of real value or use to the people is"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"a person who perverts all right thinking. And that attitude of his is"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"also pernicious for the community."	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"The VÃLKISCHE BEOBACHTER was a so-called 'popular' organ, as its name"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
"indicated. It had all the good qualities, but still more the errors and"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"

"I took care to alter those conditions promptly, for I recognized the"	"CHAPTER XXIII   PROPAGANDA AND ORGANIZATION"
