"CHAPTER XXIV"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"Owing to the rapid growth of the movement, in 1922 we felt compelled to"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"take a definite stand on a question which has not been fully solved even"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"yet."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"In our efforts to discover the quickest and easiest way for the movement"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"to reach the heart of the broad masses we were always confronted with"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"the objection that the worker could never completely belong to us while"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"his interests in the purely vocational and economic sphere were cared"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"for by a political organization conducted by men whose principles were"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"quite different from ours."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"That was quite a serious objection. The general belief was that a"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"workman engaged in some trade or other could not exist if he did not"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"belong to a trade union. Not only were his professional interests thus"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"protected but a guarantee of permanent employment was simply"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"inconceivable without membership in a trade union. The majority of the"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"workers were in the trades unions. Generally speaking, the unions had"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"successfully conducted the battle for the establishment of a definite"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"scale of wages and had concluded agreements which guaranteed the worker"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"a steady income. Undoubtedly the workers in the various trades benefited"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"by the results of that campaign and, for honest men especially,"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"conflicts of conscience must have arisen if they took the wages which"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"had been assured through the struggle fought by the trades unions and if"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"at the same time the men themselves withdrew from the fight."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"It was difficult to discuss this problem with the average bourgeois"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"employer. He had no understanding (or did not wish to have any) for"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"either the material or moral side of the question. Finally he declared"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"that his own economic interests were in principle opposed to every kind"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"of organization which joined together the workmen that were dependent on"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"him. Hence it was for the most part impossible to bring these bourgeois"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"employers to take an impartial view of the situation. Here, therefore,"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"as in so many other cases, it was necessary to appeal to disinterested"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"outsiders who would not be subject to the temptation of fixing their"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"attention on the trees and failing to see the forest. With a little good"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"will on their part, they could much more easily understand a state of"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"affairs which is of the highest importance for our present and future"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"existence."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"In the first volume of this book I have already expressed my views on"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"the nature and purpose and necessity of trade unions. There I took up"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"the standpoint that unless measures are undertaken by the State (usually"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"futile in such cases) or a new ideal is introduced in our education,"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"which would change the attitude of the employer towards the worker, no"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"other course would be open to the latter except to defend his own"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"interests himself by appealing to his equal rights as a contracting"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"party within the economic sphere of the nation's existence. I stated"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"further that this would conform to the interests of the national"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"community if thereby social injustices could be redressed which"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"otherwise would cause serious damage to the whole social structure. I"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"stated, moreover, that the worker would always find it necessary to"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"undertake this protective action as long as there were men among the"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"employers who had no sense of their social obligations nor even of the"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"most elementary human rights. And I concluded by saying that if such"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"self-defence be considered necessary its form ought to be that of an"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"association made up of the workers themselves on the basis of trades"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"unions."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"This was my general idea and it remained the same in 1922. But a clear"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"and precise formula was still to be discovered. We could not be"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"satisfied with merely understanding the problem. It was necessary to"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"come to some conclusions that could be put into practice. The following"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"questions had to be answered:"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"(1) Are trade unions necessary?"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"(2) Should the German National Socialist Labour Party itself operate on"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"a trade unionist basis or have its members take part in trade unionist"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"activities in some form or other?"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"(3) What form should a National Socialist Trades Union take? What are"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"the tasks confronting us and the ends we must try to attain?"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"(4) How can we establish trade unions for such tasks and aims?"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"I think that I have already answered the first question adequately. In"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"the present state of affairs I am convinced that we cannot possibly"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"dispense with the trades unions. On the contrary, they are among the"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"most important institutions in the economic life of the nation. Not only"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"are they important in the sphere of social policy but also, and even"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"more so, in the national political sphere. For when the great masses of"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"a nation see their vital needs satisfied through a just trade unionist"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"movement the stamina of the whole nation in its struggle for existence"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"will be enormously reinforced thereby."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"Before everything else, the trades unions are necessary as building"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"stones for the future economic parliament, which will be made up of"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"chambers representing the various professions and occupations."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"The second question is also easy to answer. If the trade unionist"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"movement is important, then it is clear that National Socialism ought to"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"take a definite stand on that question, not only theoretically but also"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"in practice. But how? That is more difficult to see clearly."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"

"To-day we have a classical example of how the active strength of a"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"

"ideological aims. It may then easily happen that trade unionist"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"

"the trades unions are to take."	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"
"The movement and the nation can derive advantage from a National"	"CHAPTER XXIV  THE PROBLEM OF THE TRADE UNIONS"

"CHAPTER XXV"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"The erratic manner in which the foreign affairs of the REICH were"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"conducted was due to a lack of sound guiding principles for the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"formation of practical and useful alliances. Not only was this state of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"affairs continued after the Revolution, but it became even worse."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"For the confused state of our political ideas in general before the War"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"may be looked upon as the chief cause of our defective statesmanship;"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"but in the post-War period this cause must be attributed to a lack of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"honest intentions. It was natural that those parties who had fully"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"achieved their destructive purpose by means of the Revolution should"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"feel that it would not serve their interests if a policy of alliances"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"were adopted which must ultimately result in the restoration of a free"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"German State. A development in this direction would not be in conformity"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"with the purposes of the November crime. It would have interrupted and"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"indeed put an end to the internationalization of German national economy"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"and German Labour. But what was feared most of all was that a successful"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"effort to make the REICH independent of foreign countries might have an"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"influence in domestic politics which one day would turn out disastrous"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"for those who now hold supreme power in the government of the REICH. One"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"cannot imagine the revival of a nation unless that revival be preceded"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"by a process of nationalization. Conversely, every important success in"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"the field of foreign politics must call forth a favourable reaction at"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"home. Experience proves that every struggle for liberty increases the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"national sentiment and national self-consciousness and therewith gives"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"rise to a keener sensibility towards anti-national elements and"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"tendencies. A state of things, and persons also, that may be tolerated"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"and even pass unnoticed in times of peace will not only become the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"object of aversion when national enthusiasm is aroused but will even"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"provoke positive opposition, which frequently turns out disastrous for"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"them. In this connection we may recall the spy-scare that became"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"prevalent when the war broke out, when human passion suddenly manifested"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"itself to such a heightened degree as to lead to the most brutal"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"persecutions, often without any justifiable grounds, although everybody"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"knew that the danger resulting from spies is greater during the long"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"periods of peace; but, for obvious reasons, they do not then attract a"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"similar amount of public attention. For this reason the subtle instinct"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"of the State parasites who came to the surface of the national body"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"through the November happenings makes them feel at once that a policy of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"alliances which would restore the freedom of our people and awaken"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"national sentiment might possibly ruin their own criminal existence."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Thus we may explain the fact that since 1918 the men who have held the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"reins of government adopted an entirely negative attitude towards"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"foreign affairs and that the business of the State has been almost"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"constantly conducted in a systematic way against the interests of the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"German nation. For that which at first sight seemed a matter of chance"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"proved, on closer examination, to be a logical advance along the road"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"which was first publicly entered upon by the November Revolution of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"1918."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Undoubtedly a distinction ought to be made between (1) the responsible"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"administrators of our affairs of State, or rather those who ought to be"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"responsible; (2) the average run of our parliamentary politicasters, and"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"(3) the masses of our people, whose sheepish docility corresponds to"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"their want of intelligence."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"The first know what they want. The second fall into line with them,"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"either because they have been already schooled in what is afoot or"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"because they have not the courage to take an uncompromising stand"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"against a course which they know and feel to be detrimental. The third"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"just submit to it because they are too stupid to understand."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"While the German National Socialist Labour Party was only a small and"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"practically unknown society, problems of foreign policy could have only"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"a secondary importance in the eyes of many of its members. This was the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"case especially because our movement has always proclaimed the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"principle, and must proclaim it, that the freedom of the country in its"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"foreign relations is not a gift that will be bestowed upon us by Heaven"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"or by any earthly Powers, but can only be the fruit of a development of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"collapse and we must eliminate all those who are profiting by that"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"collapse. Then we shall be in a position to take up the fight for the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"restoration of our freedom in the management of our foreign relations."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"It will be easily understood therefore why we did not attach so much"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"importance to foreign affairs during the early stages of our young"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"movement, but preferred to concentrate on the problem of internal"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"reform."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"But when the small and insignificant society expanded and finally grew"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"too large for its first framework, the young organization assumed the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"importance of a great association and we then felt it incumbent on us to"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"take a definite stand on problems regarding the development of a foreign"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"policy. It was necessary to lay down the main lines of action which"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"would not only be in accord with the fundamental ideas of our"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"WELTANSCHAUUNG but would actually be an expansion of it in the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"practical world of foreign affairs."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Just because our people have had no political education in matters"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"concerning our relations abroad, it was necessary to teach the leaders"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"with a question. Party politics, religious considerations, humanitarian"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"ideals--all such and all other preoccupations must absolutely give way"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"to this."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Before the War the purpose to which German foreign policy should have"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"been devoted was to assure the supply of material necessities for the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"maintenance of our people and their children. And the way should have"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"to be accomplished is the same to-day, but with this difference: In"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"condition which must be fulfilled in order that we may be able"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"lack. In other words, the aim which Germany ought to pursue to-day in"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"her foreign policy is to prepare the way for the recovery of her liberty"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"to-morrow. In this connection there is a fundamental principle which we"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"must keep steadily before our minds. It is this: The possibility of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"winning back the independence of a nation is not absolutely bound up"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"with the question of territorial reintegration but it will suffice if a"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"small remnant, no matter how small, of this nation and State will exist,"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"provided it possesses the necessary independence to become not only the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"vehicle of' the common spirit of the whole people but also to prepare"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"the way for the military fight to reconquer the nation's liberty."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"When a people who amount to a hundred million souls tolerate the yoke of"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"common slavery in order to prevent the territory belonging to their"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"retained its complete independence. Of course, the natural proviso here"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"detached members but also to prepare the means that are necessary for"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"the military conflict which will finally liberate and re-unite the"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"fragments that are suffering under oppression."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"Japanese militarism and imperialism."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Thus in England to-day the Jew opposes the policy of the State. And for"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"this reason the struggle against the Jewish world-danger will one day"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"begin also in that country."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"And here again the National Socialist Movement has a tremendous task"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"before it."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"It must open the eyes of our people in regard to foreign nations and it"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"must continually remind them of the real enemy who menaces the world"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"to-day. In place of preaching hatred against Aryans from whom we may be"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"separated on almost every other ground but with whom the bond of kindred"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"blood and the main features of a common civilization unite us, we must"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"devote ourselves to arousing general indignation against the maleficent"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"enemy of humanity and the real author of all our sufferings."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"The National Socialist Movement must see to it that at least in our own"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"country the mortal enemy is recognized and that the fight against him"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"may be a beacon light pointing to a new and better period for other"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"the struggle for its existence."	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"Finally, may reason be our guide and will-power our strength. And may"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"
"the sacred duty of directing our conduct as I have pointed out give us"	"CHAPTER XXV THE GERMAN POST-WAR POLICY OF ALLIANCES"

"CHAPTER XXVI"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPE"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"There are two considerations which induce me to make a special analysis"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of Germany's position in regard to Russia. These are:"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"(1) This may prove to be the most decisive point in determining"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Germany's foreign policy."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"(2) The problem which has to be solved in this connection is also a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"touchstone to test the political capacity of the young National"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Socialist Movement for clear thinking and acting along the right lines."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"I must confess that the second consideration has often been a source of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"great anxiety to me. The members of our movement are not recruited from"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"circles which are habitually indifferent to public affairs, but mostly"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"from among men who hold more or less extreme views. Such being the case,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"it is only natural that their understanding of foreign politics should"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"suffer from the prejudice and inadequate knowledge of those circles to"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"which they were formerly attached by political and ideological ties. And"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"this is true not merely of the men who come to us from the Left. On the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"contrary, however subversive may have been the kind of teaching they"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"formerly received in regard to these problems, in very many cases this"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"was at least partly counterbalanced by the residue of sound and natural"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"instincts which remained. In such cases it is only necessary to"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"substitute a better teaching in place of the earlier influences, in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"order to transform the instinct of self-preservation and other sound"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"instincts into valuable assets."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"On the other hand, it is much more difficult to impress definite"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"political ideas on the minds of men whose earlier political education"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"was not less nonsensical and illogical than that given to the partisans"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of the Left. These men have sacrificed the last residue of their natural"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"instincts to the worship of some abstract and entirely objective theory."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"It is particularly difficult to induce these representatives of our"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"so-called intellectual circles to take a realistic and logical view of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"their own interests and the interests of their nation in its relations"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"with foreign countries. Their minds are overladen with a huge burden of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"prejudices and absurd ideas and they have lost or renounced every"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"instinct of self-preservation. With those men also the National"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Socialist Movement has to fight a hard battle. And the struggle is all"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"the harder because, though very often they are utterly incompetent, they"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"are so self-conceited that, without the slightest justification, they"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"look down with disdain on ordinary commonsense people. These arrogant"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"snobs who pretend to know better than other people, are wholly incapable"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of calmly and coolly analysing a problem and weighing its pros and cons,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"which are the necessary preliminaries of any decision or action in the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"field of foreign politics."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"It is just this circle which is beginning to-day to divert our foreign"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"policy into most disastrous directions and turn it away from the task of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"promoting the real interests of the nation. Seeing that they do this in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"order to serve their own fantastic ideologies, I feel myself obliged to"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"take the greatest pains in laying before my own colleagues a clear"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"exposition of the most important problem in our foreign policy, namely,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"our position in relation to Russia. I shall deal with it, as thoroughly"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"as may be necessary to make it generally understood and as far as the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"limits of this book permit. Let me begin by laying down the following"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"postulate:"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"When we speak of foreign politics we understand that domain of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"government which has set before it the task of managing the affairs of a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"nation in its relations with the rest of the world. Now the guiding"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"principles which must be followed in managing these affairs must be"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"based on the definite facts that are at hand. Moreover, as National"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Socialists, we must lay down the following axiom regarding the manner in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"which the foreign policy of a People's State should be conducted:"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"The foreign policy of a People's State must first of all bear in mind"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"the duty of securing the existence of the race which is incorporated in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"this State. And this must be done by establishing a healthy and natural"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"proportion between the number and growth of the population on the one"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"hand and the extent and resources of the territory they inhabit, on the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"other. That balance must be such that it accords with the vital"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"necessities of the people."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"What I call a HEALTHY proportion is that in which the support of a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"people is guaranteed by the resources of its own soil and sub-soil. Any"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"situation which falls short of this condition is none the less unhealthy"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"even though it may endure for centuries or even a thousand years. Sooner"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"or later, this lack of proportion must of necessity lead to the decline"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"or even annihilation of the people concerned."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Only a sufficiently large space on this earth can assure the independent"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"existence of a people."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"The extent of the territorial expansion that may be necessary for the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"settlement of the national population must not be estimated by present"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"exigencies nor even by the magnitude of its agricultural productivity in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"relation to the number of the population. In the first volume of this"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"book, under the heading Germany's Policy of Alliances before the War,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"I have already explained that the geometrical dimensions of a State are"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of importance not only as the source of the nation's foodstuffs and raw"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"materials, but also from the political and military standpoints. Once a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"people is assured of being able to maintain itself from the resources of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"the national territory, it must think of how this national territory can"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"be defended. National security depends on the political strength of a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"State, and this strength, in its turn, depends on the military"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"possibilities inherent in the geographical situation."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Thus the German nation could assure its own future only by being a World"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Power. For nearly two thousand years the defence of our national"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"interests was a matter of world history, as can be seen from our more or"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"less successful activities in the field of foreign politics. We"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"ourselves have been witnesses to this, seeing that the gigantic struggle"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"that went on from 1914 to 1918 was only the struggle of the German"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"people for their existence on this earth, and it was carried out in such"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"a way that it has become known in history as the World War."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"When Germany entered this struggle it was presumed that she was a World"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Power. I say PRESUMED, because in reality she was no such thing. In"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"1914, if there had been a different proportion between the German"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"population and its territorial area, Germany would have been really a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"World Power and, if we leave other factors out of count, the War would"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"have ended in our favour."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"It is not my task nor my intention here to discuss what would have"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"happened if certain conditions had been fulfilled. But I feel it"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"absolutely incumbent on me to show the present conditions in their bare"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"and unadorned reality, insisting on the weakness inherent in them, so"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"that at least in the ranks of the National Socialist Movement they"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"should receive the necessary recognition."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Germany is not at all a World Power to-day. Even though our present"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"military weakness could be overcome, we still would have no claim to be"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"called a World Power. What importance on earth has a State in which the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"proportion between the size of the population and the territorial area"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"is so miserable as in the present German REICH? At an epoch in which the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"world is being gradually portioned out among States many of whom almost"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"embrace whole continents one cannot speak of a World Power in the case"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of a State whose political motherland is confined to a territorial area"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"of barely five-hundred-thousand square kilometres."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Looked at purely from the territorial point of view, the area comprised"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"in the German REICH is insignificant in comparison with the other States"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"that are called World Powers. England must not be cited here as an"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"example to contradict this statement; for the English motherland is in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"reality the great metropolis of the British World Empire, which owns"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"almost a fourth of the earth's surface. Next to this we must consider"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"the American Union as one of the foremost among the colossal States,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"also Russia and China. These are enormous spaces, some of which are more"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"than ten times greater in territorial extent than the present German"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"REICH. France must also be ranked among these colossal States. Not only"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"because she is adding to the strength of her army in a constantly"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"increasing measure by recruiting coloured troops from the population of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"her gigantic empire, but also because France is racially becoming more"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"and more negroid, so much so that now one can actually speak of the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"creation of an African State on European soil. The contemporary colonial"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"policy of France cannot be compared with that of Germany in the past. If"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"France develops along the lines it has taken in our day, and should that"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"development continue for the next three hundred years, all traces of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"French blood will finally be submerged in the formation of a"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"That process distinguishes French colonial policy from the policy"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"The former German colonial policy was carried out by half-measures, as"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"was almost everything they did at that time. They did not gain an"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"in German East Africa represented a small and hesitant step along this"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"road; but in reality they served only for the defence of the colony"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"itself. The idea of importing black troops to a European theatre of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"war--apart entirely from the practical impossibility of this in the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"World War--was never entertained as a proposal to be carried out under"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"favourable circumstances; whereas, on the contrary, the French always"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"looked on such an idea as fundamental in their colonial activities."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Thus we find in the world to-day not only a number of States that are"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"much greater than the German in the mere numerical size of their"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"populations, but also possess a greater support for their political"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"power. The proportion between the territorial dimensions of the German"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"REICH and the numerical size of its population was never so unfavourable"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"in comparison with the other world States as at the beginning of our"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"history two thousand years ago and again to-day. At the former juncture"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"we were a young people and we stormed a world which was made up of great"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"States that were already in a decadent condition, of which the last"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"giant was Rome, to whose overthrow we contributed. To-day we find"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"ourselves in a world of great and powerful States, among which the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"importance of our own REICH is constantly declining more and more."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"We must always face this bitter truth with clear and calm minds. We must"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"study the area and population of the German REICH in relation to the"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"other States and compare them down through the centuries. Then we shall"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"find that, as I have said, Germany is not a World Power whether its"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"military strength be great or not."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"There is no proportion between our position and that of the other States"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"throughout the world. And this lack of proportion is to be attributed to"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"the fact that our foreign policy never had a definite aim to attain, and"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"also to the fact that we lost every sound impulse and instinct for"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"self-preservation."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"If the historians who are to write our national history at some future"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"date are to give the National Socialist Movement the credit of having"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"devoted itself to a sacred duty in the service of our people, this"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"movement will have to recognize the real truth of our situation in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"regard to the rest of the world. However painful this recognition may"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"be, the movement must draw courage from it and a sense of practical"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"realities in fighting against the aimlessness and incompetence which has"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"hitherto been shown by our people in the conduct of their foreign"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"policy. Without respect for 'tradition,' and without any preconceived"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"notions, the movement must find the courage to organize our national"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"discrepancy between our territory and that of Great Britain, nor shall"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"we reach the magnitude of the United States of America. Not only that,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"but we cannot substantially lessen the importance of France in"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"international politics."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"One thing alone is certain: The attempt to restore the frontiers of"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"1914, even if it turned out successful, would demand so much bloodshed"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"on the part of our people that no future sacrifice would be possible to"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"revindicated and new ports would be opened, at least for a certain time,"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"to our commercial development."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"Against all this we, National Socialists, must stick firmly to the aim"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"that we have set for our foreign policy; namely, that the German people"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"established also before our German posterity, on the grounds that for"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"Here I must protest as sharply as possible against those nationalist"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"interests by the only effective means that can be used for that purpose."	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"
"For no nation on earth possesses a square yard of ground and soil by"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"which demarcate the territories on which other nations live. And just as"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"State frontiers are established by human beings and may be changed by"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"The fact that a nation has acquired an enormous territorial area is no"	"CHAPTER XXVI  GERMANY'S POLICY IN EASTERN EUROPES"

"CHAPTER XXVII"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"After we had laid down our arms, in November 1918, a policy was adopted"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"which in all human probability was bound to lead gradually to our"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"complete subjugation. Analogous examples from history show that those"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"nations which lay down their arms without being absolutely forced to do"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"so subsequently prefer to submit to the greatest humiliations and"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"exactions rather than try to change their fate by resorting to arms"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"again."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"That is intelligible on purely human grounds. A shrewd conqueror will"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"always enforce his exactions on the conquered only by stages, as far as"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"that is possible. Then he may expect that a people who have lost all"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"strength of character--which is always the case with every nation that"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"voluntarily submits to the threats of an opponent--will not find in any"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"of these acts of oppression, if one be enforced apart from the other,"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"sufficient grounds for taking up arms again. The more numerous the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"extortions thus passively accepted so much the less will resistance"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"appear justified in the eyes of other people, if the vanquished nation"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"should end by revolting against the last act of oppression in a long"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"series. And that is specially so if the nation has already patiently and"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"silently accepted impositions which were much more exacting."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"The fall of Carthage is a terrible example of the slow agony of a people"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"which ended in destruction and which was the fault of the people"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"themselves."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"In his THREE ARTICLES OF FAITH Clausewitz expressed this idea admirably"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"and gave it a definite form when he said: The stigma of shame incurred
by a cowardly submission can never be effaced. The drop of poison which
thus enters the blood of a nation will be transmitted to posterity. It
will undermine and paralyse the strength of later generations. But, on"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"the contrary, he added: Even the loss of its liberty after a sanguinary

"Naturally a nation which has lost all sense of honour and all strength"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"of character will not feel the force of such a doctrine. But any nation"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"

"might be frightened and driven out by such ridiculous means. And yet"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"this could have been the only purpose of an action for which the country"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"had to pay out milliards and which contributed seriously to devaluate"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"the national currency."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"Of course the French were able to make themselves almost at home in the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"Ruhr basin the moment they saw that such ridiculous measures were being"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"adopted against them. They had received the prescription directly from"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"ourselves of the best way to bring a recalcitrant civil population to a"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"sense of reason if its conduct implied a serious danger for the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"officials which the army of occupation had placed in authority. Nine"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"years previously we wiped out with lightning rapidity bands of Belgian"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"FRANCS-TIREURS and made the civil population clearly understand the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"seriousness of the situation, when the activities of these bands"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"threatened grave danger for the German army. In like manner if the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"passive resistance of the Ruhr became really dangerous for the French,"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"the armies of occupation would have needed no more than eight days to"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"bring the whole piece of childish nonsense to a gruesome end. For we"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"must always go back to the original question in all this business: What"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"were we to do if the passive resistance came to the point where it"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"really got on the nerves of our opponents and they proceeded to suppress"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"it with force and bloodshed? Would we still continue to resist? If so,"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"then, for weal or woe, we would have to submit to a severe and bloody"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"persecution. And in that case we should be faced with the same situation"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"as would have faced us in the case of an active resistance. In other"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"words, we should have to fight. Therefore the so-called passive"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"resistance would be logical only if supported by the determination to"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"come out and wage an open fight in case of necessity or adopt a kind of"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"guerilla warfare. Generally speaking, one undertakes such a struggle"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"when there is a possibility of success. The moment a besieged fortress"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"is taken by assault there is no practical alternative left to the"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"defenders except to surrender, if instead of probable death they are"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"assured that their lives will be spared. Let the garrison of a citadel"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"which has been completely encircled by the enemy once lose all hope of"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"being delivered by their friends, then the strength of the defence"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"collapses totally."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"That is why passive resistance in the Ruhr, when one considers the final"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"

"This was the classic occasion that induced us National Socialists to"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"

"And that is what we did. During those months I was attacked by people"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"

"internally more compact than ever before."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"

"the imputations and calumnies, have not been able to prevail against it."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"Thanks to the justice of its ideas, the integrity of its intentions and"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"the spirit of self-denial that animates its members, it has overcome all"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"oppression and increased its strength through the ordeal. If, in our"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"contemporary world of parliamentary corruption, our Movement remains"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"always conscious of the profound nature of its struggle and feels that"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"it personifies the values of individual personality and race, and orders"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"its action accordingly--then it may count with mathematical certainty on"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"achieving victory some day in the future. And Germany must necessarily"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"win the position which belongs to it on this Earth if it is led and"	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
"organized according to these principles."	"CHAPTER XXVII   THE RIGHT TO SELF-DEFENCE"
